webTitle: A 'hindrance to operations': extracts from the leaked reports

fields.headline: A 'hindrance to operations': extracts from the leaked reports
fields.trailText:
• Weaponry
The "reliability, robustness and 'suppressive capability"' of the light support weapon used in Kosovo was considered "insufficient", said Lt-Col Gibson's report.
fields.body:
 Weaponry
The "reliability, robustness and 'suppressive capability"' of the light support weapon used in Kosovo was considered "insufficient", said Lt-Col Gibson's report.

At night, troops worked more slowly than desired because they were not all equipped with night vision devices.

 Communications
Battle communications were a "hindrance to operations".

Radio operators resorted to using code words and "nick numbers" to disguise sensitive security details because their broadcasts could be overheard by anyone with the right equipment.

The Clansman radio equipment is "old and unreliable" with up to 35% of the units being repaired at any one time.

The communications problems were made subject of an urgent request for a secure replacement system, but the equipment was "not made available to the BG (battle group) before it left theatre," says Lt-Col Gibson's report.

Brig Freer added that the communications situation was "unworkable" for "anything other than a totally benign environment".

On ground-to-air communications, he wrote: "We were fortunate that an inadequate system was not put to the test."

 Intelligence
Tactical intelligence available to the battle groups during the operation in Kosovo was "disappointing", according to the leaked reports.

"Considerable intelligence products were available to Nato but these were not disseminated to BG (battle group) level," they say.

"In particular, imagery obtained during the air campaign was over classified and consequently not released to BGs."

They were also denied access to officers with local knowledge, such as those who had served on earlier Nato stints in Kosovo.

 Families
A lack of communication meant the families of serving personnel heard deployment details through the media rather than through official sources.

Families found out about the initial deployment from the BBC 24 to 36 hours before soldiers had the decision confirmed by their chain of command.

 Equipment
A lack of equipment led to soldiers sleeping on floors and rarely being able to take a shower during deployment in Pristina.

Many troops purchased their own solar shower bags and camp beds "to improve their living conditions", said the leaked reports.

Members of the 1st Battalion Parachute Regiment bought their own global positioning satellite receivers because there were not enough to go around.

There was also a shortage of other items of equipment, such as "plasticuffs" for use in public order situations.

 Spin-doctoring
One of the reports seems to suggest that "spin-doctoring" of the Kosovo campaign by the ministry of defence led to a lot of time being wasted.

Lt-Col Gibson wrote that while most media coverage was supportive, "on the few occasions when adverse articles might have been written, there seemed to be concern and subsequently disproportionate command and staff effort expended over the potential implications of such articles.

"This may be a product of MOD 'spin-doctoring'.

"Commanders and staff need to be much more positive in the face of the media."

Lt-Col Gibson advocated full co-operation with the media and said "black-listing" of news organisations who were not supportive "denied them access to stories and was an effective solution".

"Soldiers dealing within the BG were continually briefed on the pitfalls when dealing with the press. Experience suggested that journalists are usually delighted to be spoon-fed with direction, advice and, on occasions, copy."

 Command
A delay in dividing responsibilities between the national forces and K-For "meant that soldiers were initially operating in something of a vacuum which lasted for several days", said the reports.

The chain of command left much to be desired. Brigadier Freer commented: "A clear chain of command is a basic principle of military operations and the blurred lines which existed only served to cause confusion."

The "confused and fractured" lines of command "may have had a damaging effect on morale", adds the report.

The situation eroded troops' confidence in the chain of command and had the potential to place individual soldiers in "an invidious position".

 Legal powers
Soldiers in Operation Agricola were not made aware of their legal powers before being deployed in Pristina, says one of the reports.

It paints a picture of a confused and legally toothless military force.

The report adds: "Appropriate advice was slow to arrive. Advice often dodged the issue referring the matter back to the judgment of the soldier on the ground.

"There was much discussion about law and legal procedures but little application of justice. There seemed to be a great fear of both adverse publicity and the possibility of future litigation. Suspected war criminals could only be detained for a few hours before they had to be released."

Lt-Col Gibson added that the Albanian community, in particular, meted out violence on Serbs "sure in the knowledge that the BG (battle group) was impotent to do anything to stop them".

fields.headline: Hughes' instant hit buoys Blues
fields.trailText: When this fixture was first scheduled the smart money would have been on Birmingham to be the pacesetters and Huddersfield the also-rans.
fields.body:
When this fixture was first scheduled the smart money would have been on Birmingham to be the pacesetters and Huddersfield the also-rans.

But the arrival of Steve Bruce as manager and an outlay of £5m on new players had helped propel Huddersfield to second place prior to kick-off. In contrast City, who have suffered injuries that would tax the resources of most clubs, have slipped to 13th. Yesterday, though, pre-season predictions held sway at the expense of the mid-season formbook.

Town, who lost to Charlton a week ago, experienced another setback in the race for the Premiership when they lost for the second game in a row. And it was a defeat that did not take long in coming.

Just 12 seconds had elapsed when Bryan Hughes headed home Gary Rowett's right-wing cross for the country's first goal of the millennium to put the home side on course for their first win in five games. That set the pattern for the next hour, until a moment that Bruce felt was pivotal. Hitherto the City goalkeeper Ian Bennett had not had a save to make, but Bruce believed he should have been called into action in the 63rd minute when Marcus Stewart was bundled over by Darren Purse. "As far as I'm concerned it was a blatant penalty," Bruce said.

That apart Bruce had few complaints about his side's failure to win at the ground he graced as a player for two years. Neither did he have any complaints about the decision to disallow Clive Wijnhard's stooping header for offside.

By then, though, City would have been safe had it not been for some smart defensive work by the visitors. The substitute John Dyson was on hand to clear a David Holdsworth shot off the line shortly after the break when Nico Vaesen was stranded, but Town's keeper did not need any assistance when he produced two fine saves to thwart Marcelo and Rowett.

Ten minutes from time an even better save from Bennett to keep out Stewart's header ensured City earned a victory their endeavour deserved.

webTitle: Jack gets his skates on at ice-cold Alex

fields.headline: Jack gets his skates on at ice-cold Alex
fields.trailText: Nostradamus would have been stoned had he predicted the opening of the millennium for Manchester City fans.
fields.body:
Nostradamus would have been stoned had he predicted the opening of the millennium for Manchester City fans.

Playing a league game at Crewe while your hated rivals go for a clean sweep of international trophies after being crowned winners of everything worth winning in Europe would have been too much to bear.

And that represents an improvement. The current crop of City youngsters is making a gallant effort to return the club to the heights it once ascended.

Indeed City should have been making the short trip back up the M6 with all three points. It took a superb Rodney Jack goal to bring the home side a share of the spoils after a hard-fought match in slippery conditions finally took its toll on leg-weary players.

Until then City had looked decent value to maintain their four-point lead at the First Division summit. But, boy, was it heavy going.

Good passing football was in evidence despite the conditions. Indeed, the Crewe fan who was asked his postcode on collecting his tickets proved to be a diviner more accurate than Nostradamus. "SK8," he said. How apt.

But City adapted better to the conditions and it was from a heavily sanded quarter of the field that Bob Taylor sent Lee Crooks inside and the defender drove home a low 20-yarder that Jason Kearton will be disappointed about.

He made amends a couple of times from Shaun Goater as the game fairly fizzed along and City's goalkeeper Nicky Weaver was also given the chance to show off his not inconsiderable talents. He produced a magnificently acrobatic stop to keep out Kevin Street's 20-yard curler as the first half drew to an exciting close.

Apart from Jack's goal - a magnificent right-foot strike from the edge of the box after a rare Gerard Wiekens lapse - the second half failed to hit the same heights.

webTitle: Chaos as Maracana builds up for United

fields.headline: Chaos as Maracana builds up for United
fields.trailText: Judging by the chaos at the Maracana, the builders believe Manchester United kick off there not in two days but in two months. Forget the heat, Sir Alex Ferguson's team should consider playing their World Club Championship opener in hard hats.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Judging by the chaos at the Maracana, the builders believe Manchester United kick off there not in two days but in two months. Forget the heat, Sir Alex Ferguson's team should consider playing their World Club Championship opener in hard hats.

Less than 72 hours before United take on Necaxa of Mexico, and less than 11 days before it hosts the final, the Maracana is a building site. Seats are missing, drills are whirring, paint is being hastily slapped on.

Work began almost two months ago and is going on round the clock. No fewer than 500 people are trying to transform this crumbling concrete monster into a palace fit for the king of Fifa, Sepp Blatter, by Thursday night. "It will be fully finished," a spokesman insisted.

For the first time since it was built half a century ago, the Maracana will be an all-seat stadium; Fifa demands as much. United's 400 travelling fans will not be segregated.

An estimated 205,000 people watched the decisive World Cup game there between Brazil and Uruguay in 1950. For this tournament the capacity will be 75,000, which will rise again to 110,000 when sections of terracing reopen. An important Rio derby, such as Flamengo v Vasco da Gama, can attract crowds of that size.

It may not be up to the standard of Old Trafford but, as John Barnes once recalled, that is not the point. Barnes, the scorer of a wonderful goal there for England in 1984, noted: "Despite the awful facilities I was still treading the turf of the fabled Maracana, a name which always conjures up magic. Never mind the decay, the Maracana has history and mystique."

United, who play all their games there, are thought to be angered that they can train on the pitch only tomorrow rather than before every match. Better news for them is that it is overcast and cooler than expected, though the heat is forecast to return by the end of the week.

With that in mind, Ferguson has banned his players from sunbathing for more than 45 minutes. Also out are drinking tap water, eating shellfish, wearing jewellery in public and going out except in large groups. Perhaps, en masse, they could lend the builders at the Maracana a hand.

webTitle: Depleted Leicester prevail as Elliott spoils Everton's party

fields.headline: Depleted Leicester prevail as Elliott spoils Everton's party
fields.trailText: Toffee or not toffee? Everton ended the millennium with a theatrical flourish at Goodison Park but started the new one with much less style.
fields.body:
Toffee or not toffee? Everton ended the millennium with a theatrical flourish at Goodison Park but started the new one with much less style.

Bill Kenwright's entrance was marked by the five-goal destruction of Sunderland but Leicester made sure this was a much more prosaic performance from Everton in front of the watching impresario and owner-in-waiting.

At least they preserved their unbeaten home record in the Premiership this season with an improved second half team display that earned the reward of a penalty equaliser from David Unsworth and a point to make it six matches without defeat.

However, it was a point that looked unlikely for 20 minutes for half-time as Leicester, typically, made two route one attacks count through the considerable strength in the air of Matt Elliott.

Leicester manager Martin O'Neill has constantly complained about a paper-thin squad and a long injury list but, in fact, it proved to be the main threat as his side ended a run of four Premiership defeats.

Defender Elliott was pushed into an emergency role alongside Tony Cottee because of the injuries and the suspension to Emile Heskey, and the captain created all the damage.

Indeed, Leicester's injury problems worsened in the sixth minute when keeper Tim Flowers was carried off on a stretcher - and taken to hospital with knee ligament trouble - after a collision with Nick Barmby, and replaced by Pegguy Arphexad.

And it was the Frenchman whose long-range combination with Elliott produced Leicester's two first half goals after they fell behind in the 16th minute, when a 25-yard drive by David Weir hit Don Hutchison to end up in the back of the net, with the goal likely to be credited to the midfielder.

Then the long-range one-two between the Leicester keeper and Elliott stunned the Everton crown in the 25th minute. Arphexad's long clearance was headed on by the Scottish international and he continued his run to pick up a ball from Theo Zagorakis and drill the equaliser passed Paul Gerrard.

Weir missed the target badly from 15-yards a minute earlier for Everton and the error was punished severely again in the 32nd minute with Elliott featuring as maker and taker.

Another long ball from Arphexah was headed on by Elliott and Cottee's nagging presence prompted a mix up between Dave Watson and Gerrard. Again Elliott profited with a goal.

Everton went into shell after Leicester's equaliser but were handed a lifeline in the 57th minute when Frank Sinclair handled in the box and Unsworth stepped up to equalise from the spot.

Everton honoured their 10 selected greatest players from the last century but manager Walter Smith acknowledged their performance did not match the memory of names like Dave Hickson, Alex Young and Howard Kendall.

"We didn't play well enough to claim that we should have won and we're all disappointed we didn't produce the level of performance we have in previous home matches," he said.

fields.headline: Hungry Spurs sense rich pickings
fields.trailText: A win for Liverpool here yesterday might have taken them to third but they did not look quite ready for a place at the high table. Anfield's hopes of rejoining English football's elite have improved of late but on a sodden afternoon in north London Tottenham's pursuit of mere middle-class respectability turned out to be the stronger motivation.
fields.byline: David Lacey at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
A win for Liverpool here yesterday might have taken them to third but they did not look quite ready for a place at the high table. Anfield's hopes of rejoining English football's elite have improved of late but on a sodden afternoon in north London Tottenham's pursuit of mere middle-class respectability turned out to be the stronger motivation.

A firmly struck shot from Chris Armstrong midway through the first half brought Spurs the victory their better sense of purpose and direction deserved. It was Armstrong's 50th goal for the club, a landmark which would surely have been reached rather earlier had the player accepted more of the sort of chances he missed yesterday.

Had Tottenham not won it would have been a palpable insult to the quality of service consistently provided by David Ginola, whose crossing regularly exposed a Liverpool defence which still has not rediscovered the knack of dealing with dangerous high balls. Ginola's importance to the result was underlined by the fact that for once he was not substituted and to the end remained Spurs' principal threat.

This was only Liverpool's second defeat in 13 league games and their first since losing 1-0 at West Ham at the end of November. The absence of Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler, each suffering a recurrence of a recent injury, meant that however neat the build-up their attack was always likely to lack a punchline. But Gérard Houllier blamed the overall performance.

"Being without Owen and Fowler didn't help," the Liverpool manager admitted, "but if you've got a good squad you have to overcome this. The fact was that I didn't recognise the team in the first half today.

"The character we had shown in away games wasn't there. There was an improvement in the second half but we have to admit that Tottenham wanted to win more than we did. They were first to the ball and created more chances."

Certainly the pedigree of the opposition continues to bring out the best in George Graham's side at White Hart Lane. Creditable home victories over Manchester United, Arsenal and now Liverpool suggest that Tottenham are closer to becoming a serious force than they have been for some time.

The 6-1 defeat Spurs suffered at Newcastle three days before Christmas appears to have jolted their system. Yesterday there was little doubting the players' desire to spend the rest of the season seeking the Uefa Cup place which should be well within their capabilities.

The determination with which Spurs pursued victory kept the crowd in high optimism from first to last. Overall it was a fast, watchable encounter with Liverpool's patient, precise passing offering a sharp contrast to their opponents' swift, direct movements.

In the absence of Owen and Fowler, Titi Camara became the focal point of Liverpool's attack. His battle of wits with Sol Campbell provided an intriguing contest within a contest and, while the England defender usually had Camara's measure, he was beaten often enough to set up the basis of a Liverpool win.

webTitle: Gunners so wide of an easy target

fields.headline: Gunners so wide of an easy target
fields.trailText: Little more than 24 hours after touching down in Brazil, Sir Alex Ferguson and his Manchester United players are finding life a beach. With the champions away, Arsenal had the opportunity to plunder all they can only to be found wanting at the first obstacle.
fields.body:
Little more than 24 hours after touching down in Brazil, Sir Alex Ferguson and his Manchester United players are finding life a beach. With the champions away, Arsenal had the opportunity to plunder all they can only to be found wanting at the first obstacle.

Eight years have past since Arsenal's last victory at Hillsborough but, with Sheffield Wednesday marooned, there can never have been a better chance to take advantage of United's absence.

"Bearing in mind Wednesday are bottom you can say we have dropped two points because one is not enough for us," admitted a rueful Arsène Wenger.

The routine victory that had been expected of Arsenal seemed well on course when Emmanuel Petit put them ahead three minutes before the interval with a goal stunning in its creation and clinical in its execution. Thierry Henry's intelligent flick dissected the home defence and his compatriot was allowed to run unchallenged into the penalty area before enticing Pavel Srnicek from his goal line and expertly clipping the ball beyond him with the outside of his left boot.

However, it was one of the few occasions when Arsenal exposed the gulf in ability against a side who have officially clocked up the worst start in Premiership history.

Perhaps in Arsenal's case, more than most, this really is the dawning of a new era. Only David Seaman and Tony Adams merited a starting place from their famous back five until Mark Overmars was forced out after only 29 minutes, allowing Nigel Winterburn to restore a more customary look to the visiting side.

Overmars had gone down in obvious distress following an innocuous challenge by Wim Jonk and his loss will be United's gain. "He has an ankle problem and we will have to see how bad it is," said Wenger.

A key component missing, Arsenal lacked their usual cohesion but remained largely untroubled until 11 minutes after the interval when Wednesday had the audacity to equalise. Ian Nolan's right-wing delivery hung in the air for an age and when it came down Gerald Sibon was at the far post to direct a firm header into the opposite corner.

All of which begs the question as to why he has been so sparingly used since his £2m arrival from Ajax last summer. "You won't see a better header than that all season," said Wednesday's manager Danny Wilson. "It's been a frustrating time for Gerald because he's not had many games but there are parts of his game that need working on".

It could have been even worse for Arsenal. As Wednesday flourished, the Londoners wilted and by the final whistle they were gratefully clinging on to their solitary point.

Had Niclas Alexandersson's left-foot volley been a few inches to the left rather than striking the base of Seaman's left hand post, the most improbable of comebacks would have been complete. Arsenal also had their chances during a grandstand finish, most notably when Frederik Ljungberg's header was clawed away by Srnicek, but it was the hosts who finished with the greater verve and purpose.

Nevertheless, they are surely doomed and a substantial contingent of the home fans held a minute's silence before kick-off to mark the demise of Wednesday's top-flight status. By the end, however, many questions hung over Arsenal.

webTitle: Derby raise a glass to Strupar's debut double

fields.headline: Derby raise a glass to Strupar's debut double
fields.trailText: On screens around the ground before this match Derby's in-house television channel featured classic goals from Kevin Hector, Charlie George and Franny Lee. By the time Derby's next home match rolls round you can be sure Branko Strupar's first two goals in the Premiership will also be figuring prominently.
fields.body:
On screens around the ground before this match Derby's in-house television channel featured classic goals from Kevin Hector, Charlie George and Franny Lee. By the time Derby's next home match rolls round you can be sure Branko Strupar's first two goals in the Premiership will also be figuring prominently.

Strupar, who joined Derby's United Nations squad last month for £3m from Racing Club Genk, scored both their goals in their defeat of Watford.

Derby badly needed someone of his quality after a depressing run of form which had seen them lose eight of their previous 10 Premiership matches and score just seven goals as they dropped into the bottom three.

It took Strupar less than two minutes to start Derby's millennium on a brighter note. Avi Nimni had just wasted a good opportunity by dwelling on the ball too long when Rory Delap crossed the ball into the middle of Watford's defence.

Robert Page and Steve Palmer made a hash of the clearance and when the ball found its way to Strupar on the edge of the penalty area he drilled a powerful shot past Alec Chamberlain.

Watford had an opportunity to draw level within two minutes when Charlie Miller's deft ball caught out the Derby defence. But Michael Ngonge elected to try to lob Mart Poom rather than shoot low and the Estonian goalkeeper was able to claw his shot away.

Watford never created such a clear chance again, leaving Taylor wishing he had someone of Strupar's class in his side.

It was a message powerfully driven home when Strupar scored his second in the 72nd minute. If the first was mostly about sheer brawn, this one owed as much to subtlety. From a 20-yard free-kick, awarded for a foul by Page, he curled his shot around the wall and beyond Chamberlain. Strupar almost completed his hat-trick in the 89th minute when he pounced upon a mistake by Page and sped clear. But he squared to Marvin Robinson, whose shot was blocked.

Unfortunately for Derby, Strupar is suspended for their next match because of a sending-off in Belgium. Their manager Jim Smith preferred instead to dwell on the victory which lifted his side out of the relegation zone.

"It was a big win for us," he admitted. "Branko is a quality player although he finds it a lot quicker here than he did in Belgium. But he'll adjust."

For Watford, who remain second from bottom, all their intensity did not translate itself into class. "The last thing I would do is criticise the players for effort but the lack of quality is there for people to see," said Taylor.

webTitle: Southgate strikes, Leeds pay the penalty

fields.headline: Southgate strikes, Leeds pay the penalty
fields.trailText: The ending of Leeds United's run of 12 straight home victories surely also ended any lingering speculation about the job security of Aston Villa's manager John Gregory.
fields.body:
The ending of Leeds United's run of 12 straight home victories surely also ended any lingering speculation about the job security of Aston Villa's manager John Gregory.

Gareth Southgate, a man for whom the 1990s will inexorably be linked with missed penalty kicks, opened the new decade in more fruitful fashion with both Villa goals. This was a deserved away success against the Premiership leaders, on what may prove a pivotal day in the title race.

"All the other results went for us," said the Leeds manager David O'Leary, "but the team that will laugh most is Manchester United in Brazil - and they have been the yardstick all along. When you don't play well at home you still want to pick up a point, and we could have come off the pitch with at least a draw."

O'Leary had previously suggested that Leeds's to-be-rearranged match against United at Elland Road should be reserved until the last game of the season. The chances of it being a title decider receded yesterday, and the manner in which Leeds failed to cope with an injury and suspension list that denied them Lucas Radebe, Lee Bowyer, David Batty, David Hopkin and Stephen McPhail may offer an uncanny comparison with the plight of Villa 12 months ago.

Gregory believes his team's capitulation last season, in which they won just four of their final 17 games having led the league at the turn of the year, was the result of a lack of depth in his squad.

"Even a club like Manchester United would find it pretty hard to lose their entire midfield," O'Leary offered in mitigation. "But you are judged over a season and, as I have said all along, I don't know where we will finish.

"United are the best team in the league and that's a fact. We're trying to do our best but it's a young side, and today it was a really, really young side."

Such naivete - a characteristic O'Leary is so fond of telling you he also possesses as a manager - was exposed at the two set pieces that brought Southgate his first Villa goals since December 1998.

In the 19th minute his goalbound header from a Paul Merson corner struck his team-mate Julian Joachim on the back, only for Southgate to scramble it into the net with a fortunate mishit.

Then, just after the hour, Merson's free-kick found Southgate eluding Jonathon Woodgate at the back of the Leeds area to score with a stooping header.

"He's known as 'The Ornament'," said the tirelessly entertaining Gregory. "He goes up for every corner, every free-kick and becomes, well, an ornament! He never touches the ball so he was an unlikely match winner, to say the least."

In between Southgate's efforts, Harry Kewell conjured a superb individual equaliser 11 seconds into the second half. The Australian chested down a loose ball just inside the Villa half, played it off his knee and sent a 35-yard half-volley screaming past the despairing David James.

But, with the driving mechanism effectively removed from Leeds's engine, O'Leary's team failed to capitalise against a Villa side who were themselves lacking Ian Taylor and Dion Dublin.

Indeed, it took a staggering double-save from Nigel Martyn to prevent the scoreline embarrassing Leeds further. He kept out Merson's header from Steve Watson's cross with an acrobatic one-handed leap, before somehow deflecting a follow-up strike from George Boateng over his bar.

Another Villa absentee, of course, was Gregory himself, currently serving a touchline ban that has coincided with an impressive run of 10 points in four games.

"I think it has been beneficial - the players certainly like it," said Gregory of his exile in the stand. "It is something more intelligent managers than me do anyway, and something I'll continue with."

webTitle: Hammers hand Robson a youthful lesson

fields.headline: Hammers hand Robson a youthful lesson
fields.trailText: Nikos Dabizas may have had the honour of registering Newcastle United's first goal of the 21st century, but by the end all the attention was being lavished upon the nearest thing football has to a bunch of millennium babies.
fields.byline: David Hopps at St James' Park
fields.body:
Nikos Dabizas may have had the honour of registering Newcastle United's first goal of the 21st century, but by the end all the attention was being lavished upon the nearest thing football has to a bunch of millennium babies.

West Ham, with 10 senior players injured, fielded three of last season's Youth Cup winning side, with another three staring starry-eyed from the bench. All this talk of a new era of youthful opportunity has clearly had an uplifting effect, for the Hammers scored twice in the last five minutes to steal a point that had seemed beyond them.

Nobody could have complained had Newcastle, with 15 minutes remaining, gone three ahead, when Kevin Gallacher, still without a goal for the club, responded in disbelief as Shaka Hislop turned aside his ferocious drive.

"Shaka has been an unbelievable free transfer," said West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp and as it was Newcastle from whence he came, the reminder was hard to bear.

Newcastle, perhaps crucially, had lost Rob Lee to a thigh injury soon after half-time. His replacement, Jose Antunes, is the sort who cannot make up his mind about his name or allegiance, being known as Fumaca in various other loan deals around the country.

Neither could he decide whether to mark Frank Lampard, who with great deliberation stroked a 25-yard shot wide of Steve Harper and in off the left post.

Newcastle were equally slack for West Ham's equaliser three minutes from time. Joe Cole, who had coped maturely with an unfamiliar role just behind a lone striker, Trevor Sinclair, was fouled 30 yards from goal. From Sinclair's free kick, Igor Stimac was left unmarked to head his first goal for West Ham.

"The kids did great," said Redknapp. "I was going to bring on a 16-year-old - Jermaine Defoe - as well but he's probably got school in the morning."

Talk of all these West Ham youngsters is a particular embarrassment for Newcastle. Successive managers showed disregard for youth development in one of the most fertile breeding grounds in the land and Bobby Robson has been left to address such stupidity. His recovery has been based on sound principles and seemed set to continue when Dabizas shot past Hislop, who was still reeling from Alan Shearer's challenge for Alessandro Pistone's hanging cross.

All thoughts of a West Ham recovery seemed to evaporate by the mid-point of the second half. First Harper dashed across his line to save brilliantly from Marc Keller after Sinclair had outfoxed Pistone. Then Newcastle scored a second. Solano jinked infield from the right and his low cross was met by Gary Speed's perfectly executed volley.

Newcastle, with victory seeming assured, then fell asleep. Well, it's been an exhausting week and only a bunch of teenagers would be too insouciant to realise it.

fields.headline: Saints party like it's 1999
fields.trailText: For Southampton it is always but a small step from the party to sobriety. The threat of relegation is never far away, but they were able to give their nerve ends a respite yesterday.
fields.body:
For Southampton it is always but a small step from the party to sobriety. The threat of relegation is never far away, but they were able to give their nerve ends a respite yesterday.

It was hard to reconcile the drum beating of the local radio man who insisted "they don't come any bigger than this" with recent form displayed by these sides, but this was a win of some magnitude for Dave Jones's team. Thanks to Kevin Davies's third goal in as many games they achieved their first victory here since August and put daylight between themselves and their Yorkshire visitors, who slip into the bottom three.

"We have allowed the other teams to catch up, which was disappointing after the good start we had," admitted Jones. "We could have made life a lot easier for ourselves today but overall I think we deserved it."

Last season Southampton won seven of their final nine games at the Dell to stay afloat. Though a long road still lies ahead the view looks better for them than it does for Bradford.

After his travails at Blackburn and the growing suspicion that he was a Premiership performer only in transfer valuations and not through deeds on the field, Davies can continue to be a crucial figure for them as long as confidence remains on his side.

Yesterday the drive and determination the young striker displayed throughout made it entirely appropriate that his header 11 minutes into the second half should prove decisive. He found half a yard as the Bradford defence hesitated at a Stuart Ripley free-kick and it was enough for him to defeat Matt Clark.

"When he came back Kevin did not have a head on his shoulders. It was somewhere under his arm," said Jones. "Whatever went on at Blackburn, hopefully he has learned from the experience. He needed to prove something to himself above all and with his goals he is starting to do just that."

Soon after scoring Davies found himself back in his own goalmouth with a vital intervention as Lee Mills shaped to shoot. His strength in the air helped keep Saints in the ascendancy and with Ripley and Luis Boa Morte relishing every opportunity to take on their opposite numbers the home team had the means to make this a more convincing win.

The woodwork played its part. Jo Tessem rattled the crossbar before half-time and Marian Pahars later placed his shot against the inside of a post.

Bradford survived and when Robbie Blake was introduced there was suddenly a new dimension to their raids.

Blake raced into the area to give himself just Paul Jones to beat. Not only did the Welshman block that attempt he also did enough to distract Dean Saunders, who could only hook the rebound over.

The goalkeeper came under attack from his own supporters, who wanted to see him gather the ball more cleanly. Yet with rain sweeping across the pitch conditions were particularly difficult for goalkeepers.

Many tackles were mistimed on the slippery surface but commendably David Elleray kept his cards in his pocket. Even Dave Jones was impressed.

"Credit where it's due, even if David is not my flavour and I've had a few run-ins with him. If I'm going to give marks out of 10 he'll get at least a four."

It was hard to reconcile the drum beating of the local radio man who insisted "they don't come any bigger than this" with recent form displayed by these sides, but this was a win of some magnitude for Dave Jones's team. Thanks to Kevin Davies's third goal in as many games they achieved their first victory here since August and put daylight between themselves and their Yorkshire visitors, who slip into the bottom three. "We have allowed the other teams to catch up, which was disappointing after the good start we had," admitted Jones. "We could have made life a lot easier for ourselves today but overall I think we deserved it." Last season Southampton won seven of their final nine games at the Dell to stay afloat. Though a long road still lies ahead the view looks better for them than it does for Bradford. After his travails at Blackburn and the growing suspicion that he was a Premiership performer only in transfer valuations and not through deeds on the field, Davies can continue to be a crucial figure for them as long as confidence remains on his side. Yesterday the drive and determination the young striker displayed throughout made it entirely appropriate that his header 11 minutes into the second half should prove decisive. He found half a yard as the Bradford defence hesitated at a Stuart Ripley free-kick and it was enough for him to defeat Matt Clark. "When he came back Kevin did not have a head on his shoulders. It was somewhere under his arm," said Jones. "Whatever went on at Blackburn, hopefully he has learned from the experience. He needed to prove something to himself above all and with his goals he is starting to do just that." Soon after scoring Davies found himself back in his own goalmouth with a vital intervention as Lee Mills shaped to shoot. His strength in the air helped keep Saints in the ascendancy and with Ripley and Luis Boa Morte relishing every opportunity to take on their opposite numbers the home team had the means to make this a more convincing win. The woodwork played its part. Jo Tessem rattled the crossbar before half-time and Marian Pahars later placed his shot against the inside of a post. Bradford survived and when Robbie Blake was introduced there was suddenly a new dimension to their raids. Blake raced into the area to give himself just Paul Jones to beat. Not only did the Welshman block that attempt he also did enough to distract Dean Saunders, who could only hook the rebound over. The goalkeeper came under attack from his own supporters, who wanted to see him gather the ball more cleanly. Yet with rain sweeping across the pitch conditions were particularly difficult for goalkeepers. Many tackles were mistimed on the slippery surface but commendably David Elleray kept his cards in his pocket. Even Dave Jones was impressed. "Credit where it's due, even if David is not my flavour and I've had a few run-ins with him. If I'm going to give marks out of 10 he'll get at least a four."

webTitle: Wear wolves have turned into lambs

fields.headline: Wear wolves have turned into lambs
fields.trailText: Sunderland were relegated from the Premiership after losing at Wimbledon in May 1997. Yesterday's defeat against the same club may signal a different sort of demise.
fields.body:
Sunderland were relegated from the Premiership after losing at Wimbledon in May 1997. Yesterday's defeat against the same club may signal a different sort of demise.

Peter Reid's Premiership upstarts have taken only one point from the past nine and suddenly the sound of bubbles bursting has nothing to do with new year champagne.

Though they had six first-team players out injured, Wimbledon's makeshift side made relatively easy work of taking three points to ease themselves away from the relegation mire.

Had they won, Sunderland could have gone third. But they began the game as if they were still preening themselves about the past year rather than getting to grips with the next. And they paid the price.

Unusually for a team whose success has been built on fight and spirit, Sunderland seemed laid-back for much of the first half and struggled to get to grips with a game played in driving rain on a deteriorating pitch.

It would be falling into a stereotyping trap to say this is Wimbledon's natural habitat, but certainly they adjusted to the conditions far better and could have been three up after 15 minutes.

First, Andy Marriott, replacing the flu-ridden Thomas Sorensen in goal, saved well from Carl Cort. The England Under-21 striker then fired wide from an inviting position and soon after Jason Euell shot at the goalkeeper when he was put in six yards out. So it was hardly a surprise when Wimbledon opened the scoring on the half-hour.

After a rare Sunderland counter-attack broke down the visitors were caught short at the back. A twist and turn on the left of the area by the impressive Martin Andresen ended with a little chip to the back of the six-yard box, where Cort, unmarked, headed past Marriott for his 13th goal of the season.

Despite Niall Quinn and Kevin Phillips being passed fit, Sunderland struggled to pose any serious threat to Neil Sullivan's goal, mainly for want of a decent final ball. And it did not help when Nicky Summerbee went off injured after a clash with Ben Thatcher in the build-up to the goal.

It was only as half-time approached that the visitors began to wake from their slumbers and they should have equalised seconds before the break when Phillips uncharacteristically fired a seven-yard shot straight at the goalkeeper.

Whatever Reid said at half-time certainly did the trick as Sunderland emerged a reinvigorated side. Quinn soon headed just over then Kevin Kilbane held off Kenny Cunningham in the area only to see his goalbound shot tipped away acrobatically by Sullivan.

Wimbleon also went close through Hermann Hreidarsson and Euell but it was Sunderland who had the bit between their teeth and as the minutes increased so did the visiting side's pressure and desperation.

With seconds left Phillips cut in from the left and cracked a 20-yard drive against the angle. Soon afterwards Quinn headed goalward only to see Sullivan pull off a diving save.

Sunderland have enjoyed a great start to this season, but not a great start to the year.

webTitle: Stump mike catches testy Gough's taunt

fields.headline: Stump mike catches testy Gough's taunt
fields.trailText: Allan Donald would be the first to admit he is no longer bowling as quickly as he used to. Darren Gough would never admit to such a thing. Gough is always full of bluster, has one eye on the speedometer reading at third man and tries his rocks off for his side.
fields.body:
Allan Donald would be the first to admit he is no longer bowling as quickly as he used to. Darren Gough would never admit to such a thing. Gough is always full of bluster, has one eye on the speedometer reading at third man and tries his rocks off for his side.

Yet in this series a below-par Donald has taken twice as many wickets as a below-par Gough, and the difference is beginning to show. Donald has just taken his 20th five-wicket haul in Tests on this most unresponsive of Newlands pitches. He was helped by the benevolence of various England batsmen and the quick reactions of Gary Kirsten who took four catches of varying degrees of difficulty.

Donald had assistance at the Wanderers too: troubled by injury and a technical glitch, he was gifted the most bowler-friendly surface imaginable on which to ply his trade. He took 11 wickets as South Africa steamrollered England in the opening Test.

Gough, in contrast, has just 10 wickets in the series. He came into the tour without having bowled in serious cricket since early summer and looked slightly overweight and understandably rusty. A fast bowler need overs under his belt for rhythm and fitness and Gough has taken too long for England's liking to get into his stride on this tour.

His frustration appears to be mounting. Lack of wickets preys on a bowler's mind and Gough knows how much England have relied on him to spearhead their attack. Andy Caddick has now taken over his mantle as the leading strike bowler, but clearly England would be a much more potent attacking force with Gough at his best.

Gough does not relish relinquishing his leading role and there are signs of petulance emerging. Yesterday he continued his run-in with the former England fast bowler, Bob Willis, now a Sky Sports commentator. This began in the previous match in Durban when Gough was heard to say over the stump microphone "This is a waste of time" as England were toiling on the last day to dislodge South Africa for a second time.

Willis responded by saying in his commentary "If you think it's a waste of time, Darren, then you shouldn't be out there". Gough took exception to the remark and yesterday just before tea when he was heard to say over the stump mike "How would you bowl on this, Willis?" it was obvious his frustration was taking over.

The simple answer is that Willis would have bowled with as much heart and effort as Gough has done through his career, but the Yorkshireman has rather missed the point. Gough does not need to trouble himself with anything but his own bowling. He must let the ball do the talking.

Gough would do well to study Donald's approach. Both bowlers have known frustration and unrewarded hard work but Donald seems to have the more equable temperament. Gough used to be able to laugh it all off, come success or stress, but no more.

Ask a sports psychologist what makes the difference between success and failure in any player, at any level, and the answer will essentially take up one word: attitude. Until this series Gough's attitude has always appeared exemplary on the field but now his frustration is affecting this, his most precious asset. The best bowlers never blame the pitch, the wind, the footholds, the ball, the batsman or the fielders. They just get on with the job.

Donald will never let himself be dragged down by such distractions. Gough has been England's bowling beacon since coming into the side, his brilliant attitude the key to his performances. Now is no time to change all that.

fields.headline: Langer escapes to hit 167
fields.trailText: Justin Langer rode his luck to score an unbeaten 167 as Australia reached 331 for four on the second day of the third and final Test against India at Sydney.
fields.body:
Justin Langer rode his luck to score an unbeaten 167 as Australia reached 331 for four on the second day of the third and final Test against India at Sydney.

After India had been dismissed for 150, Langer shared a 121-run partnership with his captain Steve Waugh, who scored 57, and a 97 stand with Mark Waugh, who made 32.

Langer made a nervous start and had an escape on 45 when he played on to Javagal Srinath only for the delivery to be no-balled.

"Between zero and 47 was the worst I have ever batted," Langer admitted.

"Between 47 and 150 was probably as well as I hit them and at the end it was probably back to the worst."

webTitle: Flintoff injury piles on woe for England

fields.headline: Flintoff injury piles on woe for England
fields.trailText: Andrew Flintoff, the all-rounder on whom England have pinned their future hopes, broke a bone in his left foot while bowling at Newlands yesterday.
fields.body:
Andrew Flintoff, the all-rounder on whom England have pinned their future hopes, broke a bone in his left foot while bowling at Newlands yesterday.

Flintoff appeared in distress after completing his fourth over of the day and sat on the pitch with his boot removed before hobbling from the field. An x-ray revealed a crack in the metatarsal bone adjacent to his big toe.

He will see a specialist this morning. Although early for a confident prognosis, it seems unlikely he will be able to bowl for some time and could miss not just the end of the Test series, but the one-day matches which follow.

According to the England physiotherapist Dean Conway, the injury was not stress-related, but was caused by a single impact. It is not a complete fracture (which would mean six-to-eight weeks on the sidelines) but roughly a third the width of the bone.

"Had he attempted to bowl even one or two more deliveries, it could have been made considerably worse," said Conway.

"He certainly will be unable to bowl again in this match and probably the next as well. He is in pain and will have to bat with a runner in the second innings.

"It is difficult to say whether he would be fit for the one-day squad but he must be considered doubtful as far as bowling is concerned."

Although only 22, Flintoff has an unenviable fitness record. A back problem has never been fully resolved and, ironically, he has been nursed along gently as a bowler on this tour. Only recently has he been allowed to contribute a full day's work with the ball.

He is a huge lad - some 17st - who generates pace with a vigorous body and arm action, slamming his front foot down hard in delivery. Clearly, even for someone of his strength, the force is too much.

The news of Flintoff's injury was the cherry on the cake, for things did not go England's way yesterday. Bowled out in the morning for 258, they needed wickets early on, took but one, and struggled in the sun thereafter as Gary Kirsten and Jacques Kallis began the process of batting England out of the game and the series.

There was no luck going for England but a team that is down on its uppers, as this side were on the second day, tends not to have any. So twice, brilliant pieces of fielding at point by Michael Vaughan counted for nothing when on each occasion his shy at the stumps missed, letting off first Herschelle Gibbs and then Kirsten on 22. On a good day at least one would have found its target.

In between Kallis, on 11, was dropped by Alec Stewart behind the wicket off Chris Silverwood, the ball jolting from the keeper's right glove as his arm hit the ground following a spectacular dive. Contrast with Vaughan's ill fortune in playing a firm and legitimate shot off his hips straight into the midriff of short leg - who clung on only through reflex - and an lbw decision that went against Phil Tufnell later on when Kirsten had 67, and the picture becomes as clear as was Table Mountain yesterday.

England - sadly, for they have promised much - look like they are waving goodbye to the series.

By the close, Kirsten and Kallis had taken their unbroken second-wicket partnership to 157, taking advantage of bowling which, not surprisingly after Durban, looked jaded - particularly that of Andy Caddick - and indisciplined.

Hittable balls were two-a-penny at times and, in both reaching 80, Kirsten and Kallis struck eight fours apiece with Kallis hooking a six off Silverwood for good measure.

At 200 for one, South Africa need just 59 more to pass England, whose last hope of winning rests with the new ball, due in 13 overs, and more incisive bowling.

A crass piece of cricket so often precipitates England's worst collapses and the folly of Stewart's suicidal dismissal as Sunday's play drew to a close was evidenced by the way England folded yesterday. Had they begun the day with three wickets down rather than five, there might have been a different complexion on things.

Instead England were never in command. Vaughan, the key player left, became Allan Donald's fifth wicket (when he snared Stewart for his fourth, he overtook Sydney Barnes as the leading wicket taker, with 84, in Tests between the two countries). Adams swashed at the day's first ball and missed but repeated the stroke an hour later and was caught at the wicket. Flintoff, with the tail, slogged and three balls later Gough edged giving Lance Klusener, bowling his only over of the day, his first wickets in 106 overs of trying. Tufnell, as is his wont, surrendered.

 Pakistan have appealed against the International Cricket Council's decision to ban the pace bowler Shoaib Akhtar for an illegal action. The decision ruled Shoaib out of the one-day series involving Pakistan, Australia and India, starting on Sunday. The ICC plans to review its decision in a month.

webTitle: Hunters threaten Jospin with new battle of the Somme

fields.headline: Hunters threaten Jospin with new battle of the Somme
fields.trailText: They have been shooting ducks on the salt marshes of the bay of the Somme more or less since guns were invented, and they did not stop even when the Nazis threatened to execute anyone found with a gun.
fields.body:
They have been shooting ducks on the salt marshes of the bay of the Somme more or less since guns were invented, and they did not stop even when the Nazis threatened to execute anyone found with a gun.

`We didn't surrender our rifles to the Germans, so anyone who thinks a couple of anti-hunting directives from the European Union and an environment-friendly Socialist government are going to stop us has got it wrong,' said Jean Pilniak of the regional hunters' federation.

A countryside crisis over bloodsports has already spawned a new political movement by France's 1.5m hunters - Chasse, Peche, Nature et Tradition, or CPNT - which collected an astonishing 7% of the national vote in the European elections last June. That was slightly more than the Communists, who are a part of the governing coalition.

In Mr Pilniak's department of the Somme, CPNT emerged as the biggest party, winning 27% of the vote against the ruling Socialist party's 16%. Six of its MEPs sit in the European parliament, where they have formed a highly vocal parliamentary group with half a dozen like-minded Danes and Dutchmen and three members of the Eurosceptic UK Independence Party.

`If [prime minister Lionel] Jospin riles us, our vote is now big enough to lose him 64 seats at the next election,' said Yves Butel, one of its MEPs.

For 20 years, successive French governments have successfully staved off EU directives that would significantly curb hunting. But two things are likely to force the prime minister's hand. A new report from a Socialist MP, François Patriat, suggests - besides improved safety regulations for a notoriously dangerous sport that kills 40 people a year - that the government really has no option but to shorten the hunting season.

And the council of state, which weighs the legality of all government decisions, has declared finally and conclusively that France is breaking EU rules. The start of the July 14-February 28 season, it said in a potentially explosive verdict, will have to be delayed by six weeks, and the end brought forward by a month.

Caught between the votes of the hunters and an anti-hunting lobby that includes his coalition partners, the Greens, Mr Jospin will have to tread very carefully indeed in the new hunting legislation he has promised to introduce before next summer.

A more immediate danger is that ecologists and anti-bloodsports campaigners have promised to use the council of state ruling to launch legal proceedings against any local authority that allows hunters to continue shooting after January 31.

fields.headline: Kohl's successor drawn into scandal
fields.trailText: The scandal unleashed by Germany's former chancellor Helmut Kohl yesterday began heading towards the man who took over from him as head of the Christian Democrats.
fields.body:
The scandal unleashed by Germany's former chancellor Helmut Kohl yesterday began heading towards the man who took over from him as head of the Christian Democrats.

As Mr Kohl braced himself for the start today of a criminal investigation into his activities as party leader, Wolfgang Schäuble, who succeeded him as party chairman last year, was last night under growing pressure from political friends and foes alike to explain a mysterious - and apparently illicit - movement of funds. The transfer was spotted in figures the Christian Democrats were forced to make public because of the Kohl affair.

The accounts, released last Friday, revealed that in January 1997 more than 1m marks (£350,000) was sent by the parliamentary party to party headquarters in apparent contravention of Germany's law on political financing. Mr Schäuble was leader of the parliamentary party at the time.

A senior Christian Democrat, Hans Georg Wagner, told the Welt am Sonntag newspaper: "Schäuble must have known about it. He has a duty to tell us exactly where the money came from and exactly what it was used for."

There is no evidence that the money came from tainted sources and Christian Democrats yesterday insisted that it was handed over in compliance with the law.

The legal adviser to the Christian Democrat Union (CDU), Andreas Schmidt, said the cash had been built up out of the monthly 50 mark fees that members of parliament paid to the parliamentary party. He added that the account in which the money was held had to be closed because of a change in the law and that the subsequent transfer was perfectly legal.

However, as the Christian Democrats' opponents pointed out, the amount involved was surprisingly large. The parliamentary leader of the Greens, Rezzo Schlauch, expressed disbelief that so much could have been raised with membership subscription. "It smells like something illegal," he said.

Prosecutors in Bonn are today due to begin their investigation of Mr Kohl. Germany's longest-serving chancellor of the 20th century has admitted he ran secret accounts for party donations which, in apparent violation of the law, were never disclosed. Mr Kohl risks being charged with an offence that carries penalties of up to five years in jail.

Another Greens MP, Volker Beck, said: "If it turns out that, in violation of campaign finance laws, money from the CDU parliamentary group went to the CDU headquarters, then we will have to open up a Schäuble file as well."

An all-party parliamentary commission of inquiry will begin in February to look at claims that some donations to the Christian Democrats during the Kohl era were bribes or rewards. Questions have been raised about payments by property developers and an arms dealer, all of whom benefited from government decisions.

Mr Schäuble, who was a loyal Kohl lieutenant, is regarded as a man of personal integrity and has emphasised that his predecessor, who was chairman for 25 years, ran the party in a distinctly paternalistic manner.

The only doubts expressed about Mr Schäuble before now have been whether he had, as he claimed, been unaware of the secret accounts until reading of them in the newspapers.

webTitle: The difference between men and women

fields.headline: The difference between men and women
fields.trailText:
1. He will completely screw your head up every second that YOU are with 
him
fields.body:
1. He will completely screw your head up every second that YOU are with him

2. You ARE a mind reader... never forget it, and never tell him any different

3. No man is SPECIAL, they all turn out the same in the end

4. You can NEVER ask him for any more commitment than he's already giving you

5. A man will always FORGET your birthday, and any other special occasion

6. He will always want to do IT, even after you've just had a blazing row with your best mate

fields.headline: Sara Denver, nurse turned solicitor
fields.trailText: At the age of 18, Sara Denver set her heart on becoming a nurse and embarked on almost four years of training - first a degree, then a course to specialise in cardiothoracic intensive care. 'I loved my job, I was doing something practical and I enjoyed working with people.' After spending such a long time training, it never occurred to her that she would want to change, particularly to a career which would involve an even longer period of study. But a chance conversation with a disaffected doctor who had decided to jettison medicine in favour of law had a profound effect on her.
fields.body:
At the age of 18, Sara Denver set her heart on becoming a nurse and embarked on almost four years of training - first a degree, then a course to specialise in cardiothoracic intensive care. 'I loved my job, I was doing something practical and I enjoyed working with people.' After spending such a long time training, it never occurred to her that she would want to change, particularly to a career which would involve an even longer period of study. But a chance conversation with a disaffected doctor who had decided to jettison medicine in favour of law had a profound effect on her.

She began to find out as much as she could about training and what a job as a solicitor would entail. 'I wanted to find out as much as I could, as once you've left a career it's quite hard to go back to it.'

Research completed, she decided that law would suit her perfectly. And she hoped that when she qualified she would be able to use some of her skills gained in the NHS to specialise in medical negligence cases. Another protracted training stint followed - this time for five years - with a one-year law conversion course then two years of legal practice and finally a two-year training contract with a firm of solicitors.

'I qualified in September and it feels great. I loved the challenge of studying for something new; law was something I really wanted to do for myself but at the same time I think I've chosen something useful.'

While she doesn't know of many lawyers who have changed career direction, Denver, 32, can think of many colleagues from medicine who are now doing different jobs.

She says an increasing number of medical negligence cases are being taken out, which means an abundant supply of work is likely. 'I don't know whether the incidences of negligence are increasing or whether people are becoming more aware of legal action as an option.'

She is certain there won't be any more lightning career changes. 'This is it now. I'm so much happier in this career; I feel I can really make a difference to people. I would recommend changing direction to anyone. Explore the options thoroughly, but don't be afraid of change.'

webTitle: Diana's landmine crusade put Tories in a panic

fields.headline: Diana's landmine crusade put Tories in a panic
fields.standfirst:
US diplomatic cables describe controversy over Angola visit
Read the US embassy documents
fields.trailText: A graphic account of how John Major's government was gripped by panic over Princess Diana's uncompromising stance on a worldwide ban on landmines is revealed in previously secret diplomatic cables.
fields.body:
A graphic account of how John Major's government was gripped by panic over Princess Diana's uncompromising stance on a worldwide ban on landmines is revealed in previously secret diplomatic cables.

They were sent by American ambassadors to the US secretary of state, Madeline Albright, during the princess's visit to Angola. They reveal that the Americans believed Diana had 'bested' John Major and the foreign secretary, Malcolm Rifkind, after a junior defence minister, Earl Howe, had accused her of being a 'loose cannon'.

They also contain a revealing insight into how she refused to 'wine and dine' the social elite and snubbed the daughter of an African king in favour of meeting the Angolan people. Such attitudes caused considerable embarrassment for the British ambassador in Angola, Roger Hart, who had to sneak in VIP guests to eat char sui and bean sprouts with the princess.

The trip, in January 1997, caused huge controversy in the press when she appeared to endorse Labour's policy of a worldwide ban on landmines. The US cables show that the Americans - who later cooled on the idea of a ban - could scarcely conceal their delight at her strong stance and even told the British ambassador in Angola what a great success her visit had been.

Blow-by-blow accounts of the princess's controversial visit were sent to Ms Albright from Admiral William Crowe, then US ambassador to Britain, and Donald Steinberg, then US ambassador to Angola. The cables released to the Guardian under the US freedom of information act would be banned from publication in Britain until 2072 because of their mention of the royal family. Admiral Crowe's cable - written in the same colourful language as his outspoken comments about the royals and William Hague after Diana's death - is headed 'Princess Di trips political landmine'. 'Controversy and/or room for misunderstanding was inherent in the princess's trip' because the British Red Cross wanted an immediate worldwide ban on anti-personnel mines, while the government's position was that Britain would not support a ban until all countries had signed a deal. Once the princess had made her statement supporting a worldwide ban, she was attacked by Earl Howe for being 'ill-informed on the issue of anti-personnel mines' and a 'loose cannon' ' that Her Majesty's government did not need'.

Admiral Crowe says: 'Government officials immediately scrambled to repair the public relations damage and issued statements affirming the government's commitment to 'working toward a worldwide ban on landmines'.' A Downing Street spokesman was quoted as claiming there had been a 'misunderstanding' and that the princess's remarks were not 'inconsistent with government policy'. He adds: 'Labour party officials used the flap to highlight differences between Labour and the Conservative government on the landmine issue.'

Mr Steinberg tells Ms Albright from Luanda that by the time the three-day trip had finished the princess had 'bested a political furore in London', adding that Mr Major and Mr Rifkind had 'stepped in to cool things off'. He also reports approvingly of how she shunned celebrity status. 'She wanted a serious visit, not to be seen wining and dining with the social elite. The daughter of the king of the Lundas wanted to meet with her British counterpart, but failed. The princess accepted a dinner invitation hosted by first lady Ana Paula Dos Santos (the Angolan president's wife) on condition that it be small (26 guests ate from a catered Chinese food buffet) short (it ended at 8.10pm) and there be no press or speeches. Hart (the British ambassador) managed to get the local directors of Shell, BP and De Beers invited. 'Hart himself held only a dinner for her and Red Cross officials.'

The reports also discloses that Mr Major's government had the added problem that Diana had been fully briefed of the British position by the foreign office and the visit had been personally approved by the Queen. 'For her part, the princess was looking for a new public cause to promote that would not conflict with the interests of other members of the royal family.'

The US ambassador's report adds that originally the Red Cross wanted to send her to Vietnam or Cambodia but this was ruled out by the foreign office as too dangerous. Mr Steinberg concludes: 'She was excited about the results and talking about more visits to Vietnam, Cambodia, Kuwait and return engagement in Angola. No one can come to Angola and see the human devastation caused by landmines and not be moved. We have told the British ambassador how seriously the United States' government takes this problem and how much we appreciate Diana's support.'

fields.headline: Yeltsin's resignation caught opposition flat-footed
fields.trailText: Russia's centre-left opposition has been plunged into disarray by Boris Yeltsin's snap resignation designed to boost the presidential prospects of his protege, Vladimir Putin. Reeling from the New Year's Eve coup, the opposition appears at a loss about how to mount a credible challenge to the acting president and prime minister.
fields.body:
Russia's centre-left opposition has been plunged into disarray by Boris Yeltsin's snap resignation designed to boost the presidential prospects of his protege, Vladimir Putin. Reeling from the New Year's Eve coup, the opposition appears at a loss about how to mount a credible challenge to the acting president and prime minister.

The presidential election is expected on March 26 - three months earlier than scheduled. And the campaign effectively kicked off on New Year's Day, with Mr Putin shown live on state television during a morale-boosting visit to Russian troops in Chechnya. 'Russia thanks you,' he told Russian officers and soldiers.

Already the darling of the military because of his hard line on Chechnya, Mr Putin burnished his army credentials further by telling the top brass and the country that the military and not the politicians would decide on the pace and conduct of the war.

However, Mr Putin faces three declared candidates in the race for the Kremlin: Yevgeny Primakov, the former prime minister and foreign minister, Grigory Yavlinsky, the liberals' leader, and Vladimir Zhirinovsky, the extreme nationalist. It is also assumed that Gennady Zyuganov, the Communist party's leader who lost to Mr Yeltsin in 1996, will also stand.

The first three all declared their candidatures just before the elections to the duma two weeks ago in an attempt to enhance their vote. But only the Communist vote stood up, although they are 35 seats worse off in the new parlia ment, which is dominated by centrists and promises far greater support for Mr Putin than Mr Yeltsin ever enjoyed.

Can Mr Putin be stopped?

Mr Yavlinsky's candidacy can be effectively discounted, and Mr Putin's main opposition will come from the centre-left, the Communists and the Fatherland-All Russia movement (OVR) of Mr Primakov and the Moscow mayor, Yuri Luzhkov.

The former Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, responded to the Yeltsin resignation by urging the centre-left to unite behind a single candidate, Mr Primakov, to maximise the vote against Mr Putin.

The Communists are the best organised and most disciplined party machine in Russia and could probably guarantee Mr Primakov a quarter of the electorate. But that would entail Mr Zyuganov eating humble pie and standing aside.

But despite Mr Primakov's declared candidacy two weeks ago, it is no longer clear if he will run. Mr Luzhkov declined to endorse Mr Primakov last Friday, saying there would need to be 'consultations'.

Moreover, the number three in the OVR, Vladimir Yakovlev, the mayor of Russia's second city, St Petersburg, faces re-election in May and is already flirting with the Putin camp.

Gennady Seleznev, the Communist speaker of the outgoing duma says frankly that Mr Putin looks unbeatable. The interim president has returned the compliment by voicing support for the Communist in his bid to be governor of the greater Moscow region.

In short, while the opposition fractures in the face of the Putin phenomenon, the acting president and prime minister is busy building a broader support base - ambitious politicians of all stripes are suddenly eager to bask in his glory.

State television propaganda has been hugely instrumental in building up Mr Putin and in securing the strong showing of his allies in the duma election. The next three months will see a continuation of that campaign. And if Mr Primakov, 70, confirms his candidacy, he will be painted as an elderly, unreconstructed communist by state television.

At the moment, the question is not whether Mr Putin can be beaten, but whether the opposition can force him into a second round by denying him an outright victory on March 26.

fields.headline: Russian roulette
fields.standfirst: An election with too obvious a winner
fields.trailText: Mr Putin's breathtaking ascent from obscurity to the role of president presumptive, as from the end of March, may not be exclusively due to the war in Chechnya, but that has clearly been its most powerful ingredient. Indeed, promoting Mr Putin, may be what this second Chechen war is all about.
fields.body:
On New Year's day Vladimir Putin scrapped his plans to celebrate the millennium in Moscow and set off instead for Chechnya to congratulate the troops on the splendid job they were doing. In military terms that might suggest he is easily satisfied, for the quick resolution of the war expected last month shows little sign of arriving; the rebels are far from quelled, Grozny is, as we write, yet to be taken and more bloody conflict, in line with this weekend's escalation, is likely before Russia gets its way. But undoubtedly in terms of Mr Putin's own advancement, the armed forces have done a good job indeed. His breathtaking ascent from obscurity to the role of acting president - and more than that, president presumptive, as from the end of March - may not be exclusively due to the war in Chechnya, but that has clearly been its most powerful ingredient. Indeed, promoting Mr Putin, may be what this second Chechen war is all about.

That is not just because getting tough with the Chechens has played so well with Russian public opinion: it is also because Mr Putin looks clear-headed, decisive, indeed ruthless, when the leadership of the country in the closing years of President Yeltsin has looked utterly the reverse. He is riding so high in the polls because he promises order to a disordered country. He promises the smack of firm government, delivered if need be with a mailed fist. Once that was Boris Yeltsin's appeal, when with the kind of courage which borders on foolhardiness, he climbed on the tank in 1991 to rout the projected putsch against Gorbachev; and again as he successfully engineered the end of Communist rule. For their own political reasons - largely the fear of something still worse - western leaders have been doing their best in the late 90s to pretend that Yeltsin was still the deci sive leader of earlier days, when in fact he had been reduced, by ill-health compounded by drink, to a capricious, confused and sometimes literally tottering figure. So the economy foundered and the standards of daily life grew worse rather than better, and people increasingly yearned for the stability of communist times: a development to which the west has contributed by insisting on economic solutions which put ideology first and left the easing of change, which is part of all practical politics, limping woefully behind. Crime and corruption flourished. If this was the `genius' which some on the right in Britain continue to see in Yeltsin, it was genius of a fitful and sozzled kind.

And yet the end game, whoever devised it, has indeed had a touch of genius about it. The singling out of Vladimir Putin. The confection of a political party which has no greater remit than to support what he says and does. Elections for the duma which though democratic in name were profoundly undemocratic in practice, with a television coverage that was more party political broadcast on behalf of Unity than open democratic debate. And now the near-perfect scenario for elections in March rather than June, with no time for his country's uncharacteristic new year optimism to shrivel. And for Boris Yeltsin himself, a permanent exoneration for whatever he may have done; immunity from prosecution and an absolute guarantee of no questions asked, which given the suspicions hanging over him, he urgently needed; a fat pension and other perks to ensure a life of safety and comfort for the rest of his days. Most western tributes to him as he departs have so far been sensibly muted. Whatever Mr Putin may now produce, it was more than time for Russia to come under new management.
