Elections for the duma which though democratic in name were profoundly undemocratic in practice, with a television coverage that was more party political broadcast on behalf of Unity than open democratic debate. And now the near-perfect scenario for elections in March rather than June, with no time for his country's uncharacteristic new year optimism to shrivel. And for Boris Yeltsin himself, a permanent exoneration for whatever he may have done; immunity from prosecution and an absolute guarantee of no questions asked, which given the suspicions hanging over him, he urgently needed; a fat pension and other perks to ensure a life of safety and comfort for the rest of his days. Most western tributes to him as he departs have so far been sensibly muted. Whatever Mr Putin may now produce, it was more than time for Russia to come under new management.

fields.headline: Recovering a title
fields.standfirst: Can Esquire ever recapture its Golden Age?
fields.trailText: At the end of the film When We Were Kings, Norman Mailer recalls that his last meeting with Muhammad Ali was at an Esquire party in New York. As we left the cinema my friend Al recalled the line and said: 'What would you say these days? The last time I saw Jamie Theakston, he was at an Esquire party... '
fields.body:
At the end of the film When We Were Kings, Norman Mailer recalls that his last meeting with Muhammad Ali was at an Esquire party in New York. As we left the cinema my friend Al recalled the line and said: 'What would you say these days? The last time I saw Jamie Theakston, he was at an Esquire party... '

And that is why the job of Esquire editor must be fraught with gloom. Every time you step into your office you are made aware of the huge weight of publishing history resting on your shoulders. The ghost of 1960s US Esquire must sit in the corner, sniffing haughtily as you bung yet another Caprice shoot on the cover and in your heart you must know it will shake its head at almost everything you do. Because, quite simply, 1960s US Esquire was the greatest magazine in the world. Now, Peter Howarth the present editor, says he wants to rediscover that magic.

He has a lot to live up to. Which other magazine could claim to have created a new form of journalism and discovered Tom Wolfe and Norman Mailer? Which other magazine could boast writers such as Truman Capote, Vladimir Nabokov, Allen Ginsberg and Edward Albee, and yet be confident enough to attack Capote on its own front page? Esquire was the first mainstream US magazine to take an anti-Vietnam war stance. It campaigned for Muhammad Ali's right to fight. It supported actors such as Jack Nicholson and Dustin Hoffman. It was vilified by Nixon and praised by Warhol and managed to disregard them both.

In large part, its place in history was guaranteed by its covers. In 1962, editor Harold Hayes abandoned the idea of using the in-house art department to create his cover and turned to a Madison Avenue advertising executive called George Lois. Lois wanted to create powerful images that sold the magazine without reference to the tedious list of features - 'burn off your belly!', '1,000 ways to be wicked!', 'this year's Bond girl - as you've never seen her before!' - that dominate men's magazine covers these days.

It was Lois who persuaded Ali to pose like St Sebastian and who dared to put out an all-black cover with the phrase 'Oh my God - we hit a little girl' on the issue that carried the true story of M Company in Vietnam. It was also Lois who was mainly responsible for the way Esquire's UK editor Peter Howarth felt three months ago when looking at yet another bikini blonde on his cover.

'I was ashamed,' he says. 'My wife looked at the cover I'd brought home and I felt embarrassed. Around the same time, a friend of mine who runs a bar round the corner told me that he can't leave copies of Esquire out when his friends come round because of the cover. In that issue we had a feature from the only journalist to train with the All Blacks and I was sitting at Twickenham with our deputy managing director and wondered how many people here would have known we had that kind of feature. I figured probably none of them.'

Howarth was so ashamed that he did something about it. He decided to redesign his magazine, abandoning his 'girl in pants' cover policy completely and replacing it with a head and shoulders shot of the month's cover star. He decided to put his cover lines on a removable strip which can be thrown away once the magazine has been bought, leaving a pure image of the woman or - much more significantly - the man that Esquire has chosen this month. Because Howarth has also decided to abandon the recently accepted market wisdom that it's only chicks on the cover who sell, and that's why this month's Esquire cover star - on sale next week - is Johnny Depp.

'We have this heritage that we publish good writing and great art and that had been lost,' he explains. 'I mean, it's all very well publishing John Updike in the 60s, but we've got some great writers now. We publish people like Martin Amis but we also use the Alex Ferguson principle of playing Eric Cantona alongside Ryan Giggs. That's why we also use new names such as Giles Foden and Matt Seaton, or James Parker or a TV documentary maker called Eamonn O'Neil who does all our investigative stuff.

'People like that are exciting. They are the new Tom Wolfes. British Esquire should be about finding the new New Journalism. It's just that our covers didn't suggest that you were holding that sort of magazine in your hands. If we were the only men's magazine in the market, like Arena was in 1985, you could put whatever you wanted on the cover. But we're not. The ones that sell the most are the ones with the most childish content and the most girls with the least clothes. Our covers suggested we were like them and put off the sort of reader we wanted to attract.'

And yet, surely something that is accepted market wisdom is usually accepted for a reason. Loaded recently put Dennis Hopper on the cover and saw its circulation instantly dip by about 50,000. The IPC board panicked and a missive shot down to Loaded's offices asking them to redress the situation sharpish. Isn't Howarth's plucky stance merely the doomed effort of a worthy editor to buck the inevitable? Won't he be on the phone to Caprice's agent by April?

'The board has given me a year,' he says. 'Well, they've given me forever, but I have said to them that you can't judge this in any less time than a year and they backed me, which was very brave of them. The intention is not to lose circulation, and I think that's achievable.

'I should say that this doesn't mean we're abandoning having women in the magazine. This is not a moral crusade. Even Harold Hayes had shoots with Raquel Welch and Angie Dickinson alongside pieces by Wolfe and Mailer. If we were to go down [in circulation], however, then it becomes interesting. Our advertisers are the kind of people who buy predominately on environment. Prada doesn't buy numbers or it would be advertising in FHM. But it isn't.

'The question is, when do the numbers stop making sense? Given the momentum of the title over the last eight months, I'm convinced our readers will stay with us and we can keep selling over 100,000.'

He's already dipped his toe into the water with the international edition of the magazine's last issue. In the UK the cover star was model Kate Groombridge, who sat naked against a white background. Overseas the cover star was Damon Albarn, that issue's big interview. Already, the overseas change has produced results. Both Prada and Hugo Boss, Howarth says, have welcomed the move and hope Esquire will move even further towards its 60s character. The big question, of course, is how the UK reader will react. Do any liberal British men reading this feel prompted to go out and buy Esquire? Over to you.

fields.headline: Sold out
fields.standfirst: As apologies go, this one takes some beating - a 32,000-word indictment of the editor, publisher and chief executive of one of America's most powerful papers. And on its own front page. So what the hell went wrong at the Los Angeles Times? Edward Helmore reports
fields.trailText: It surely stands as one of the most damning mea culpas ever issued by a newspaper, let alone America's fourth largest. But the Los Angeles Times has just printed a 14-page, 32,000-word indictment of its own operating practices.
fields.body:
It surely stands as one of the most damning mea culpas ever issued by a newspaper, let alone America's fourth largest. But the Los Angeles Times has just printed a 14-page, 32,000-word indictment of its own operating practices.

Written by a Pulitzer prize-winning staffer, David Shaw, the front page report not only attacked a profit sharing deal between the paper's Sunday magazine and a new, multi-million dollar sports centre - itself the subject of a bumper edition published last October - as 'a tangled tale of ignorance and arrogance', but also cast a harsh light on the paper's editor Michael Parks, its publisher Kathryn Downing, and chief executive Mark Willes.

It was not the kind of confession you would expect from a British newspaper but then here there has yet to be such a high-velocity, head-on collision between the business of newspapers and the objective, independent principles of journalism. The report, which was not seen by the editor or publisher prior to publication, was designed to re-establish the paper's 'bond of trust' with its readership - a bond its reporters felt had been badly sullied.

As a result of the deal with the Staples Centre, and the ensuing controversy, Shaw wrote: 'The Times' credibility and integrity - ultimately the only commodities a newspaper has to offer - have been severely compromised at a time when public confidence in the press is already in deep decline.'

On October 10, the LA Times published an unusually large, 164-page magazine supplement entirely devoted to the Staples sports arena in downtown Los Angeles without revealing to its readership, or its own reporters, that the $2m the issue raised in advertising revenue would be split between the paper and its subject.

Nor was it revealed that the ads were sold with the assistance of the Staples ad staff or that the Times is a corporate sponsor of the arena and had committed to pay $1.6m in cash and free advertising for five years in exchange for 'joint revenue opportunities' - such as a special magazine issue - and a permanent corporate box.

What may have seemed like a bright, profit-boosting idea to the paper's new publisher, Kathryn Downing, soon dimmed when word of the scheme leaked out to the city's alternative weekly, the New Times. Amid intense internal protest, the publisher and editors maintained the arrangement had not influenced their coverage but the issue soon came to be seen as the ugly tip of an ethical iceberg that threatened to undermine the paper's integrity and reputation.

The paper's 300 reporters signed a petition demanding that Downing - who had no experience in newspapers and had only been in the job six months - apologise and undertake a thorough review that would unearth any other dubious financial relationships. Unfortunately for Downing, it did.

The Staples issue 'creates an impression that maybe the editorial independence of the newsroom is up for grabs and maybe that independence has to be proven now,' says Tom Rosenstiel, director of the Project for Excellence in Journalism in Washington DC. 'Even if it's not true, readers might wonder: 'Did they kill critical stories?' or 'Maybe they didn't assign tough ones'.'

The furore grew with a contribution from former LA Times publisher, Otis Chandler, scion of the family that has had a controlling stake in the newspaper since 1882. Chandler called the management's behaviour 'unbelievably stupid and unprofessional' and said the episode was the 'most serious single threat to the future survival and growth of the paper'. Downing retorted that Chandler was 'angry and bitter'.

Ultimately, Downing did apologise but was hardly able to instill much confidence when she revealed that the profit-sharing arrangement and her failure to reveal it came from her 'fundamental misunderstanding' of a publisher's role and ignorance of newspaper ethics. Nor did the paper's editor look much better - he said he knew of the deal after the magazine was completed but before it was distributed and yet failed to stop delivery or notify readers. 'Clearly, I underestimated the impact of the Staples arrangement on our credibility, on the journalistic ethos that we foster, on our standing in the community and in the profession,' Parks told Shaw. 'And for all those things I have profound regret.'

Although the investigation did not find a smoking gun, it did identify an incremental evolution of mistakes that led to the fiasco. The first inkling of the future disaster came in 1995 when the paper's parent, Times Mirror, hired Mark Willes - a former General Mills executive who had earned the title Cap'n Crunch for his vigorous cost-cutting methods at the food giant - to re-invent the business of running a newspaper. Under his predecessor, Chandler (a champion surfer, a former shot-putter who came within inches of the world record, a racing-car driver and big-game hunter), the paper had gained in stature but remained junior to the big three, the New York Times, the Washington Post and the Wall Street Journal, in terms of reach and importance.

During Chandler's 30-year tenure, he behaved like a proprietor of the old school. He lavished money on the paper - it stationed 14 correspondents and photographers in the Soviet Union during the collapse of communism - and built up a considerable circulation, peaking at 1.2m in 1990.

But in the Californian recession of the early nineties, the LA Times began haemorrhaging money and its board members and stockholders (largely made up of Chandlers) became increasingly unhappy with the cost of fulfilling Otis's dream to knock the New York Times 'off its perch'. Enter Willes as publisher and chief executive, a man with the stated intention to 'blow up' - with a 'bazooka' if necessary - the wall that separates the newsroom from the business side of the paper.

Instrumental to his plan to boost circulation and profits and drive up the stock price, was the aim that the business concerns of the paper would now be a regular part of newsroom decisions, editors would be required to work closely with advertising staff identifying stories that would appeal to advertisers, and different sections of the paper would operate as separate business units.

Despite widespread warnings at the time that applying his consumer product savvy to a newspaper could upset the fine balance between editorial and advertising, Willes advanced his plan. The book review section, for instance, would now give special consideration to books published by houses with large advertising budgets.

Willes and his team had many other ideas, many of which are only now surfacing: the paper received a sales commission for books sold by Barnes & Noble if the reader of a Times online book review clicked over to the retailer. Man agement had proposed publication of a special section on a local car racetrack for which the track would receive a commission for ads it sold in the paper. Shaw's report also noted that the paper devoted heavy coverage to conferences and other events it sponsored and that the news staff had helped organise.

Although none of these examples is spectacularly heinous, and similar changes have been instituted at other newspapers as they try to find new revenue and staunch declining circulations, the irony of the Times affair is that it seems to have been caused by too little communication between business and editorial, not too much.

Nor have Willes' reforms necessarily worked. Though Times Mirror's stock price has tripled since 1995 after he cut costs and sold assets, circulation of the LA Times remains flat at 1m and he has yet to find a radical cure for what ails the business. 'Newspapers that don't take appropriate risks to meet the challenge of a rapidly changing media environment are doomed to die,' he says.

In the end, the profit-sharing agreement obliged the Times to pay Staples Center about $300,000; a relatively small amount of money for a paper that enjoys almost $1bn a year in advertising revenue. But the damage to its reputation, particularly in a country where the press sees itself as having explicit constitutional significance and full disclosure, has been marked. 'The wall [between the newsroom and business] used to represent a clear protection of editorial integrity and independence from the influence of advertisers,' Downing said in a statement, before acknowledging that the cultural change at the paper did not include putting into place 'protocols to replace what we took away'.

In clarification of its journalistic principles, and the rules of engagement between the editorial and business sides, the paper published a manifesto of intent, including one commitment reading: 'advertising may not be co-ordinated with or sold against specific stories or graphics in a way that raises questions of credibility of integrity'. Another said that if 'the editorial mission and the commercial interests of the Times conflict, editorial integrity will always come first'. While the new guidelines offer some solace and all those in positions of power at the paper now appear to agree the whole affair was a colossal blunder, Shaw concluded his exhaustive inquiry expressing scepticism at Downing's assertion that the Times would emerge better after the Staples debacle.

'Is she right?' David Shaw asked. 'Or will the guidelines be followed diligently only until profit margins fall again and pressure for new revenue intensifies?'

fields.headline: The latest Tory defector
fields.standfirst: When the Conservatives announced that a certain Irwin Stelzer would be their economic adviser, the spin was that William Hague was making up with Rupert Murdoch. A day later Stelzer resigned. Matt Wells unravels another Tory PR disaster
fields.trailText: The Tories have been having such rotten luck recently that you almost feel sorry for them. For months now, their media managers have had about as much trouble generating a positive headline as Neil Hamilton's barrister had getting a word in edgeways with Mohamed Al Fayed.
fields.body:
The Tories have been having such rotten luck recently that you almost feel sorry for them. For months now, their media managers have had about as much trouble generating a positive headline as Neil Hamilton's barrister had getting a word in edgeways with Mohamed Al Fayed.

Some elements of the recent run of desperately unhelpful headlines - such as those spawned by the disaster-courting dishonourable former member for Tatton - were the result of a bumper harvest of bad apples, and can hardly be blamed on the luckless party leadership. But in so many day-to-day issues of general political policy, the Tories are constantly coming nowhere in the race for a positive spin on the front pages - even in those papers on whose support it could traditionally count.

So when they managed to secure the (unpaid) services of 15 eminent economists to serve on an advisory panel for the beleaguered Tory high command, it was rightly seen as something of a coup. But inept handling of the announcement by a junior party official turned what should have been a minor victory into a major defeat, precipitating the resignation of a prominent member of the committee on the day his appointment was announced. It was yet another Tory fiasco.

The 15 names on the Conservative press release were, to most journalists, impressive-sounding but unknown. One name, however, stood out - that of the US economist, Irwin Stelzer. Any mention of Stelzer's name in a British political context always pricks the attention of Westminster-watchers, for Stelzer is not simply the director of a prominent Washington free market-oriented think tank, but one of the few close confidants of a certain Rupert Murdoch.

Stelzer, who has known and advised Murdoch for over 20 years, writes columns in the Murdoch-owned New York Post and Sunday Times and is a super-lobbyist on behalf of the media magnet. Almost anywhere around the world where a big Murdoch deal is being pulled off Stelzer's name will not be far from the action. He has been called Murdoch's secret agent. It was doubly interesting that Stelzer should be associated now with the Tories. He is an admirer of Gordon Brown, and a frequent visitor to Downing Street. He is also a staunch Thatcherite who has little time for the political and economic fudges that have stalked the Conservatives since her departure. Murdoch's stable of newspapers has broadly abandoned the Tories, having given themselves up to the prevailing new Labour wind. Stelzer was in on the whole process - reportedly party to a secret, and always-denied deal done between Murdoch and Blair in which the Sun's support for new Labour was guaranteed, provided Blair backed off from outright support of the single currency in the short term.

It was a stroke of unseasonal bad luck which made the welcoming of a Murdoch confidant into the bossom of the Conservatives a new year banana skin. The former chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, had chosen the same day to launch a vicious broadside against the current leadership, and much of the Westminster press gallery was in Tory meltdown (again) mode.

But it was the middle of the holiday period and most publications were operating on skeleton rotas - meaning that Stelzer's appointment, although interesting to the hacks, was surely seen as something of a low priority.

But at the Financial Times political desk Cathy Newman's interest was aroused. Perhaps it was her background in media matters - until recently, she was the FT's media correspondent - but whatever the reason, she thought that Stelzer's involvement with the Tories was worthy of note.

She sought further comment from Conservative sources, and was rewarded by an off-the-record quote from an adviser to the shadow chancellor Francis Maude - who had assembled the panel. In a comment which was attributed to an 'aide' in the next day's edition, the Maude team member said: 'We're not claiming that Murdoch is back with us or anything of the kind. But it is encouraging that someone so close to Murdoch is happy to sit on our council.'

As soon as he read the story in Washington, Stelzer was furious. Despite his close association with the News Corp chief, he hates to be portrayed as a Murdoch frontman, and he dashed off an acidic resignation letter to Maude. 'I do hope that the remaining members [of the committee] will help you to improve the forecasting skills that led you to predict a recession immediately before the nation's rate of economic growth soared and unemployment began to fall,' he concluded acidly.

Once again, the Tories were rewarded with a crop of negative headlines. With luckless timing that would have been dismissed as unbelievable had it appeared in a work of political fiction, the Stelzer story broke just as news emerged of further criticism of Hague - this time by his predecessor, John Major.

Stelzer himself could not avoid a smile to himself. Sitting at home in his Washington apartment, he remarked that the Tories seem to be getting desperate in their search for a good story. Reflecting on the tale over the weekend, he suggests that the Conservative party must think long and hard about what it stands for if it is to regain the confidence of the traditionally 'Tory' press. Although Stelzer stresses once again that he can't speak for Murdoch, the News International stable is clearly in this category.

'I assume media people are intelligent, and there's no reason to believe they are of less than average intelligence, it seems to me the way any politician gets support of media people is through attractive, coherent policies,' he says.

As far as Stelzer is concerned, one area where Tory policy is clearly neither attractive nor coherent is European monetary union - a subject close to his heart (he is currently in the process of preparing a Hudson Institute book on European integration). Labour's position of entering economic union when certain criteria are met, Stelzer says, is at least principled - even though he doesn't believe in it. Hague's position is not to enter EMU within a decade. 'It's very hard to ride into battle with the banner 'I want to wait three years longer than Blair wants to wait',' Stelzer says.

In some of Stelzer's frequent conversations with Blair, the prime minister has revealed that he can at least understand those who sustain an implacable opposition to the single currency. Michael Portillo, Stelzer suggests, did at least have a position: 'No, never.' It would be one that Hague would do well at least to consider: 'The more you are against it the closer you are to a principle,' Stelzer says. While Hague flounders, Blair's stance is supported by a coherent principle while delivering 'wiggle room' - that all-important room for manoeuvre that all politicians crave.

webTitle: In with the new, down with the old

fields.headline: In with the new, down with the old
fields.trailText: The prime minister's '21st century message' was not, one deduced, intended to offer any last-minute challenge to those masters of the political platform, Martin Luther King or Winston Churchill. It was intellectually vacuous and rhetorically impoverished; Blair's most effective device was pounding repetition. The adjective 'new' occurred no fewer than 23 times in the Guardian's edited text of the speech. And always as what Orwell calls a 'doubleplusgood' word. 'Old' occurred just once and pejoratively.
fields.body:
The prime minister's '21st century message' was not, one deduced, intended to offer any last-minute challenge to those masters of the political platform, Martin Luther King or Winston Churchill. It was intellectually vacuous and rhetorically impoverished; Blair's most effective device was pounding repetition. The adjective 'new' occurred no fewer than 23 times in the Guardian's edited text of the speech. And always as what Orwell calls a 'doubleplusgood' word. 'Old' occurred just once and pejoratively.

So intoxicated is Blair with the idea of newness that it is sometimes difficult to see where he's going with it. 'The New Deal,' he prophesies, 'is only the first step in a new approach to welfare and work. On its foundation, we must build a new welfare system.'

Is the foundation, then, to be entirely new? No pensions, no benefits, no tax relief? The brain whirls. We are not, however, allowed to linger. There is so much other novelty to admire. There is, for example, a 'new peace in Northern Ireland'. In the regions, 'new dispensations' and 'new partnerships'. In Europe, 'new bonds of connection'.

Here at home, there is oodles of newness as well. Thanks to New Labour, we have 'a new national institute of clinical excellence', '37 new hospitals' and 'thousands of new doctors'. They are raring to go. 'People,' Blair declared, 'want to see the new doctors and nurses on the wards, want the new system to tackle cancer and heart disease up and running.' If, horrible thought, you had cancer or heart disease, would you want a 'new doctor', the ink still wet on his or her diploma? Or would you want a doctor who had 30 years' clinical experience treating your condition?

Clearly 1.1.2000, if ever, is a time to be out with the old and on with the new. Blair's refrain was appropriate and one should not worry about what it means any more than one should worry about what exactly 'auld lang syne' is. (Every January, I resolve to look it up.) Blair's iteration of New Deal, New Labour, New Year, New Millennium, New Systems gets his big idea across. He is dedicated to change and history is on his side.

Nonetheless, most of the citizens of Blair's Britain are not new. Many, in fact, may justly be termed old. And, according to recently published figures, they can confidently expect to get older. Average life expectancies, for both men and women, are moving inexorably towards 80 and beyond. And what with all the new doctors and systems tackling those pesky degenerative diseases, those who have seen it through to the new millennium may expect to live even longer. There is a troubling blind spot in Blair's vision of New Albion. He sees no place for anything 'old' - not even old people. What to do with the superannuated and underpensioned? Park them out of sight, seems to be the PM's solution.

I can only speak for my own profession. I teach in Britain and in America. In Britain, at the age of 65, I must retire. American universities, like other professional institutions, may impose no age-mandatory retirement. It's federal law. You can soldier on until you drop. Many do. On the face of it, the American system looks brutal. But in my experience that is not how it works. University teachers are no more likely to suffer late-life incompetence than barristers such as George Carman who, for all his 70 years, ran rings round the opposition in court a couple of weeks ago. (If you were defending a libel suit, would you rather have Carman or a 'new lawyer'?)

Many American academics land their career-best jobs in their 60s. Old teachers are, of course, expensive. They take up space required for new recruits. And they tend, given their decades of experience, to dominate key committees. But if their (American) institution wants them out, they must make a deal. A golden handshake, in other words. It cushions retirement very nicely.

The abolition of age-mandatory retirement would keep a significant number of high-earners in the tax-paying sector. It would shift the onus of pension top-up from the state to the employer. Most importantly, it would retain a valuable reservoir of expertise. Since no one registers how much of Blair's Third Way is lifted from America, he could even present it as a 'radical new reform'.

fields.headline: Birt's BBC u-turn
fields.standfirst:
In all the new year revelries one thing has been missed - Sir John Birt is baleing out as DG two months early. Janine Gibson reveals why

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: In the early hours of New Year's Eve, as the attention of the world was diverted to the approach of the next millennium, a BBC announcement revealed some truly welcome news. Indeed, at this time of over-excited pronouncements, it could be described as an historic turnaround.
fields.body:
In the early hours of New Year's Eve, as the attention of the world was diverted to the approach of the next millennium, a BBC announcement revealed some truly welcome news. Indeed, at this time of over-excited pronouncements, it could be described as an historic turnaround.

Elevated to the exalted position of baron in the new year's honours list, John Birt is to step down two months before his declared leaving date of the end of March. In just over three weeks, Birtism at the BBC will end when the man who has led it through the dog days of the century leaves to take up his life peerage and join the House of Lords.

As Lord Birt clears his desk and vacates the open-plan office he has shared with his successor Greg Dyke for the last three months, the nods and winks of those close to the DG-in-waiting who have persisted in suggesting that Birt would see in the new year and elegantly depart seem more prescient than hopeless. Through all the speculation, urging and at times ungracious insistance that Birt must go and leave Dyke in peace, the director-general remained at least on the surface resolute.

Sadly we can only guess at the behind the scenes manoeuvring that the neatness of his u-turn implies. What were the terms of the trade-off? Did Dyke make clear the untenable nature of his position? Did Sir John self-sacrificingly lay down his sword and his last 60 days of power for an extra £5 on the licence fee? Did it involve a mandatory appearance at the dome?

In Cambridge, at the Royal Television Society convention, he was adamant he would see out the entire six-month handover period, unconvincingly arguing that Dyke would need all the assistance he could give. Echoing the Queen, by publicly refusing to countenance abdication, though the successor may wish it with all his heart and the public might believe it to be inevitable, Sir John was not for moving. Even when, after the conference, briefings from government suggested a solution involving elevation and grandeur might be acceptable, his position remained firm.

It would have been unseemly, of course, for Lord Birt to rush straight from the editorial impartiality of the BBC into a Labour whip in the Lords. Unseemly and unnecessarily provocative for a Tory party sufficiently beleaguered to make further accusations of bias at the Beeb all too inevitable. He will sit on the cross benches (as revealed by this paper last year) where, we may fondly hope, he will soon be provoked into some stirring attacks on his former policies, much as Duke Hussey so eloquently turned on his former protege in a debate on the future of public service broadcasting last year.

There will be much to concern him. A broadcasting act seems certain to be scheduled early in the next parliament. Birt's understanding of digital television will hopefully help the politicians' loose grasp of the technology. Perhaps during his maiden speech, the remaining slumbering Lords will be treated to a Birt special; complete with overhead projector, bullet points and clips from the costume drama du jour. Followed naturally by a thorough background briefing (or translation) from a team of corporate press officers.

If the new year cannot be guaranteed to bring the BBC a substantial slug of digital licence fee income to the tune of the £700m it has requested, then at least the government can claim to have performed this small miracle, of contriving a happy and graceful solution to the never justifiable two leaders in one office dilemma.

Should the now widely predicted across the board increase in the licence fee replace Gavyn Davies' digital supplement and finally materialise before the end of January, Dyke will be able to take over in February with the minimum of conflict.

It's probably the best solution broadcasting could have hoped from the government. More gratifying than the well-deserved OBE to media hack Ray Snoddy for services to explaining convergence to politicians, more satisfying somehow than ITN chief executive Stewart Purvis's CBE for struggling valiantly against the move of News at Ten and certainly more edifying than the CBE to News Corporation's chief spin doctor, Jane Reed, for services to creating a better image for Rupert Murdoch.

If Lord Birt seems to have shown, in this his last roll of the corporate dice, a rash determination to stay on till the final curtain, his reward should be that he considers himself amply recompensed by the government with a fancy costume and the chance to make a suitably damning condemnation of his enemies. Perhaps it's just because it's the panto season, but the picture of Baron not-so-Hard-Up strutting his ermine-clad stuff in the Lords should gladden even the least forgiving of his detractors' hearts.

fields.headline: The pleasure zone
fields.standfirst: This week, Channel 4 belatedly turns its attention to the great 90s drug: cocaine. Nice idea, says Jenny Fabian, but their lack of insight gets up her nose
fields.trailText: Cocaine, put on earth by God, perverted by nasties, rendered tedious by Channel 4. Construction workers, football hooligans, painters, decorators... the thought of cocaine-crazed white van man will bring shudders to Tunbridge Wells. No mention, however, of Freud's Cocaine Papers, Sherlock Holmes's bottle, or the Empire of the Incas, who looked upon the coca shrub as a living manifestation of divinity.
fields.body:
Cocaine, put on earth by God, perverted by nasties, rendered tedious by Channel 4. Construction workers, football hooligans, painters, decorators... the thought of cocaine-crazed white van man will bring shudders to Tunbridge Wells. No mention, however, of Freud's Cocaine Papers, Sherlock Holmes's bottle, or the Empire of the Incas, who looked upon the coca shrub as a living manifestation of divinity.

Coming down from the transcendental 60s, sweet cousin cocaine whispered to me of dangerous glamour; rock gods had lines laid out on top of their amps and we all knew about Hollywood Babylon. Since then it has gone through the grim process of democratisation and become The People's Drug of the 90s. Housewives in Hampshire can now order what Tallulah Bankhead called the 'absolutely divine' from a man in the market. It's as commonplace as the mobile phones that make dealing it so easy. I suppose it's still fun, but it doesn't look like it from these programmes.

Because no dealer in their right mind would go on screen and admit to possession with intent to supply Class A drugs, most interviews in Secrets And Lines (9pm, Thursday, Channel 4) are recreated by actors. Apparently the spawn of prohibition are doing very nicely, thank you, 'I could never live on the 300 quid you get for a 9-to-5 job, know what I mean?' Especially nauseating is 'high-end dealer' Johnny Mohair, played as a camp coloured man with a blond top knot, who grovels before the status of the people he sells to. 'I have a duty to respect my clients, and in return they respect me.' Who's he kidding? The token female dealer was a dodgy blonde who bore no resemblance to any of the chicks I knew who trekked up mountain pathways to bring back the best Bolivian flake.

My Mate Charlie (9pm, Wednesday, Channel 4) deals with the up-tight white folk for whom a wrap of coke is a couple of phone calls away. Like Sue, looking strangely fit and tanned yet dead within, who blew her inheritance of £322,000 up her nostrils at a rate of 15 grams a day. When she'd licked the wrap and scratched at the floorboard for fallen fragments she would blow her nose and eat the tissue. 'My dealer was my only friend.'

During his Thin White Duke ordeal David Bowie blew his nose and thought his brains had fallen out. He had mind enough left to know it was time to quit the Nietzschean fantasies. At least it had brought us some great music. What can 90s man Matt the Welder, on three grams a day, bring us from his less exotic nasal passages? 'Blobs of blood, and grisly bacon stuff.' His voice utters from a face of uncooked pastry, and he is so dedicated to the White Mischief that he says he won't stop until his nose falls off. A Fantastic Voyage - like journey up the inside of Matt's proboscis brought screams of terror from the younger viewers.

Also in this trio of coke-fest programmes is Cocaine On The Brain (10pm, Wednesday, Channel 4), featuring bog-standard medical experts, and a young group of 'cocaine takers' who are studied during an evening's indulgence. In the late 19th century, Freud was berated for his advocacy of 'the third scourge of humanity', but his data on the effects of cocaine deserve mention as much as any thing because the person he experimented on was himself, and it's hard to improve on such methodology. 'Here we have someone who is high,' says a psychopharmacologist, indicating a woolly-hatted youth. A girl sitting by a fibre-optic light shares her inner secrets: 'You can get into things, I feel so focused... let's have another line.'

fields.headline: Snow's business
fields.standfirst: For those who can't get enough of Jon Snow, Channel 4 is launching a bulletin into that news desert: Sunday. He talks to John Dugdale about ITV and the BBC
fields.trailText: On BBC1's 6 O'Clock News, poor Huw Edwards still looks like someone sentenced to reading an autocue for an unspecified anti-Birtist crime. At 9 O'Clock on the same channel, Michael Buerk and Peter Sissons are said to be sulking, convinced their bulletin has been downgraded ever since the 'Six' was relaunched. On ITV at 6.30, Sir Trevor McDonald has yet to regain the authority which News At Ten gave him. And on Channel 5, a programme built around ITV defector Kirsty Young will now have to be reconstructed.
fields.body:
On BBC1's 6 O'Clock News, poor Huw Edwards still looks like someone sentenced to reading an autocue for an unspecified anti-Birtist crime. At 9 O'Clock on the same channel, Michael Buerk and Peter Sissons are said to be sulking, convinced their bulletin has been downgraded ever since the 'Six' was relaunched. On ITV at 6.30, Sir Trevor McDonald has yet to regain the authority which News At Ten gave him. And on Channel 5, a programme built around ITV defector Kirsty Young will now have to be reconstructed.

Looking across the main terrestrial bulletins, the lone vibrant exception to this pattern of misery and resentment is Channel 4 News, which has already successfully introduced a Saturday edition and next Sunday (albeit in exchange for losing 30 minutes on Fridays) becomes a seven-day operation.

After a year as presenter, reporter, debate referee and celebrity interviewer, anchorman Jon Snow is raring to go. 'I've always had a genuine passion to see a serious Sunday news programme, and I think other channels have missed a trick, that there's a real appetite for something that says, 'the weekend's ending, where are we, what's happened, what's going to happen?' On Saturday, you know, we're getting the best figures of the week, 1.6m heading out to 2m, and my feeling is we could get more. In fact, I'd be disappointed if we don't get 2m.'

Jim Gray, lured away from Newsnight by Michael Jackson to edit and overhaul Channel 4 News, says that he soon found that the Saturday bulletin he introduced last year needed to 'rattle along' more than he expected, but is convinced the 'more reflective, more lateral' approach that he initially planned for Saturday will work on a Sunday. Among its other defining features, he adds, will be 'a strong international perspective, investigative stories given room to breathe, and long interviews at the top of the programme.'

Asked if he still sees himself as the bolshy 'enemy within' at ITN, Snow laughingly replies, 'not with Jim Gray around - I'm no longer alone. I feel very much part of Channel 4. I feel rather less part of ITN, within which Channel 4 News is a very aberrant creature, but it's ITN who pay me and I haven't worked for anyone else, except briefly in radio. So it's an odd situation, a split-personality thing.'

Does the fact that the same organisation is now making bulletins for ITV at 6.30pm and Channel 4 at 7pm cause problems? 'Not really. Because of the way technology has developed, we're able to extract material at the same time. And, anyway, we and ITV are actually rarely scrabbling over the same ground. I don't think, for instance, that we covered the death of Cilla Black's husband in any great depth, but they did it for three minutes.'

This is said with dry humour, but his underlying point is serious. 'I mean, ITV's got out of the business of public service broadcasting. News At Ten was a public service. There's a great swathe of people in British society who don't have the time or inclination to watch news before 10pm, and they're entitled to a channel that provides it. By moving the news, ITV have forfeited all right to be called a public service broadcaster.' What's Snow's assessment of the 6.30 bulletin? 'Well, it's 'right for its market',' he replies, grinning broadly.

The BBC fares no better, with Newsnight's 11pm Scottish opt-out slated as 'a complete disgrace. In fact, the whole way the BBC has responded to Scotland is very mealy-mouthed. If even Westminster can countenance devolving power, the BBC should certainly have a devolved a 'Scottish Six' news bulletin. The fact that they didn't shows really scared thinking.'

Snow has been approached to defect 'from time to time, over the years', but says 'the BBC would have to change profoundly for it to be tempting. It's far better resourced than any of us have ever dreamt of, and it would be wonderful to have all those resources to play with. But on the other hand it would be awful to put up with the stale breath of the bureaucrats who would be peering over your shoulder.

'And they do: whenever you meet your BBC counterparts, there's always something burdened about them, they've always got a shoulder sagging - and on that shoulder is the heavy arm of those endless bureaucrats. Even in Jeremy Paxman's case, there's probably four or five layers of accountants and other sorts of creature above him, whereas there's only one person between me and the boss of Channel 4, and that's Jim Gray.'

Adding to his enthusiasm for the channel is the way it has belatedly begun to exploit his talents by using him for what he calls 'extra-curricular' work, such as last Thursday's On the Line programme which was Snow's own idea. Alongside the day power was devolved to Northern Ireland - beginning at Seamus Heaney's house in Dublin, and ending at Stormont - and forays to Macedonia and Kosovo, one of his personal highlights of the year was travelling to Australia to chair a rumbustious pre-referendum debate on the monarchy.

'Fantastic! I thought I'd died and gone to heaven. If you said to somebody, 'go to a country about which people [here] know nothing and care less, find 80 people nobody here's ever heard of, put them in a studio and make a good programme', they'd think you were mad. But it was wonderful, and it raised issues that are relevant here because in Britain the monarchy is rarely discussed, it's the subject that dares not speak its name.'

His interview with Monica Lewinsky is not among the high points he singles out, and he freely admits it was flawed: 'I asked some very fatuous questions, like 'did [Clinton] make you tingle?', which was probably not a very wise idea, but on the other hand nothing about interviewing Mikhail Gorbachev and Margaret Thatcher prepares you for interviewing a young woman who hasn't been found in bed with the President.'

Did he fail to ask obvious questions because he was too diffident, as some women profile-writers suggested? 'I might be. It's a difficult problem. You never have to interview 24-year-old women in depth, basically. And as the depths had all sorts of Freudian connotations, I felt I was treading on very, very rocky ground and could have got into really serious trouble - so the fact that I emerged only criticised for not asking more specific questions was OK.

'I've often asked myself, 'should I have done a more aggressive, make-the-woman-cry interview?' Barbara Walters did her on the same day and her ambition, which she achieved, was simply to make her cry. But I thought [in my interview] the real Monica came across, perfectly nice and rather naive. And, after all, what's your service to the viewer? It's to share some real insight about who she is. But it would have been interesting to see the difference if Paxo had also intereviewed her.'

Famously dubbed 'that pinko' by Denis Thatcher, Snow is unusual among news presenters in the candour of his opinions - about ITN and ITV, for example, or about whether working journalists should accept honours from No 10 (he declined one), but also about political issues. He needs no prompting to defend this openness: 'It's important to stop imagining that there is a human being who is neutral. I don't believe it. There ain't such a thing. What you have to be is fair, to let people state their case, and be aware that the whole way you interview them is shaped by your prejudices, where you're coming from.'

Is John Humphrys penning regular columns for the Sunday Times a wholly good thing, then? 'He's a much more irascible and opinionated person than I am, but yes, I believe in an open society, and the more viewers know about what you really think, the more they can form an opinion as to what it is they're being given.

'This is probably dangerous territory, but I think it also helps to know how these people live in society. Then you know where they're coming from. There are plenty of presenters with fine stock-holding portfolios and reams of privately educated children, who also come from a particular perspective but don't show their hand.'

Describing the movie Broadcast News as 'full of all kinds of truths' about TV journalism, Snow relishes the 'kick bollock and scramble' it depicts, the moments when 'just getting it on air becomes more important than what gets on air' or when 'you hear through your earpiece that something's happened, and you know most of what's been planned is about to go out the window'.

He also thinks that news anchors should regularly re-experience the rough-and-tumble of reporting: 'It's a problem that the sausage machine doesn't often release, people such as Trevor [McDonald] and Michael Buerk and Peter Sissons to get the old dust under their feet. And once you become removed from the journalistic process and remain in presenter mode, you begin to lose sight of what's happening.'

fields.headline: We don't talk any more
fields.standfirst: Nye Bevan had it. Ann Widdecombe's got it. But Tony Blair is sadly lacking in it. Simon Hoggart on how the media killed rhetoric
fields.trailText: The late John Stradling Thomas MP was a Tory whip, but he did a brilliant Nye Bevan impression. I recall him standing perilously on a stool in Annie's Bar, reciting the whole of a Bevan speech, with the right accent, intonation, pauses and inflections. You might have been on a windswept hill above Ebbw Vale.
fields.body:
The late John Stradling Thomas MP was a Tory whip, but he did a brilliant Nye Bevan impression. I recall him standing perilously on a stool in Annie's Bar, reciting the whole of a Bevan speech, with the right accent, intonation, pauses and inflections. You might have been on a windswept hill above Ebbw Vale.

The speech was one of Bevan's great, lovingly rehearsed turns, about how as a boy he had thought that power was in the council, then he realised it was in parliament, then on becoming an MP he discovered it was in the cabinet. Finally he found that power actually resided in Whitehall, and hence democracy was a sham. It was a funny, exhilarating performance, and I felt privileged to enjoy it even secondhand, because a good impressionist is more evocative than any amount of scratchy black-and-white film.

You couldn't do that now. The audience would have gone home ages ago. Imagine any contemporary politician trying to convince the public with a long, oratorical set piece. In November last year the prime minister gave an interview to Jeremy Paxman about Ken Livingstone. He appeared half demented. His eyes bulged. He gulped. Even more disturbingly, he suddenly remembered to smile a death's-head grimace. Later I ran into Paxman and asked him what had gone wrong. He thought - and I paraphrase - that Blair was so consumed with hatred of Livingstone that his normal speech patterns were dislocated. The medium, unable to cope with the message, had imploded.

That wouldn't have happened to Nye Bevan, who would have produced a speech - 'lower than vermin' or 'dessicated calculating machine' perhaps. But Tony Blair is a creature of the modern media, and speaks the language of the daytime TV studio - cosy, cuddly, warm. He hasn't got the verbal bag of tools to do hatred. The way rhetoric has changed as the media have changed is the theme of a three-part Radio 4 series I've just finished working on. We wondered whether the formal persuasive talking of the past can survive today in a world where communication is by electronic pulses rather than by ringing voices. Nothing could be less rhetorical than email, with its sparse grammar and punctuation, minimalist vocabulary and absence even of capital letters, the equivalent of a speaker's stress. It is bland and unarousing. McLuhan talked about 'hot' and 'cool' media; email is positively frozen.

But rhetoric has survived. No one who has heard the Rev Ian Paisley in full flood can doubt that, nor the power his speech has over an audience. Indeed, US evangelists use all the tricks and formulae the ancient Greeks knew. Few people in a modern business organisation have escaped the motivational speech, a form of discourse which uses some of the same devices for praising capitalism that John Wesley used for praising the Lord. Lawyers still use rhetoric, in the packed intimacy of a courtroom; George Carman is the most successful exponent today.

Even in politics, rhetoric is still used - though it's now almost confined to party conferences, which are the only remaining great rallies. Gladstone's Midlothian campaign couldn't happen now; we'd all be at home watching TV. Ann Widdecombe, who has taken over the job of whipping the Tories to a fervour, told us of the tricks she uses - walking about the stage, arranging physical bits of business to attract attention, and most of all performing extempore, which is hypnotic, since the audience watches fascinated to see if she dries up. But it doesn't work as well on the page, and can look just silly on TV. Rhetoric isn't dead, but the people who use it now have to have multimedia skills as well.

The Art of Rhetoric starts tomorrow at 3.45pm on Radio 4

webTitle: Russia's bombardment of Chechnya goes on

fields.headline: Russia's bombardment of Chechnya goes on
fields.standfirst: Numerous casualties reported today
fields.trailText: The Russian assault on the Chechen capital Grozny continued today, despite pressure from Germany to halt its campaign and rebel reports of mounting Russian casualties.
fields.body:
The Russian assault on the Chechen capital Grozny continued today, despite pressure from Germany to halt its campaign and rebel reports of mounting Russian casualties.

"As long as this conflict continues it will cast a shadow over the relationship between Russia and Germany and the European Union," German chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's foreign policy adviser, Michael Steiner, told German Radio.

Chechen rebel spokesman Movladi Udugov claimed the Russians were suffering mounting casualties and had lost control of three villages southwest of Grozny. Moscow denied the report.

Federal officials reported that Russian jets and artillery had bombed a small village in Chechnya's southern mountains, trying to block the path of retreating rebel forces.

The strikes killed some 50 militants and wiped out two rebel bunkers, said Russian military spokesman major Alexander Diordiev.

These death tolls could not be confirmed. During the Chechen campaign both sides have routinely exaggerated claims of losses inflicted on their opponents.

RIA news agency reported today that some 80 more guerrillas had been killed in clashes around Vedeno, home base of rebel commander Shamil Basayev in the mountains south of Grozny. Only three Russian solders were killed, RIA said.

Interfax news agency quoted military sources in Mozdok, Russia's main army base in the North Caucasus just outside Chechnya, as saying up to 35 rebel fighters had been killed in the latest clashes in and around Grozny.

A spokeswoman for a body representing the mothers of Russian soldiers told Ekho Moskvy radio at least 1,000 federal troops had died and about 3,000 had been wounded during the military operation.

The radio said the Russian defence ministry had put the number of federal troops killed until the end of November - roughly two months after the campaign started - at about 300.

Acting president Vladimir Putin, propelled into the Kremlin by Boris Yeltsin's shock resignation last Friday, discussed the situation in the Russian-controlled parts of Chechnya today with Nikolai Koshman, Moscow's top representative in the war-racked province.

Mr Putin wants to finish the Chechen war if possible before Russia's presidential election, set for March, which he is the favourite to win. The war is popular among Russians and forms the basis for the acting president's high opinion poll ratings.

 A gunman has been shot dead in Beirut after firing grenades at the Russian embassy. It was believed the gunman was protesting against Russia's bombardment of Chechnya. One policeman was killed in the incident.

webTitle: Broken guns and old radios: standard issue to British soldiers

fields.headline: Broken guns and old radios: standard issue to British soldiers
fields.standfirst:
Weapons not working; communications failing: the problems of Tommys in Kosovo are just the latest in a series of equipment failings that have plagued the British army in recent years

British Kosovo troops hampered by failed guns, 'fractured' command and few powers
fields.trailText: Weapons not working; communications failing: the problems of Tommys in Kosovo are just the latest in a series of equipment failings that have plagued the British army in recent years
fields.body:
The British Army's chosen rifle is the troubled SA80, developed at the Royal Small Arms factory in Enfield. Launched to a fanfare of applause in 1985 as the modern weapon of choice for the Army, soldiers soon complained that the gun - developed at a cost of £384 million - had serious faults.

In March last year, the Ministry of Defence scientists identified 'underlying problems' with the rifle. Soldiers in the Gulf complained that firing pins broke, sand jammed the mechanism, a faulty catch allowed the magazine to fall out, the trigger stuck and the bayonets fell off during training. It was even suspended from Nato's list of acceptable weapons and the faults discovered so far have cost over £24 million to rectify. And it was no good for left-handers.

The news that British soldiers had problems using their radio units is also not new. Soldiers in Kosovo reportedly had to borrow cellular phones from reporters there as their own communications didn't work.

Most British units use the obsolete Clansman radio, developed originally in the 1960s. Its signals were, according to the reports, regularly intercepted by the Serbs.

And there is no immediate solution in site: it was announced last month that, after many delays, the new £2.2 billion Bowman radio system will be delayed by two years, and is scheduled to enter service in 2004 - eight years late.

But even that is not the end of the saga. Because Ministry of Defence rules mean that 'acceptance' of a product is defined as use by a brigade-sized part of the army, only around 2000 people could end up using the new equipment out of 102,000 serving soldiers.

It's all part of what is becoming a fine tradition of army equipment problems. A National Audit Office report in 1988 found that the military's stocktaking process was hopelessly inefficient and that millions of pounds of equipment had gone missing. Soldiers in the Gulf also found that their Challenger tanks lacked vital spare parts.

webTitle: British Kosovo troops hampered by failed guns, 'fractured' command and few powers

fields.headline: British Kosovo troops hampered by failed guns, 'fractured' command and few powers
fields.standfirst:
 British troops had to borrow weapons
 Radio conversations could be heard by Serbs
 War criminals freed because of lack of powers

Broken guns and old radios: standard issue to British soldiers
fields.trailText: Nato's advance into Kosovo was blighted by serious equipment failings experienced by British troop units, it is reported  today.
fields.body:
Nato's advance into Kosovo was blighted by serious equipment failings experienced by British troop units, it is reported today.

According to documents leaked to BBC Radio 4's Today programme, supposedly secure radios could be listened into by the Serbs. Guns issued to British paratroopers did not work properly, and some had to borrow weapons from other units, the documents, drawn up by senior British commanders, suggested.

Troops could not work properly after dark because they lacked sufficient quantities of night vision equipment. And one paratrooper unit had to let a suspected war criminal go free because they lacked a legal basis on which to detain him.

The BBC said that the leaked documents suggested that the British forces were ill-prepared for an opposed invasion.

It quoted one of the documents as saying: "It is the view of this headquarters that had the situation on 12th June (the day of Nato's advance) been anything less than benign, there would have been command, control and communication difficulties which could not have been resolved by K-For headquarters."

One section highlighted the unreliability of the paratroopers' guns. "During both blank and live training for Kosovo the light support weapon proved to be both unreliable and insufficiently robust."

On communications, the document stressed: "Communications are essential for the success and survival of light forces. We were fortunate that an inadequate system was not put to the test."

The Ministry of Defence issued a statement in response to the BBC's report. The MoD said that Britain and its allies were well prepared to launch a land campaign in Kosovo. And it was confident that this would have proved successful, had it been necessary to commence such a campaign.

The documents displayed concerns among the military about their inability to detain war crimes suspects. "There was much discussion about law, but little application of justice. Meanwhile the Albanian community in particular meted out violence on Serbs, sure in the knowledge that we were impotent to stop them."

Another section in one of the documents suggested that the headquarters of K-For commander General Sir Mike Jackson was too distant from troops on the ground, leading to "confused and fractured" command.

"Soldiers were operating in something of a vacuum which lasted for several days. There were constantly changing orders and confusion, with a potentially damaging effect on morale. This erodes confidence and may, in extremis, place individual soldiers in an invidious position."

Bruce George, the Labour MP for Walsall South who chairs the Commons select committee on defence, said he wanted to see action taken on the shortcomings suggested by the leaked documents.

"The documents ... have raised very interesting points. The defence committee has conducted substantive inquiries after every war, and we have already begun a very serious inquiry into the lessons to be derived from the war in Kosovo," said Mr George.

"The defence committee produced a report on the Strategic Defence Review and we reached the conclusion that if the Government wished to achieve its objectives, politically and militarily, then defence expenditure would have to rise beyond the rather miserable level to which it has sunk over the last 15 years.

Mr George said he was disturbed about the military's inability to detain war crime suspects. "This is not a military failure, it is a political inadequacy in which people who were undertaking peace keeping were in fact given inadequate legal tools," he said.

A spokesman for the Ministry of Defence said the equipment failings detailed in the reports would not have damaged the success of any land campaign in Kosovo.

The two reports, prepared by a lieutenant colonel and a brigadier, were designed to be as "critical as possible" of the armed forces' performance in the campaign, he added.

They would form part of a larger review of the military action in Kosovo which will be published later this year. "We always, after a campaign such as Kosovo, review the events as soon as possible and as critically as possible," said the MoD spokesman. "These reports are two of many such reports.

"They will form part of a balanced overall picture which we will be making public when we publish a report on the campaign later this year." He added: "With our 18 allies in Nato we prepared for a land campaign and were confident that this would have been successfully executed, had it been necessary.

Shadow Defence Secretary Iain Duncan Smith called for a wide-ranging inquiry into the military's problems during the Kosovo conflict. Mr Duncan Smith said: "It's very, very worrying obviously, and it's very worrying that we have to get this via a leaked report. "The most important thing is that this was pretty much perhaps as good as it will get, because this was done on the previous budget."

Former Liberal Democrat leader and Balkans expert Paddy Ashdown said the leaked documents suggested serious problems, but added that they contained the kind of complaints frequently voiced following a conflict. "Well it's undoubtedly very serious and I hope it will be taken seriously. But ... I don't think I can ever remember a single campaign ... in which there were not afterwards natural and proper complaints by frontline soldiers about the inadequacy of the equipment and the staff."

"But it has to be put in its context. This was a highly successful operation which was brought off with great skill and courage," Mr Ashdown told the Today programme.

webTitle: England rely on their elders and betters

fields.headline: England rely on their elders and betters
fields.trailText: Any of us can make a New Year resolution and fail to live up to it, but it takes an England cricket team to end the old year in resolute fashion and start the new one by falling apart.
fields.body:
Any of us can make a New Year resolution and fail to live up to it, but it takes an England cricket team to end the old year in resolute fashion and start the new one by falling apart.

To lose one batsman caught at third man and another to the hook trap may be considered a misfortune. To lose two in each of these ways looks like something worse than carelessness. And as for Chris Adams ...

Yesterday lunchtime, the spread-betting people thought England were heading for 420. That's how good a toss it was to win, how good a pitch, and how good a start by Atherton and Butcher. Twenty-four hours later, those two must have wondered why they had bothered, as 213 for 3 turned to 258 all out. The other day a statistician revealed that England no longer had the worst tail in the world. Is he quite sure?

Nasser Hussain was one of the two frontline batsmen who didn't get out to an awful shot - the other, naturally, was the very reverend Michael Vaughan. But Hussain was to blame in a deeper sense. In yesterday's Sunday Telegraph, Scyld Berry conducted a revealing round-table discussion between Hussain, Atherton, Barry Richards and Graeme Pollock, in which Hussain said that the reason the selectors chose the present batting line-up was that something had had to be done about England's top six. In fact, both last summer and in other recent series, England's top six had exactly matched that of their opponents. The weakness in the batting was the bottom five. The dropping of Mark Ramprakashæwas based on a fallacy.

Hussain thought it would be good for team spirit to take several beginners, and he has clearly been proved right. But he has paid a heavy price in terms of runs and wickets. In effect, he has been playing with half a team. England have made seven big individual scores, ranging from Hussain's stonewall 146 to Atherton's sparkling 71 (interesting how those two have swapped stereotypes), and every one has come from the three old stagers. In 18 innings, Hussain, Atherton and Stewart have made 776 runs at an average of 48, which is all you would have expected and a little more, especially given the way they began. It's worth looking at their scores, in chronological order: 0, 0, 0; 0, 16, 86; 108, 82, 15; 3, 70*, 28; 1, 146*, 95; 71, 15, 40.

Leaving aside Mark Butcher, who is neither one thing nor the other (like his footwork a lot of the time), the rest of the batting consists of three novices, Vaughan (or his understudy, Darren Maddy), Chris Adams and Andy Flintoff. They have also played 18 innings, which look like this 33, 16, 38; 5, 1, 36; 21, 25, 42; 29, 1, 12; 24, 19, 5; 42, 10, 22. Total 381 runs - half as many as their elders and betters - at an average of 21. This too is more or less what you would have expected. The striking thing is the number of starts the young ones have made: ten times out of 18, they have reached 20, or Done the Hard Part as the coaches say. Hussain, Atherton and Stewart have managed it just nine times, but only Stewart (twice) has failed to capitalise, and he has the excuse that he is having to keep wicket.

This is not to condemn Vaughan, Adams and Flintoff out of hand. Vaughan's defence is impressive, and so is Flintoff's hitting, though for a man who is fond of a pint he is easily intoxicated by his own strength. This time 10 years ago, England took a bunch of novice batsmen to the West Indies. Team spirit flowed, the runs didn't, and two promising players kept getting out between 20 and 45. Alec Stewart and Nasser Hussain made it in the end, and so should Vaughan and Flintoff. But it will be a lot easier for them if they play in a side that wins the odd Test match. Having Adams there with them, rather than Ramprakash, makes that highly improbable.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly. He was voted Editor of the Year in the special-interest category of the recent British Society of Magazine Editors awards.

fields.headline: Situation normal: all fouled up
fields.standfirst:
The news that British troops were woefully ill-equipped simply reflects the management of Nato's war.

Plus: The last Peanuts
fields.trailText: British forces which spearheaded last summer's occupation of Kosovo were  bedevilled - and could have been placed in mortal danger -  by deficient  weapons and equipment and scrambled lines of communication.  Two reports by  front-line commanders suggest that had the invasion been resisted, there  could have been horrendous casualties.
fields.body:
British forces which spearheaded last summer's occupation of Kosovo were bedevilled - and could have been placed in mortal danger - by deficient weapons and equipment and scrambled lines of communication. Two reports by front-line commanders suggest that had the invasion been resisted, there could have been horrendous casualties.

This is serious, as well as eye-catching. But we should not be too carried away. The reports, carefully leaked to the BBC Today programme this morning, carry a heavy whiff of crude Ministry of Defence budget politicking. What is more, both were very deliberately intended to highlight the shortcomings of the operation, as an aid to future planning.

All the same, the reports reveal some damning flaws in the Kosovo campaign. The airborne forces at the sharp end of the expedition had guns which did not work properly, and had to borrow weapons from other units. They lacked night vision equipment and could not operate properly after dark. The chain of command was confused, and orders were routinely countermanded. The soldiers were inadequately briefed about their duties and legal responsibilities once they had established control of the battered province.

At one level, this is confirmation that the military machine remains a blunt and blundering instrument. Forget all the hype about surgical precision, perfect discipline and split-second timing: all armies tend to make up their operations as they go along. We should remember too that the Kosovo operation was a more than usually ad hoc affair, dictated less by military considerations than by the squalid dither and confusion of Nato's political masters.

Now, where once Belgrade's federal army had overseen the brutal persecution of Albanians, Nato's woefully ill-equipped and prepared troops have watched over the expulsion of 90% of the province's Serbs. The ethnic cleansing of Kosovo is all but complete.

In that godawful context, the cockups of the actual invasion are a footnote. But they do raise interesting and urgent issues for military planners and analysts and, more important, will fuel the debate about defence funding. Equipping and training a modern army is screamingly expensive (ditto, with knobs on, for modern air and naval forces). The reports from Kosovo highlight just how close to the bone successive defence budget cuts have sliced. That is precisely why the reports have been leaked.

Advances in military technology have added exponentially to defence costs. In the post-Cold War world, priorities and objectives are ever harder to define. It remains true that war is too important a business to be left to generals. But Kosovo, more than any other recent conflict, strongly suggests that politicians are dangerous people to be put in charge of armies.

Related link:
Special report

The last Peanuts

The most endearing and successful comic strip of all time appears for the last time in daily newspapers today. Charles Schultz, the creator of Peanuts, has drawn his last Snoopy, Charlie Brown,and Lucy.

The strip first appeared in October 1950. Since then, Schultz has become an extraordinary one-man industry. His strip appears in 2600 newspapers read by more than 350m people daily, in 75 countries. Now 77, he is suffering from colon cancer, and has laid down his pen.There will be no more Peanuts, for Schultz's contract stipulates that no other artist can take over his gallery of loveably goofy characters. But at least there is a half-century of re-runs available, most of them inimitably timeless.

Related link: Special report The last Peanuts The most endearing and successful comic strip of all time appears for the last time in daily newspapers today. Charles Schultz, the creator of Peanuts, has drawn his last Snoopy, Charlie Brown,and Lucy. The strip first appeared in October 1950. Since then, Schultz has become an extraordinary one-man industry. His strip appears in 2600 newspapers read by more than 350m people daily, in 75 countries. Now 77, he is suffering from colon cancer, and has laid down his pen.There will be no more Peanuts, for Schultz's contract stipulates that no other artist can take over his gallery of loveably goofy characters. But at least there is a half-century of re-runs available, most of them inimitably timeless. Related links: Peanuts official site US National Cartoonists Society

webTitle: Jack Straw orders deportation of suspected Nazi war criminal

fields.headline: Jack Straw orders deportation of suspected Nazi war criminal
fields.standfirst: Race to investigate war crimes suspect
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw today ordered Konrad Kalejs to leave  Britain amid a growing public clamour for the government to  throw out the suspected Nazi war criminal.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw today ordered Konrad Kalejs to leave Britain amid a growing public clamour for the government to throw out the suspected Nazi war criminal.

Mr Straw's deportation notice followed an investigation into how Kalejs who was known by Scotland Yard to be suspected of murdering thousands of Jews was allowed into Britain.

Kalejs indicated at the weekend that he had seen the writing on the wall. "I am leaving this country as soon as I can," Kalejs told the Mail On Sunday before the deportation notice was officially served on him, "I have learned my lesson. The police cannot hold me," he said.

The Simon Wiesenthal Centre in Jerusalem, which tracks down Nazi war criminals and traced Kalejs to Britain, immediately urged the British government to act.

"We are calling for the British to arrest (Kalejs) and put him on trial for war crimes unless there is an extradition request from Latvia," the centre's director, Efraim Zuroff, said. "Britain should view this as an opportunity to achieve justice rather then as a problem that was thrust in their lap."

The home office came under heavy criticism since it emerged that Kalejs, an 86-year-old Australian citizen who has previously been deported from Canada and the United States, has been living in a retirement home in Lutterworth, Leicestershire.

In a further embarrassment to Mr Straw, the US department of justice told the Guardian it had shared information about Kalejs with the Metropolitan police, while the Yard's now disbanded war crimes unit was investigating another war crimes suspect.

Like Kalejs, Harijs Svikeris was also believed to have been part of the notorious Arajs Kommando unit, which was involved in the murder of at least 30,000 people, mainly Jews. Kalejs was identified in his Canadian deportation judgment as a war criminal by Svikeris. The two men are believed to have been joint second in command of the unit.

Svikeris, who lived in Milton Keynes, died before he could be prosecuted.

A department of justice spokesman said: "We shared a great deal of our Kalejs material with Scotland Yard for their use in the Svikeris investigation."

After home office officials admitted they could do nothing to prevent Kalejs leaving Britain, it was feared that he would flee before he could be arrested. He arrived in Britain in July on an Australian passport. Under immigration regulations Kalejs is due to leave on January 6.

Australia has said it would take Kalejs back.
