webTitle: Some less flattering experiences of the Dome

fields.headline: Some less flattering experiences of the Dome
fields.trailText: As one of the lucky 10,000 invited to the Dome on New Year's Eve, I must record what a shambles the arrangements for the audience were. We were stuck at a Stratford tube reception point, ticketless of course, until, in a sequence worthy of an Ealing comedy, we were herded on to a fleet of coaches and driven through the Blackwall tunnel with a police escort.
fields.body:
As one of the lucky 10,000 invited to the Dome on New Year's Eve, I must record what a shambles the arrangements for the audience were. Like your own editor, we were stuck at a Stratford tube reception point, ticketless of course, until, in a sequence worthy of an Ealing comedy, we were herded on to a fleet of coaches and driven through the Blackwall tunnel with a police escort.

We arrived at 10.40pm, by which time food and drink were long gone, and were among thousands still finding their seats, whilst the unfortunate singers on stage attempted to perform. The atmosphere up to and beyond midnight was ruined, and the only person sharp enough to refer to this immense cock-up was Stephen Fry, who was being blamed the next day by Michael Grade for messing up the timings for the show.

My grievance is not that this happened - the Dunkirk spirit was alive and well on the Greenwich peninsula, that night, and we had paid nothing for our tickets. What galled me was the duplicity emanating from the New Millennium Experience people, represented by Jenny Page, and from the government, represented by Chris Smith, in the 48 hours before. Both gave groundless assurances that it would be all right on the night, and seemed more concerned to spin than react.

Our conclusion was that the ruin of most of the audience's millennial night meant nothing to `the shareholder', so long as it all looked OK on television, and some heavy hitters could be wheeled out the next day to call black white.

In the shambles of this public-private initiative lies another confirmation that the public department is often unable to meet its brief. I regret raining on the Dome parade, but the prevailing mood of self-congratulation will not suffice.
Paul Arnott
Edenwood Productions

I spent Saturday at the Dome but came away disappointed. Best is the body zone - a witty take on the sounds and textures inside the body - but it's over too soon and the queue to get in a mile long.

The mind zone is aimed at the mindless. Most people collected around the football video replay in the hope of seeing some real action. Worse is the faith zone which fails to rise above noisy, text-based displays before offering an uninspired chance to write down your addled hopes on slips of paper in what feels like a high-tech betting shop. Other zones invite superficial involvement (often via push buttons - oh, the new technology!), while avoiding anything unexpected or, whisper it, controversial.

The rest is so universally obvious and unchallenging that the whole barely counts as an 'experience' at all. The Dome is a politician's vision of issue-free `edutainment' to keep us active but disengaged while they set about planning the future unencumbered by our input.
Andy Dawson
Shrewsbury
andy59_uk@yahoo.com

fields.headline: Gong - but not forgotten
fields.trailText: How Margaret Thatcher must be smiling to herself: 15 years after she told an untruth to the House of Commons - had she not told it, she might, she said to close associates, have ceased to be prime minister at six o'clock that night on the evening of the critical parliamentary debate on Westland - a Labour government creates two life peers in a list of five.
fields.body:
How Margaret Thatcher must be smiling to herself: 15 years after she told an untruth to the House of Commons - had she not told it, she might, she said to close associates, have ceased to be prime minister at six o'clock that night on the evening of the critical parliamentary debate on Westland - a Labour government creates two life peers in a list of five (Blair's bumper honours, December 31).

First Leon Brittan, who solemnly stonewalled and refused to answer the legitimate questions of the select committee on trade and industry looking into the Westland helicopter affair; and extracted from Mrs Thatcher a resignation letter which expressed the hope that he would 'return to high office soon'. And secondly Charles Powell - at the epicentre of the selective leaking of solicitor general Patrick Mayhew's letter, a wholly improper act for a civil servant.

Why has Bernard Ingham, Mr Powell's colleague over Westland and much else, been omitted from the peerage or, more seriously, how about many good men and women who served the Labour party faithfully in those difficult days of the mid 80s?
Tam Dalyell MP

More pages of crowd pleasing empire gongs for a few celebs and a host of functionaries. Plus ca change, plus ca change. Yours in millennial exasperation,
Chris Abbott
Harlow
cabbott@netcomuk.co.uk

fields.headline: New year's reflections
fields.trailText: 'The light may be fading on the 20th century, but the sun is still rising on America' - President Clinton. Can this be the same nation in which four juvenile offenders are to be executed during this month?
fields.body:
'The light may be fading on the 20th century, but the sun is still rising on America' - President Clinton. Can this be the same nation in which four juvenile offenders are to be executed during this month - two in Texas and two in Virginia - in flagrant contravention of international law?
Brian Crowther
Leeds
brian@bcrowther.demon.co.uk

President Clinton wishes the US to be the guiding light in the new century. With 98 executions last year, a record number since 1951?
Nigel Baldwin
Portsmouth
nigelbaldwin@clara.co.uk

In the new century, how long before men stop wearing the uniform of the 90s? Every male one sees on the telly wears the same boring yellow tie and blue shirt.
Fred Brooks
Redgrave

Do all those pedants who insist the millennium begins in 2001 (Letters, January 1) also believe the 60s began in 1961? That my forties began when I was 41? They're confusing a logical approach to number with a symbolic approach.
Roger Horrocks
London
Roger@jetcom5.freeserve.co.uk

The new millennium? It's just another 1,000 years to me.
Bill McMellon
Wormingford

First cuckoo of the millennium, anyone?
Tim Squires
Edinburgh
timmi@genie.co.uk

webTitle: From restaurant chef to environmental activist

fields.headline: From restaurant chef to environmental activist
fields.trailText: All her life, Joyce Hambling has loved food. Wooed by its luscious variety of textures, flavours and colours, she chose a career in restaurants, first as a waitress and later as a chef. Jobs in high-profile establishments such as London's L'Escargot nurtured this love, and five years ago she decided to become a self- employed caterer.
fields.body:
All her life, Joyce Hambling has loved food. Wooed by its luscious variety of textures, flavours and colours, she chose a career in restaurants, first as a waitress and later as a chef. Jobs in high-profile establishments such as London's L'Escargot nurtured this love, and five years ago she decided to become a self- employed caterer.

Prestigious contracts to provide food for events such as London Fashion Week followed. Then Greenpeace asked her to cook for them. 'I can only describe what happened as a road-to-Damascus conversion. My first thought when I got the Greenpeace contract was that they would look good on my client list. I had always thought of food in terms of its gorgeousness - how much olive oil you could throw at a dish, that sort of thing.'

Towards the end of 1996, Greenpeace environmental campaigners were involved in blockading the port of Liverpool to prevent the first genetically modified crops coming into the UK. 'I decided to find out a bit more about why they were doing this, and read an article in Guardian Weekend about the possibilities of growing oranges in Scotland and mange tout in Manchester if these foods were genetically modified to flourish in an alien climate. At first, having been brought up in an age of scientific discoveries, I thought wow, but by the end of the article I was saying, 'Oh, my God, what would that mean for countries in east Africa who have moved away from what they used to grow traditionally so they could have an export crop?' 'It suddenly occurred to me that I couldn't let these Greenpeace campaigners blockade while I just cooked their lunch. I felt that if I didn't make a stand too there would be nothing left to cook with.'

What she describes as 'a steep learning curve' followed. She became involved in the Genetic Engineering Network, a loose coalition of people and groups sharing information about genetic engineering. She has abandoned her catering business to work for them full time, collating news and email lists. The job has not been funded, so at the moment she has no salary. 'I've lost all my muscle tone because I no longer rush around carrying huge sacks of potatoes - instead I'm sitting at a desk reading through all this material. I read much more than I used to and always want to know the other side of the story.'

Aside from her passionate commitment to the campaign, Hambling, 35, believes the new way of working has liberated her. 'I'm free of all that 'I've worked an extra 15 minutes so that's an extra £3.20' stuff.' Even the luxuries she used to enjoy, such as grabbing a taxi, taking a friend out to dinner or buying a new pair of shoes, she has happily forgone.

'My change in direction has made all sorts of differences. I used to be the sort of person who would wear matching lipstick and nail varnish, but now I don't even know where my last dried-out mascara is. Some people think I've taken on sainthood and others think I've joined the ALF. 'The only trouble is that I'm in danger of becoming a bit boring because I love what I do so much and think about it all the time. Let's face it, there aren't many people who want to talk about intellectual property rights when they go to a party.'

I read much more than I used to and always want to know the other side of the story.' Aside from her passionate commitment to the campaign, Hambling, 35, believes the new way of working has liberated her. 'I'm free of all that 'I've worked an extra 15 minutes so that's an extra £3.20' stuff.' Even the luxuries she used to enjoy, such as grabbing a taxi, taking a friend out to dinner or buying a new pair of shoes, she has happily forgone. 'My change in direction has made all sorts of differences. I used to be the sort of person who would wear matching lipstick and nail varnish, but now I don't even know where my last dried-out mascara is. 'The only trouble is that I'm in danger of becoming a bit boring because I love what I do so much and think about it all the time. Let's face it, there aren't many people who want to talk about intellectual property rights when they go to a party.'

webTitle: Gay couple's twins denied entry to UK

fields.headline: Gay couple's twins denied entry to UK
fields.trailText: A gay couple face a legal battle with the home office to allow their three-week old twin babies to stay in Britain after they were refused entry when they arrived at Heathrow.
fields.body:
A gay couple face a legal battle with the home office to allow their three-week old twin babies to stay in Britain after they were refused entry when they arrived at Heathrow.

The babies, Aspen and Saffron Drewitt-Barlow, were conceived after Barrie Drewitt and Tony Barlow found a surrogate mother in California who was willing to carry the children after one of the couple provided the sperm and the egg came from a separate donor.

But when they arrived back in Britain last week, immigration officials immediately detained the babies and their parents were questioned for more than an hour.

The babies' US passports were confiscated and they were granted temporary admission to Britain for a month while the issue of their immigration status is resolved.

Mr Drewitt, 32, a businessman from Danbury, Essex, said he would write to Tony Blair asking for a meeting with the home secretary, as the case appeared to be a case of discrimination against the children of gay couples.

He said it had been frightening to be detained at Heathrow airport. He told the Mail on Sunday: 'They asked us if the twins needed anything and put us and the two nannies in a small interview room with no windows or air conditioning for over an hour.

'They were asking who the parents of the children were, and Tony and I said: 'We are.' They could not get their heads round that at all.'

His partner, Mr Barlow, 35, told the newspaper: 'We have been told that we were very lucky to get a month. Sometimes they only give you 24 hours.'

In an interview with Sky News yesterday, he said: 'It's stressful. We've been through so much before, just to get pregnant and then worrying all through the pregnancy. All we want to do is just get on with our lives.'

The US supreme court names both men as the children's parents on their birth certificates, recognising them as 'parent one' and 'parent two', following a ruling.

The couple said they would take the matter up with the European court of human rights if necessary. They have consulted a solicitor who has advised them that under UK law, British citizenship can only pass through a father if he is married to a baby's mother.

If either of the men had adopted the babies, then they would have automatically gained British citizenship.

A home office spokeswoman said: 'As a general principle we will be looking at what is best for the children consistent with UK law and what precedent will be set.'

The couple have the option of asking Jack Straw to allow the babies to stay in Britain indefinitely. Under British law, the surrogate mother is still the legal parent. If the babies are refused entry to Britain, they may be forced to return to the United States to make an application for entry clearance at a British embassy, which would mean the children would remain American nationals, but would be allowed to live in Britain. Or the couple could apply to adopt the babies and ask officials to extend the length of their stay while the adoption process takes place.

But the spokeswoman said the home secretary would be wary of setting a precedent that could then be applied to other child immigration cases.

She added: 'We want to consider this case very carefully. With any case that raises unprecedented issues we would want to be careful to consider the implications.'

webTitle: Smoke bomb masks burglar's theft of £3m Cezanne

fields.headline: Smoke bomb masks burglar's theft of £3m Cezanne
fields.trailText: The theft of a £3m painting by Paul Cézanne in Oxford on millennium night was carried out by a professional burglar who created a smokescreen to foil security cameras, it was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
The theft of a £3m painting by Paul Cézanne in Oxford on millennium night was carried out by a professional burglar who created a smokescreen to foil security cameras, it was disclosed yesterday.

With the noise of his break-in masked by celebratory fireworks, the burglar cut a hole in the roof of the Ashmolean museum and descended to its art gallery by rope ladder.

He had a holdall containing a scalpel, tape, gloves, a smoke canister and a small fan. He set off the canister, and used the fan to spread the smoke and obscure the view of the gallery's closed circuit cameras. In less than 10 minutes, he had seized the painting, View of Auvers-sur-Oise, climbed up the ladder, and gone. Behind him he left the holdall, gloves, scalpel and tape.

Yesterday a Thames Valley police spokesman refused to discuss the method behind the biggest of a series of recent thefts and attempted thefts from the 317-year-old Ashmolean. But a police source said: `It was a very clever ploy, a very professional theft. The burglar only entered the room where the Cézanne was hanging, and that appeared to be his only target. `He obviously knew exactly what he was doing. He used the smoke device to prevent any security cameras or patrolling guards from seeing his face.'

The smoke caused a university porter to call the fire brigade. When the firefighters arrived and realised there was no blaze, they found the remains of the smoke canister. It was only then that the police realised there had been a break-in and that an alarm was flashing near where the painting should have been.

Specialists in art theft had been called in by Thames Valley police, a spokesman said. `This is not a crime which is going to be solved overnight. We are more used to run-of-the-mill crimes. We need expertise.'

Customs and immigration staff at sea and air ports have been warned in case an attempt is made to smuggle the Cézanne abroad.

Superintendent John Carr of Oxford police, who heads the investigation, said: 'Whoever has taken this painting has given some thought to how to steal it. The person has some reason for it, and some outlet for it. One possibility is it has been stolen to order.'

The Ashmolean's director, Christopher Brown, said security at the museum had been the same on Friday as on any night of the year.

Dr Brown described the painting as an important early transitional picture from the very early work to the mature Cézanne, showing a small town near Versailles in which the artist lived for a short time.

'It is the only Cézanne we have in the Ashmolean, and it is very important as an example of late 19th-century painting. This is not just a criminal act but a very selfish act. 'The pattern in previous similar thefts is that pictures have been retrieved.'

In 1997 three men tried to steal a 1,100-year-old jewel made for Alfred the Great from the Ashmolean, but in attempting to smash a display case they set off alarms. In 1996 two 17th-century French bottles were stolen. Earlier in the decade there was a spate of thefts from the museum and from Oxford colleges.

View of Auvers-sur-Oise was painted between 1879 and 1882 and is subtitled The Fence to distinguish it from other studies by Cézanne and by other artists - including Van Gogh, who painted his Portrait of Dr Gachet there; this latter holds the world's auction-price record but has also been stolen.

fields.headline: Constant criticism upsets teachers
fields.trailText: Most primary teachers say they feel demoralised, overworked and undervalued, but are sustained by the love of working with children, according to a survey published today by the National Union of Teachers.
fields.body:
Most primary teachers say they feel demoralised, overworked and undervalued, but are sustained by the love of working with children, according to a survey published today by the National Union of Teachers.

About 97% of teachers surveyed regarded the children as a positive aspect of their jobs. Nearly one in five mentioned time spent on after-school activities with pupils as an enjoyable part of the work.

The survey of 168 teachers in England and Wales found that most felt the biggest pressure, after the paperwork, was implementation of the government's initiatives. They wanted more time out of the classroom for paperwork and lesson preparation. According to the union, few primary teachers are entitled to 'non-contact' time in working hours; a small number get up to 30 minutes a week.

More than a quarter of those surveyed felt inspections from the office for standards in education (Ofsted) and 'constant criticism' were the biggest pressures. One teacher with 30 years' experience said: 'Good teachers never make a child feel inadequate, but good teachers are made to feel inadequate every day of their teaching lives, with 'must try harder' on every end of term report.'

Another said she was 'deflated and disheartened, due to regular insults and negative comments towards the teaching profession'. A male teacher with 20 years' experience said: 'Get off our backs and allow our own professional judgment and expertise to get the best from our children.' A female colleague, with a similar length of service, said: 'We are open to the recent changes, but need more time to take initiatives on board before more changes are made.'

More government funding was cited by more than one in three as the single change that would do most to improve standards in schools. In other comments, there was clear opposition to performance-related pay in schools, due to be implemented this year.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, said: 'This snapshot shows a profession which cares about the future of its children, even though, personally, teachers feel demoralised, devalued and dispirited. There are many lessons here which the government should heed. Teachers do not resist change unless they perceive it to be against the interests of pupils. 'They want change to be evaluated and its impact audited before being introduced. They will take on extra work even though it may push them to the limits, if they believe it's for the benefit of children.'

Most teachers of English, maths and science say the national tests at 14 do not motivate children or accurately measure their achievements, a survey by the Association of Teachers and Lecturers finds.

More than six in 10 teachers surveyed said the tests dominated their teaching. Of English teachers, more than seven in 10 said the tests did not allow pupils the chance to shine. Peter Smith, the union's general secretary, said: 'The culture of constant testing is a real turnoff for young people. Many enter the year in which they'll sit the tests with dread.'

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Woman held over deserted boy
fields.body:
Woman held over deserted boy

Scotland Yard last night arrested a 24-year-old woman after an 18-month-old boy was found in a tower block minutes before midnight on millennium eve. The toddler, called Omarin, was discovered in the hallway of flats in Holloway, north London, and is now being cared for by foster parents. He was left with a bag of secondhand clothes, disposable nappies, a blanket, a toothbrush and a fizzy drink.

Harrison leaves hospital

George Harrison was recovering at home yesterday after being discharged from Harefield hospital, west London. Harrison, 56, was taken there on Thursday with an injured right lung after a knife attack at his home. Michael Abram, 33, from Huyton, Liverpool, has been charged with the attempted murder of Harrison and his wife, Olivia. Paul Baldwin

Four detained after fatal fire

Four people were yesterday being questioned by police about a fire in Newport, south Wales, on New Year's Day in which Shaun Mahoney, 40, died. Police launched an inquiry after four arson attacks, three on houses and one on a car, in Newport on January 1. Two men and two women from Newport, aged between 20 and 22, were being interviewed at Newport central police station.

Pensioner found dead

Merseyside police last night launched a murder investigation after the body of an 87-year-old woman was found at her home in Liverpool. Marjorie Keating had suffered massive head injuries. Police believe she may have disturbed an intruder.

fields.headline: Lottery to fund youth camps
fields.standfirst: Blunkett plan for adventure holidays for all 16-year-olds
fields.trailText: Ministers are planning revolutionary adventure-style summer camps for all 16-year-olds to develop their self-confidence and help them mature more quickly.
fields.body:
Ministers are planning revolutionary adventure-style summer camps for all 16-year-olds to develop their self-confidence and help them mature more quickly.

The scheme, to be announced this week by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, is designed to provide an exciting and enriching experience for all young people at the end of their years of compulsory education.

Camps running between June and September will offer outdoor trips including climbing, orienteering and survival skills, some of which may take place abroad. Other options will include extended work experience and voluntary jobs in the local community.

Mr Blunkett is particularly anxious to target the thousands of young people who leave school at 16 without qualifications and have no plans for further education, training or work. He fears that many will become permanent dropouts unless something is done to awaken an interest in continuing education.

But the government thinks places at the camps should be offered to all 16-year-olds, regardless of academic attainment or family income. Ministers do not want the courses to be seen as a reward for underperformance.

A department of education spokeswoman said: "We want to give teenagers real-life experience which will help them to grow up more quickly. At the moment, some adolescents find it difficult to make the transition between school and adult life. These courses will make them ready for the adult world much sooner."

Mr Blunkett is expected to explain how the scheme will work in an address to the north of England education conference in Wigan on Thursday.

It will be a joint initiative with Chris Smith, the culture secretary, and is likely to be funded by lottery money. Discussions are planned with local authority leaders and others who might be able to organise camps.

Details, including the level of funding, and whether participants might contribute themselves to the cost, remain to be determined. Ministers hope the first might begin this year. Attendance would be voluntary.

"This is not some new kind of national service," the spokeswoman said. "The aim would be to make these camps sufficiently attractive that youngsters would want to come on them."

Courses are likely to vary but ministers envisage that travel and outdoor experience will form an important ingredient. Possibilities could include mountaineering in Wales, building a well in Africa or camping on Dartmoor.

Mr Blunkett is aware that many young people already gain similar experiences from the Duke of Edinburgh awards or organisations such as Camp America. However, these teen-agers tend to be from middle class families only. "This would not simply be an experience for the few, but an opportunity to contribute to the community, to focus on volunteering and active citizenship and perhaps offer extended opportunities for experience in the world of work," the spokeswoman added.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, yesterday welcomed the proposal.

"I would send some of the kids away for more than six weeks," he said. "Some could do with several years. But the summer camps would do no harm and they could do a lot of good, particularly for children who feel school has no relevance to them."

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, dismissed the suggestion that young people should pay to attend the camps, adding: "They will stand or fall on their ability to attract students with what they can offer. I'm sure the schools will offer encouragement and work with parents to ensure they do attend."

webTitle: Ex-pupils offer internet revision tips for GCSE success

fields.headline: Ex-pupils offer internet revision tips for GCSE success
fields.trailText: A company founded by two schoolboy entrepreneurs to publish GCSE study guides is preparing to launch a free internet revision service with notes provided by some of Britain's finest teachers.
fields.body:
A company founded by two schoolboy entrepreneurs to publish GCSE study guides is preparing to launch a free internet revision service with notes provided by some of Britain's finest teachers. The company's bosses, now first-year students at Oxford, claim the site will revolutionise learning and take the slog out of exam preparation.

'We are doing what the government is failing to do - providing the best education for everyone,' said Nick Rose, 19, who, with his partner Jordan Mayo, 18, left Manchester grammar school last year.

Mr Rose, from Sale, Greater Manchester, is studying politics, philosophy and economics at Lady Margaret Hall when not using his hands-free phone in a penthouse office near the Bank of England in London to raise a six-figure start-up capital fund. 'We've been told we need to go in first and flashy to capture the market,' he said.

The company's website has been registered in Italy so that it can be called Revise.it. 'I thought that was kind of funky,' said Mr Rose. 'I never did like all that dot.com stuff.'

Despite their being rude about the government's education policies, Mr Rose and Mr Mayo have already received a letter of support from that well-know technophobe Tony Blair.

'At the back of our minds, both when we were at school and now, is the idea of sharing our education and passing on the massive benefits we have had,' said Mr Rose. 'We have not yet met one person who does not think this is a fantastic idea. The best thing about it is that if you wake up in a panic at 4am on the morning of your maths exam, you can do some instant revision. The information is instantly available and it's free.'

Most mainstream GCSE subjects will be covered when the service goes live in March and A-level guides will be introduced later in the year.

Staff at Manchester grammar, including three who are shareholders in the company, have so far been commissioned to produce revision notes.

'It's quite ironic having to chase teachers up and trying to keep them to deadlines,' said Mr Rose. 'We want the best teachers we can find and we don't care about their background or what kind of school they come from.'

About a third of Britain's school students have access to the internet at home and another third have access at school. 'We hope that once schools see the service online they will realise it is a resource they cannot do without.'

Mr Rose and Mr Mayo admit that they are also in business for the money and the buzz. 'We tried writing a maths GCSE guide together but a teacher told us it was rubbish,' said Mr Rose. 'So now I stick to the business side.'

'I love meeting consultants, bankers, solicitors and venture capitalists.'

For reasons of commercial secrecy, he said, he was unable to reveal how he and Mr Mayo would make the profits from their revision service. 'We have various clever ideas that our web people have come up with and we're also using tools that can only be provided by the internet.' Revise.it Ltd has been launched with the help of profits generated by the modest success of the original book-form revision guides.

'I phoned every Dillon's and Waterstone's in the country to persuade shops to take them,' said Mr Rose. 'My greatest success was when Waterstone's in Preston took 20.'

The young entrepreneurs eventually sold out to Oxford University Press, which is about to bring out the chemistry and biology guides. The advance has been shared between the authors and the royalties will go to Manchester Grammar's bursary fund to provide school places for boys whose parents cannot afford its fees.

Mr Rose, from Sale, Greater Manchester, is studying politics, philosophy and economics at Lady Margaret Hall when not using his hands-free phone in a penthouse office near the Bank of England in London to raise a six-figure start-up capital fund. 'We've been told we need to go in first and flashy to capture the market,' he said. The company's website has been registered in Italy so that it can be called Revise.it. 'I thought that was kind of funky,' said Mr Rose. 'I never did like all that dot.com stuff.' Despite their being rude about the government's education policies, Mr Rose and Mr Mayo have already received a letter of support from that well-know technophobe Tony Blair. 'At the back of our minds, both when we were at school and now, is the idea of sharing our education and passing on the massive benefits we have had,' said Mr Rose. 'We have not yet met one person who does not think this is a fantastic idea. The best thing about it is that if you wake up in a panic at 4am on the morning of your maths exam, you can do some instant revision. The information is instantly available and it's free.' Most mainstream GCSE subjects will be covered when the service goes live in March and A-level guides will be introduced later in the year. Staff at Manchester grammar, including three who are shareholders in the company, have so far been commissioned to produce revision notes. 'It's quite ironic having to chase teachers up and trying to keep them to deadlines,' said Mr Rose. 'We want the best teachers we can find and we don't care about their background or what kind of school they come from.' About a third of Britain's school students have access to the internet at home and another third have access at school. 'We hope that once schools see the service online they will realise it is a resource they cannot do without.' Mr Rose and Mr Mayo admit that they are also in business for the money and the buzz. 'We tried writing a maths GCSE guide together but a teacher told us it was rubbish,' said Mr Rose. 'So now I stick to the business side.' 'I love meeting consultants, bankers, solicitors and venture capitalists.' For reasons of commercial secrecy, he said, he was unable to reveal how he and Mr Mayo would make the profits from their revision service. 'We have various clever ideas that our web people have come up with and we're also using tools that can only be provided by the internet.' Revise.it Ltd has been launched with the help of profits generated by the modest success of the original book-form revision guides. 'I phoned every Dillon's and Waterstone's in the country to persuade shops to take them,' said Mr Rose. 'My greatest success was when Waterstone's in Preston took 20.' The young entrepreneurs eventually sold out to Oxford University Press, which is about to bring out the chemistry and biology guides. The advance has been shared between the authors and the royalties will go to Manchester Grammar's bursary fund to provide school places for boys whose parents cannot afford its fees.

webTitle: Machete attack kills Antrim unionist on estate in grip of drug dealers

fields.headline: Machete attack kills Antrim unionist on estate in grip of drug dealers
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Police in Northern Ireland were last night questioning several people over the murder of a father of three children, less than five hours into the new year. They said that they were unable to rule out a sectarian motive.
fields.body:
Police in Northern Ireland were last night questioning several people over the murder of a father of three children, less than five hours into the new year. They said that they were unable to rule out a sectarian motive.

Denver Smith, 32, a Protestant from Antrim, whose three daughters are aged between seven and 11, was married to a Catholic, Bridget. He was killed in a machete attack in the town's mixed Stiles housing estate, which, increasingly, is in the grip of drug dealers.

Republicans helped stamp out a mushrooming drugs trade in the nearby Rathenraw estate, but suppliers have switched to the Stiles area. One local politician described parts of the estate as being a 'little Beirut', with houses and garages burnt out where the drug dealers operate. Friends said Smith, a campaign worker for the Progressive Unionist party, linked to the Ulster Volunteer Force, had been attacked as he made his way to a house party. A minibus had dropped him off along with several other men after the group had seen in the new year at the local football side's social club.

Smith, described as probably weighing more than 20 stone (127kg), had been unable to run when a gang of six men set on the group. He was hit on the head a dozen times with a machete, and stabbed several times with a large pike.

The attackers screamed at locals as they went to his aid. One witness said one shouted: 'Let the bastard die.' As police swooped, suspects were seen jumping through windows. It is thought officers seized clothing that was being rapidly washed, but also took away some blood-soaked items.

Smith was taken to Antrim area hospital just after 4.30am on Saturday. He was pronounced dead three minutes after he arrived.

The attack came about two hours after another incident involving a gang that attacked a house in the area. There is speculation that the UVF was behind that, either in a row over protection money or in a campaign against dealers.

But Smith's friends hotly denied that he was either involved in drug dealing or in the UVF attack on the house. He is believed to have had no criminal record.

Ken Wilkinson, a spokesman for the PUP in south Antrim, said Smith had been a close friend who had driven a vehicle for him during council election campaigns. They had been at the social club function together He said Smith's widow and daughters were in shock. The funeral is expected to take place on Wednesday.

'I am convinced that there was nothing sectarian about the attack,' said Mr Wilkinson. 'It was, instead, the work of criminal elements. There is no doubt about that. He was set upon by a group with hatchets, machetes and crossbows. There was no escape for him.

'Most of the Stiles estate is decent, except for a small corner around where he was hacked to death. The drug dealers openly sell everything you could imagine while standing around oil drums with fires blazing in them.

'Antrim is gaining a terrible reputation, one of the worst. It is becoming the drugs supply capital of Northern Ireland.'

Residents in the area heckled Paddy Marks, the Ulster Unionist mayor of Antrim, as he arrived at the murder scene. He said he had hoped the authorities were winning the war against drugs, and promised to step up efforts to stamp out the burgeoning problem.

webTitle: Build loyalty or face revolt, Callaghan warns Blair

fields.headline: Build loyalty or face revolt, Callaghan warns Blair
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was warned by James Callaghan yesterday that he would face a cabinet revolt unless he governed in a more collegiate way.  In a mild rebuke, the former Labour prime minister called on Mr Blair to open up cabinet discussions to ensure loyalty and understanding from senior ministers when the going got tough.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was warned by James Callaghan yesterday that he would face a cabinet revolt unless he governed in a more collegiate way.

In a mild rebuke, the former Labour prime minister called on Mr Blair to open up cabinet discussions to ensure loyalty and understanding from senior ministers when the going got tough.

'When times become more difficult  then of course you need all your colleagues to be associated with the problems that you're facing,' Lord Callaghan told BBC Radio 4's The Westminster Hour. `You must be able to command not only their loyalty but also their understanding. The best way to do that is to have full discussions of whatever problems you have.'

Lord Callaghan, who has been generally supportive of Mr Blair, stressed that he was not criticising the prime minister who 'had done extremely well'. But the ticking-off from Britain's last Labour prime minister will fuel criticism of the presidential style of government which has led one Downing Street insider to compare Mr Blair to Napoleon Bonaparte.

Mr Blair, who, from being elected Labour leader, made no secret that he intended to 'govern from the centre', holds short cabinet meetings lasting about 45 minutes. All the government's big decisions are made in cabinet sub-committees or in discussions with ministers.

But Downing Street is un likely to heed Lord Callaghan's warning because Mr Blair is determined to avoid cabinet splits like those that occurred in the Callaghan and Wilson years. Lord Callaghan held long cabinet discussions as he tried to win consensus among colleagues, ranging from Tony Benn on the left to Denis Healey on the right.

In the interview, he also warned New Labour supporters not to sever the party's relationship with the trade unions. 'Anybody who suggests that [the relationship] should be discontinued would, I think, be wrong,' he said. But Lord Callaghan, who was beaten by Margaret Thatcher in 1979 because of his failure to tame the trade unions, admitted that he had allowed the union barons too much power.

'In the late 70s and in the 80s in particular the unions became overweaningly powerful and they intervened too much on issues that were purely political. We encouraged them to do so, so of course we're responsible for that.'

He added that the right balance had now been struck with the unions, and praised Mr Blair and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, for rescuing the Labour party from its 'unsatisfactory' state in the 1980s.

Lord Callaghan, who calls himself Original Labour rather than New Labour, sympathised with Mr Blair's habit of consulting Baroness Thatcher more often than himself. But this did not say anything about New Labour's policies, he said. 'I think all it says is that he turns to somebody who won four [sic] elections instead of somebody who didn't win any.'

webTitle: Tales of horror oust Enid Blyton

fields.headline: Tales of horror oust Enid Blyton
fields.trailText: For children, he is the Enid Blyton of his day - only his characters eat strained eyeballs and brains, and walk down Fear Street.
fields.body:
For children, he is the Enid Blyton of his day - only his characters eat strained eyeballs and brains, and walk down Fear Street.

He is RL Stine, a 53-year-old New Yorker who outdid JK Rowling and Roald Dahl yesterday by emerging as the author whose books are borrowed most from secondary school libraries in Britain.

His hallmark is buckets of gore, jokily poured into books written almost as fast as those by Blyton, which featured the placid Noddy and Big Ears and the Famous Five children, and which ruled the children's book market for much of the last century.

Stine began taking his brother to horror films at the age of nine. His motto is: 'It's fun to scare people - and it's fun to find out a new way to scare them every time.'

Best known for the Goosebumps series, he writes with a skeleton and a tribal mask by his side. He sells 1.75m copies a month and works on two titles at once.

In the survey, he beats his only two conceivable rivals into second and third place - Terry Deary, who writes the irreverent Horrible Histories series, and Dahl.

Terry Pratchett comes fifth, while the author of the Asterix comics is 23rd and Sue Townsend 28th - all above Rowling's 43rd, with Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone as her most popular title.

The hobbit man, JR Tolkien, is 42nd, Shakespeare is 50th, Blyton 59th, and CS Lewis of Narnia fame 66th. Charles Dickens is 104th.

The survey came from a website, www.schoolsnet.com, which tracked borrowings of every book in 100 school libraries over a year - a total of 250,000 borrowings. The top 10 authors and their most popular books were:
1 RL Stine, Cuckoo Clock of Doom
2 Terry Deary, Terrible Tudors
3 Roald Dahl, Matilda
4 Jacqueline Wilson, Bad Girls
5 Terry Pratchett, Truckers
6 Judy Blume, Just as Long as We're Together
7 Christopher Pike, Secret Path
8 Paul Jennings, Undone!
9 Katherine Applegate, Visitor
10 Morris Gleitzman, Puppy Fat

fields.headline: Timing is everything
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV
fields.trailText: Elsie Tanner, they said, was the woman every salesman hoped would answer the door. Whereas the woman who did open the door was invariably Ena Sharples.
fields.body:
Elsie Tanner, they said, was the woman every salesman hoped would answer the door. Whereas the woman who did open the door was invariably Ena Sharples.

Raquel (Sarah Lancashire) of the Rovers Return was the barmaid every man dreamed would serve him, leaning like the blessed damozel from the gold bar of heaven, backed by shining spirits in bottles. A barmaid in excelsis. Beautiful as a daffodil though not as bright. A fine comic creation but entirely without a sense of humour. Three years ago she left Curly, her husband, and Coronation Street (ITV) and went to Kuala Lumpur, the sort of place scriptwriters send you if they are secretly in love with you. Otherwise you go to Lowestoft.

On New Year's Day Curly answered the door and it was Raquel.

Then again, it wasn't. Offered a glass of good wine by Curly (who had been keeping it for a special occasion that never occurred) she said 'Oooh! Syrah and Grenache!' And seeing his stunned look, added 'The grapes it's made from. I'm getting leathery undertones.' 'If you don't like it...' began Curly helplessly.

Raquel was now living in a French chateau, 'It's not an enormous chateau. It's not huge. It is a proper chateau though. It's detached and everything.' The skin between her eyebrows puckered with unaccustomed thought. 'What's so funny? It is detached and everything.' She wanted a divorce to marry Armand, a wine-grower, being, as she mentioned in passing, preganant. 'Only just, mind you.'

Dawn was breaking - you wondered if this was a dream - and she was anxious to get back to Curly's daughter, Alice, and Armand's daughters, Madeleine and Elene. 'That's like what we call Helen except they don't sound the aitches in France.' 'No,' said Curly soberly, 'we don't in Weatherfield. We're very French in that respect.'

Raquel is luminous but not bright. Curly once named a star after her, and she vanished with the first light as stars do. This was, unusually for Coronation Street, a duet and profoundly melancholic.

There was a natural magnificence about Michael Gambon's performance as John Harrison in Longitude (Channel 4) Rawboned, provincial and powerful, he invented the first accurate nautical clock. Not unlike Dr Johnson, who, about the same time, was compiling the first dictionary with the same heroic labour (and sharing Harrison's poor opinion of the sea).

In 1714 parliament offered £20,000 for the first practicable solution to finding longitude at sea. A fortune for the time, but only £10 for every sailor drowned when Sir Cloudesley Shovell wrecked his fleet on the Scillies, believing he was off Brittany. With latitude as his belt and longitude as his braces, a man could face the unknown unafraid and, indeed, unexposed. The proposed solutions were Swiftian. Wounding dogs, on the theory that they would howl at noon. Mooring a chain of 600 barges across the Atlantic. Harrison was a carpenter, a rude mechanical, and his solution was mechanical. A clock which kept GMT reliably at sea. If you knew Greenwich time you could calculate, from the sun, how many degrees east or west you were.

Sailing home with his first sea-going clock, Gambon stood foursquare on the deck and shouted that they were heading for the rocks. 'According to my calculations, that is the Lizard Rock. I am not mistaken. I'd set my life on it. You are 60 miles west.' This is a flag-planting declaration of faith like Galileo's 'But it does move' or Martin Luther's 'Here I stand.' It was the Lizard. Your skin prickled.

The story swung invigoratingly between horology and Hornblower. It also tick-tocked between Harrison and Rupert Gould (Jeremy Irons) who, two hundred years later, restored the neglected masterpieces.

Written and directed by Charles Sturridge, it was a magnificent leap of faith (and a safe landing) for Channel 4. You were always comfortingly conscious of rock solid performances, ballasting the film. Apart from the big wigs, I was unusually aware that somebody made the model ships, that somebody rebuilt Harrison's exquisite clock for the film. And that the standby carpenter, though he came well below the accountants in the credits, must have felt proud to the point of explosion. Let's hear it for the craftsmen.

webTitle: Motorway mayhem 110 vehicles in crash on foggy German autobahn

fields.headline: Motorway mayhem 110 vehicles in crash on foggy German autobahn
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: About 110 vehicles were involved in a crash yesterday on a fog-shrouded motorway in central Germany, killing two people and injuring at least 73 others.
fields.body:
About 110 vehicles were involved in a crash yesterday on a fog-shrouded motorway in central Germany, killing two people and injuring at least 73 others.

Ten of the 20 people who suffered serious injuries were flown by helicopter to nearby hospitals, police said. Another 250 uninjured car passengers were taken by bus to a Red Cross building for assistance.

Authorities said the accident, on the A7 between Fulda and Waurzburg, was caused by drivers going too fast in the fog, which had reduced visibility to 100 yards. After the first vehicles crashed in the northbound lanes - leading to a 50-car pileup - about 60 cars travelling in the other direction became involved in a second pileup as drivers tried to see what was going on, a police spokesman said.

Damage was estimated at at least DM2m (£700,000) and police said it would take hours to separate the wrecks. Traffic was jammed 25 miles in both directions. 'It's a giant pile of scrap,'' a police spokesman said.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText:
Great Estates 12.45pm, Channel 4
Quite why film-makers are so keen to give free PR to Britain's landed nobs is one of TV's eternal mysteries. A subtle plot to hasten the revolution? Whatever, this new series on Britain's stately piles mostly succeeds because it focuses on the staff responsible for maintenance and restoration. Great Estates 12.45pm, Channel 4
Quite why film-makers are so keen to give free PR to Britain's landed nobs is one of TV's eternal mysteries. A subtle plot to hasten the revolution? Whatever, this new series on Britain's stately piles mostly succeeds because it focuses on the staff responsible for maintenance and restoration. This show on Chatsworth also has the bonus of the Duke of Devonshire, an engaging gentleman who comes across like PG Wodehouse's batty Lord Emsworth. But with GCSEs.

The Oldest Tree On Earth: The Curse Of Methuselah
7.30pm, Channel 4
Perhaps it's appropriate, but this documentary devoted to the Methuselah Tree, a shabby bristlecone pine growing on a remote Californian mountain which is the world's oldest living organism at a staggering 4,643 years old, begins slowly. But gradually, with the help of especially commissioned poems from Roger McGough, a narrative tracing humanity's history over the course of the tree's life emerges - a tale that encompasses ancient civilisations, the settlement of America by Europeans and the testing of atom bombs 100 miles away in the Nevada Desert. A gentle film that nonetheless grapples with the issue of our own mortality.

Longitude
8.30pm, Channel 4
The second part of this marvellous adaptation of Dava Sobel's bestseller is, quite simply, unmissable. The story picks up with 18th century clockmaker John Harrison (Michael Gambon) still struggling to design a clock accurate enough to help sailors plot their position at sea. At every turn, he faces opposition from a bigoted scientific establishment who hate the idea of a mere artisan solving the problem. Ambitious and intelligent, this is period drama that never gets hidebound by the distracting eye-candy of costumes and settings. Instead, director Charles Sturridge allows the performances of Gambon, Ian Hart as Harrison's son William and Jeremy Irons as Rupert Gould (who restored Harrison's clocks in the 20th century) to shine through. Mesmerising.

fields.headline: Sir Christopher Harding
fields.standfirst: Trying to make nuclear fuels acceptable again in the post-Chernobyl climate of opinion
fields.trailText: Christopher Harding, who has died aged 60, made a quiet but profound impression on that bleak territory occupied by the nuclear power industry. Charming and diplomatic, he was the first atomic power industrialist to appreciate fully that public acceptance of this controversial industry had to be won.
fields.body:
Christopher Harding, who has died aged 60, made a quiet but profound impression on that bleak territory occupied by the nuclear power industry. Charming and diplomatic, he was the first atomic power industrialist to appreciate fully that public acceptance of this controversial industry had to be won.

He spent much of his business life with ICI, the Hanson Group, and latterly with United Utilities and Legal & General. But it is for his time, 1984-1992, at British Nuclear Fuels, the state-owned nuclear reprocessing giant, that he will be remembered. Without those years, it is inconceivable that BNFL should stumble towards privatisation, under a Labour administration.

A bank manager's son, he was educated at Merchant Taylor's School and read modern history at Corpus Christi College, Oxford. He joined ICI in 1961 and spent eight years as a personnel officer before being headhunted by Lord Hanson to work for and ultimately run the Hanson transport group. He remained a non-executive director of Hanson Trust until 1997.

He joined BNFL as a director in 1984 and became its part-time chairman on April 1 1986, working with Neville Chamberlain, a BNFL veteran, as chief executive. The two replaced Con Allday, who had combined both roles. BNFL had a reputation for poor safety and obsessive secrecy. Crass manoeuvres, like substituting the name Sellafield for Windscale, and numerous safety scares incompetently hidden from the public, had left an indelible impression.

When he and his chief executive took up their posts, a wry commentator pointed out it was symptomatic of the company's PR problems that only BNFL could choose April Fool's day to announce that Neville Chamberlain was replacing a man called Con Allday.

Harding immediately invited Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth to talks about the company's operations. Making the nuclear case was considerably more difficult thereafter, especially after the Chernobyl disaster, which struck weeks into his BNFL tenure. At Sellafield and other sites, he strove to represent the workforce, while preaching the simple doctrine that a successful nuclear company was a safe one.

It was his idea to open the popular Sellafield visitors' centre, lending Britain's most eerie industrial site the feeling of a science theme park. In the London HQ, he talked to endless detractors and doubters, making the case for nuclear power with a disarming earnestness. Meetings were often followed by hand written letters of thanks.

But glasnost opened the door to another set of problems. Openness about safety issues made it inevitable that more detailed answers would be demanded about BNFL's extraordinary finances, dominated by multi-billion pound liabilities for the clean-up of nuclear installations and huge investment in new installations like the Thorp reprocessing plant and, now, the mixed oxide fuel plant.

BNFL found it as hard to make the financial case as it had been to make the safety case. Its reputation for trying to blind its critics with science was replaced with a reputation for blinding them with economics. This was not helped by British nuclear companies portraying BNFL as an unhealthy monopoly.

The first accounts produced after Harding's retirement from BNFL were held up for many months: when finally published, they were stamped with a rare warning from the company's auditors that they could be rendered invalid because the Tory government had removed a pledge to underwrite £17 bn worth of reprocessing contracts. BNFL, like its nuclear cousins, continues to struggle to answer the economic and safety cases, but it does so from a position unrecognisable 10 years ago.

After BNFL, Harding continued to make the case for nuclear power through the pressure group, Supporters Of Nuclear Energy. He chaired the industrial services group BET, but failed to protect it from takeover by Rentokil in 1996. He faced criticism for his characteristic loyalty to the incumbent, but underperforming, management team. In 1997, he was offered the chair of United Utilities, replacing Sir Desmond Pitcher, who lost two chief executives in quick succession and a great deal of investor confidence. Harding brought in a new chief executive and put the business back on an even keel.

From 1994, he was also the chairman of the life insurance company Legal & General, which he helped steer towards a merger with the NatWest, only to be thwarted by a counterbid for NatWest by the Bank of Scotland. Other chairmanships included the Newharthill Group, the private holding company of the construction group, Sir Robert MacAlpine, from 1993, and the GEC remunerations committee.

His public work notably included the Prince's Youth Business Trust, where he chaired the advisory board. He was knighted in 1991.

He had a collection of well over 1,000 egg cups, which moved wherever he worked.

He was married first to Susan Berry, with whom he had a son and a daughter, and then to Francçoise de Laperrière. He found happiness with his third wife, Anne Skelley, whom he married in 1994. They had a daughter.

Sir Christopher George Francis Harding, businessman, born October 17 1939; died December 13 1999

webTitle: Utopia or dystopia? Challenges for our future

fields.headline: Utopia or dystopia? Challenges for our future
fields.standfirst: Predictions of a new international order made only 10 years ago now seem hopelessly optimistic. Guardian writers examine the options for four areas which are likely to shape the 21st century.
fields.trailText: If the new millennium had come a decade earlier, in the first flush of post-cold war enthusiasm, how different the forecasts would have been. Then we were encouraged to look forward to a new international age, free from superpower strife, when efforts would be focused on real problems: poverty, ill-health, injustice and the environment.
fields.byline: John Gittings, Victoria Brittain and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
If the new millennium had come a decade earlier, in the first flush of post-cold war enthusiasm, how different the forecasts would have been. Then we were encouraged to look forward to a new international age, free from superpower strife, when efforts would be focused on real problems: poverty, ill-health, injustice and the environment.

The UN-led war against Saddam Hussein encouraged optimism: the international body, no longer paralysed by the veto, was able to act against aggression. The US and Russia began to roll back their arsenals and the fear of global obliteration receded.

Those forecasts now seem hopelessly utopian. New conflicts have broken out in areas we were hardly aware of; world poverty continues to rise. There are two new nuclear powers. The UN's reputation has been deeply dented by its inadequate response to a string of humanitarian crises. The mood is shifting from utopia to dystopia.

What sort of world are we living in where the perspective can change so fast? Predictions remain difficult but four areas will vitally affect our global future - the prospects for China, Africa, the UN and disarmament.

China

China enters the new millennium as a giant with shaky foundations. Assessments of its prospects from outside continue to be wildly inconsistent. Will it become the world's second economic power within 20 years or be brought down by massive political and social contradictions? Is a strong China good for Asia or a potential threat?

Everyone agrees on one thing: stability in China is crucial for the region and the world - note the huge sigh of relief in 1997-98 when Beijing refrained from devaluing its renminbi currency, and thus saved the Asian economic crisis from becoming a global disaster.

The greatest risk now faced by China, many believe, is that the communist regime will fail to adapt and will meet the same fate as that of the Soviet Union, plunging the country into chaos and risking disintegration. Certainly the current leadership of Jiang Zemin has disappointed by maintaining the brake on political reform. Somehow the momentum checked by the 1989 Beijing massacre has to resume. Yet the comparison with the Soviet Union is inexact. China's version of perestroika, unlike that of Mikhail Gorbachev, will continue to deliver enough goods to enough people to buy acquiescence.

The politically alienated of 1989 are already returning to make money. More will come back when Beijing joins the World Trade Organisation. Patriotism is not a discredited concept, and a sense of common identity - far stronger than the artificial Soviet version - will endure, reinforced by the overseas Chinese community. The party is not loved, but neither is it hated; instead it is seen as an apparatus of government which in one form or another China needs. Popular protest at corruption and privilege focuses on specific complaints, without demanding the party's overthrow.

But China will pay an increasingly high environmental price for the policy of maximising the growth which buys it stability. In the long run, pouring concrete over fertile land is a recipe for disaster. Mounting floods and diminishing naturalresources will hit particularly hard those in poor areas who have already missed out on the economic boom.

By the year 2050, a population well above 1.5bn people will face severe water and land shortages, heightened by a growing concentration in urban areas near the coast. Pollution could rise by 600%, with hidden costs to health and productivity. Cities will fail to provide adequate services for the rural migrants on whom they depend, and whose numbers should reach 220m within 10 years.

The police and security forces will be strengthened to deal with rising crime. As in Indonesia, an underclass of the under-employed will provide a reservoir of social unrest.

China's complete entry into the world market will remove the last barriers which have cushioned its economy: the renminbi will fluctuate and export industries will become increasingly vulnerable to competition from other developing labour forces. Beijing's nightmare scenario - a surge of domestic unrest coinciding with a western economic slump - will one day become reality.

China will pour resources into defence and prestige projects to achieve the aim of becoming `the giant of Asia'' by the year 2050, leading to recurrent tensions with Japan and an unstable Russia.

The love-hate relationship with the US will be tested to destruction over Taiwan: sooner or later (probably sooner) Beijing will be tempted, or obliged for internal political reasons, to make a challenge across the strait. Repression of alleged `splittism'' in the non-Han Chinese western regions will provoke what it seeks to prevent: the challenge will come first from Muslim militants in Xinjiang, then from Tibetan activists after the death of the Dalai Lama.

Slowly new generations will realise that the only solution to these problems is to reject the concepts of centralised rule based on the Chinese empire.

Africa

Will Africa be the forgotten orphan of the 21st century? It limped out of the 20th with little more prestige or autonomy than it had at the beginning of it, when most of its states were ruled by European colonialism. It will not be in a position to reverse this powerlessness alone, and it will be in the rest of the world's urgent self-interest to offer massive financial and technical aid. This will be the only way to stem Africa's contribution to the growing problems of global warming, the spread of the Aids pandemic and unrest in Europe as the angry poor outnumber the rich with the influx of men fleeing economic and political insecurity in Africa.

The speed of technological change in the 21st century, and the world's domination by a knowledge-based economy will be a threat, rather than an opportunity, for the continent. Inevitably this trend will further marginalise Africa.

On present trends, in 15 years three-quarters of all the world's school-age children who are not able to go to school will live in Africa. The yawning education gap will prevent the continent moving towards more democratic and accountable government. Instead it will still be prone to see its people swept easily into the primitive fascist movements which have managed in the late 20th century to destroy country after country in west and central Africa in civil wars.

These wars for resources, easily fired by ethnicity, by extensive drug abuse and by the use of impressionable children as cannon fodder could simply spiral on from one generation to another with no political force capable of redrawing the map of these countries' alternative possibilities.

One new force of the century will be the increasingly powerful non-governmental organisations (NGOs). The erosion of national sovereignty in the face of the western human rights lobbies was one of the more remarkable phenomena of the last two decades of the 20th century. In the 21st it will be not only the confident and ambitious NGOs which dictate policies to African governments, but the multinationals who will be obliged by their shareholders to answer publicly for every policy or financial transaction in the countries where they operate.

United Nations

An effective UN will be crucial for the 21st century, as nation states show no signs of being able to regulate disputes peacefully and ethnic conflict is on the increase.

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, has been publicly criticised in an independent report for his role in the UN's failure to prevent genocide in Rwanda in 1994. This report came hard on the heels of Nato taking the lead in the Kosovo war; on the long stalemate on Iraq which reduced its people to abject poverty; and on the failure of UN-supervised elections and years of fruitless negotiations in Angola.

Meanwhile the US continues to hobble the organisation by failing to pay its dues in full while demanding the right to approve all significant UN initiatives.

Yet expectations of the UN are higher than ever, while international law is changing to give it a wider mandate. As environmental and man-made catastrophes multiply, UN agencies will be asked to perform miracles to bring food and medicine to millions of victims.

The UN's future will depend on how soon these new pressures lead to structural change. These must include the long postponed enlargement of the security council, more democratic decision-making, more secure funding for specialised agencies and the formation of permanent peacekeeping forces. The prospect of any of this happening may seem unlikely now. But international disaster in the 21st century will concentrate minds and promote a new demand for international solutions.

Disarmament

The world will face new types of conflict which national governments and even established groupings like the EU are still not prepared for, despite their rhetoric.

The threat of further proliferation will put the prospects for nuclear peace throughout this century to a severe test. A new arms race will also start if the Nato allies fail to dissuade the US from plans for a national anti-ballistic missile shield. President Bill Clinton is expected to give the go-ahead to this expensive `Son of Star Wars', which is enthusiastically backed by the Republican candidate George Bush. The Democratic front-runner, Al Gore. may have to support it reluctantly.

The strong security element in the Russian leadership - enhanced by the rise of Vladimir Putin - increases the danger of conflict between a revanchist Moscow and the US, with a side-current of discord between the Nato powers over how far Russia has legitimate security concerns.

The Europeans believe that the US wants a series of `regional anti-missile shields'', one to protect Israel, another for Taiwan and Japan. The plan is also directed at China, provoking Beijing's military to a new arms race. Moscow has also reacted angrily to US proposals to amend the 1972 anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty and is deploying more advanced missiles. European concerns are deepened by the US senate's refusal last year to ratify the comprehensive test ban treaty.

Prospects for the non-proliferation treaty review conference, to be held in New York in April, do not look good. The five official nuclear weapons states are not giving a lead. Indeed, the US is developing new warheads for its Trident system, on which Britain relies.

Instead of constructing nuclear shields, western strategy will have to find new ways of bringing `pariah states'' into the international community.

As the environment deteriorates, new sources of conflict will also emerge over scarce resources such as water.

The next one or two decades will be make or break time for the choice. We can either continue down the road of nuclear proliferation, with ever smaller weapons, plus chemical and biological weapons, which can also be used by terrorists. Or the nuclear five must take a new road to convince the world that they are serious about disarmament.

fields.headline: Apartheid victims reject handouts
fields.standfirst: Government offers tiny reparations for unjust jail Apartheid victims push for adequate reparation
fields.trailText: Duma Khumalo was hours away from the gallows when a judge stayed his execution. Yet he and the other anti-apartheid activists known as the Sharpeville Six still served seven years in prison for a murder not even the prosecution said they committed.
fields.body:
Duma Khumalo was hours away from the gallows when a judge stayed his execution. Yet he and the other anti-apartheid activists known as the Sharpeville Six still served seven years in prison for a murder not even the prosecution said they committed.

Mr Khumalo is free now, but like many of those jailed, persecuted or tortured under South Africa's white regimes, he believes he is owed due compensation.

The country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission agrees: It recommended that the government pay substantial reparations to the most abused of apartheid's surviving victims, and to the partners and orphans of the dead, to help them rebuild their lives. But now President Thabo Mbeki's administration has angered many who suffered while struggling for liberation by saying it cannot afford more than token payments.

Mr Khumalo says the state owes it to his children to provide the education for which he could not pay while he was imprisoned.

`I'm not saying the government should make me rich, but I don't want to see my children victimised because of what happened to me,' he said. `When I was arrested, my son, Lucky, was five. It affected him very badly. There is a bitterness between me and Lucky. I keep on making promises to him, but I fail because I don't have the money to send him to school and so he is causing trouble on the streets. I want to pay him back because he suffered because I was in prison.'

The Sharpeville Six were sentenced to hang in 1984 for murdering a town councillor, stoned to death during a township demonstration. There was no evidence that Mr Khumalo or his co-accused participated in the killing, but they were convicted according to a now disgraced law, which held that anyone joining a protest was responsible for the actions of the others in the crowd.

The six were released in 1991 after the then president, F W de Klerk, began dismantling apartheid. But Mr Khumalo and his fellow prisoners have not been able to find regular work, and they remain stigmatised by their time in jail.

In 1998, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission recommended that 22,000 people receive compensation of up to £15,000 each to help them buy homes, to educate their children and to pay for medical care. But the government has decided that the victims will receive a few hundred pounds. So far, 8,000 people have received `interim' payments of 2,000 rand (£200).

`Two thousand rand won't do anything,' said Mr Khumalo. `There are children who lost parents and that won't get them an education. There are people in wheelchairs - 2,000 rand won't pay their medical bills.

`If the aim of the present government is to restore dignity for an injustice done to us, they ought to discuss this with us - not dictate terms like imposing the 2,000 rand.'

Just two years ago, the ruling African National Congress (ANC) argued that substantial compensation was crucial.

`Unless there are meaningful reparations, the process of ensuring justice and reconciliation will be flawed,' it said in a submission to the truth commission. Last year, however, senior officials and ministers began backing away from this position.

There is considerable bitterness among the victims about the amnesty that was granted to many of apartheid's human rights abusers: Not only are the abusers now immune from criminal prosecution, they also cannot be sued for civil damages.

Last month, the former apartheid law and order minister, Adriaan Vlok, who oversaw a police force that murdered and tortured with virtual impunity, was granted amnesty for his part in the bombing of the offices of South Africa's trade union confederation.

`We have been betrayed,' Mr Khumalo said. `The previous government gave Vlok and the killers golden handshakes and the present government gave them amnesty. [But] the victims have been left empty handed.'

webTitle: Hijackers' vanishing act stokes Indian suspicions

fields.headline: Hijackers' vanishing act stokes Indian suspicions
fields.standfirst:
Masked men presumed to have headed to Pakistan
More about the Indian Ailines hijacking
fields.trailText: Two days after they waved goodbye to their terrified captives aboard a hijacked airliner and drove off into an Afghan sunset, there was no trace yesterday of the five Islamist gunmen who for a week held more than 155 people - and the government of India - to ransom.
fields.body:
Two days after they waved goodbye to their terrified captives aboard a hijacked airliner and drove off into an Afghan sunset, there was no trace yesterday of the five Islamist gunmen who for a week held more than 155 people - and the government of India - to ransom.

The authorities in both Afghanistan and Pakistan say they have no knowledge of the whereabouts of the hijackers, who owe their allegiance to the Harkat-ul-Mojahedin, an Islamist organisation fighting New Delhi's rule over Kashmir.

However, the Indian foreign minister, Jaswant Singh, told reporters on Saturday that the five masked men - whom he did not identify, although he said they were Pakistanis - had left the southern Afghan city of Kandahar together with the three men whose release they won from Indian jails.

Mr Singh was quoting the Taliban authorities in Afghanistan, who brokered the deal that ended the hijacking drama on their soil. On Friday, the Taliban gave the hijackers 10 hours to leave the country. A few hours later, the Taliban announced that the men had disappeared, and that the Afghan hostage who was guiding them to the border had returned to Kandahar.

With the Pakistani border city of Chaman just a three-hour drive from Kandahar, the obvious conclusion is that the gunmen drove straight to the frontier. However, there was no way of knowing whether the five were travelling with the men whose release they engineered: a Pakistani-born preacher; a Briton, jailed in India for the 1994 kidnapping of western tourists; and a militant leader from the Indian-held part of Kashmir. Despite all spending several years in Indian jails, none of the three has been convicted of a crime.

If the hijackers eventually turn up in Pakistan, it may prove uncomfortable for Islamabad, which has claimed on several occasions that India was unfairly seeking to implicate its intelligence agencies in the crisis. It would also be a propaganda coup for India, which has made the war on global terrorism a tenet of its foreign policy in recent months.

But Islamabad is determined that this will not happen. Within hours of Mr Singh's statement that the hijackers were Pakistani, Islamabad retaliated with a denial: 'Levelling of baseless and false accusations against Pakistan is part ... of Indian tactics,' a foreign ministry spokesman said.

Pakistani authorities insist that the hijackers will find no refuge there. 'Under no circumstances will these persons be allowed to enter Pakistan,' Moinudeen Haider, the interior minister, told the official Associated Press of Pakistan. 'Pakistan is on high alert. In case they enter Pakistan territory they will be apprehended and tried as per established international rules and conventions to which Pakistan is signatory.'

However, that is almost impossible to guarantee. The borderlands between Pakistan and Afghanistan are mainly untamed mountain and desert, and much of the terrain is in federally administered tribal areas, where Pakistan's legal writ does not run.

Afghans and Pakistanis do not need passports or visas to cross the border, and with border posts often left unmanned, it is often possible for even western travellers to slip across unnoticed.

The hijackers have a crucial advantage: they kept their balaclavas on throughout the eight-day ordeal, and the Indian authorities have yet to identify them.

As for their three guests, Pakistan would presumably have no objections to their presence on its soil, and they would probably receive a heroes' welcome in Pakistani Kashmir.
