fields.headline: A life taken undiluted
fields.standfirst: With a gallery of eccentrics to his name and a face etched with melancholy, John Hurt is a natural Beckett actor. But, he tells Claire Armitstead, it hasn't all been doom and gloom
fields.trailText: It's the voice that arrives first: it doesn't so much waft as cascade down the corridor - a juicy, actor's voice, enjoying its own resonance among the hushed tones of pre-lunch drinks at a sombre London club. Then, there he is, in a sharp navy suit and shiny lavender tie. He is instantly recognisable except for one detail: it's as if someone has ironed his face.
fields.body:
It's the voice that arrives first: it doesn't so much waft as cascade down the corridor - a juicy, actor's voice, enjoying its own resonance among the hushed tones of pre-lunch drinks at a sombre London club. Then, there he is, in a sharp navy suit and shiny lavender tie. He is instantly recognisable except for one detail: it's as if someone has ironed his face.

Ever since the mid-70s, when John Hurt emerged from the classical theatre into the cathode glare of television, his parchment features have seemed to hold all of life's disappointments, all its bad mornings-after-worse-nights-before, in its creases and folds.

Reviews of Krapp's Last Tape, the Samuel Beckett monodrama which brings him back to London this month, give no reason to expect any different. 'What makes Hurt a natural for this role,' wrote one critic, 'is that he possesses a face full of wrecked Rembrandtesque fascination, suggesting acres of pained and mysterious hinterland, and a voice that has an extraordinarily kippered lived-in intimacy.' Another critic suggested that, with his seamed, pouchy features and shock of close-cut, iron-grey hair, he bore a striking resemblance to Samuel Beckett himself.

Hurt himself has said that 'what I am now, the man, the actor, is a blend of all that has happened'. Yet today his face looks ironed smooth of past troubles, and there are three possible explanations. One is that he is happy, and his new-found domestic stability - in Ireland, with a woman 20 years his junior - has combined with a new-found sobriety to smooth his features. Another possibility is that he is thriving on being back at centre-stage again. 'When you've been away from an audience as long as I have - and it's four years since I was last on stage, in A Month in the Country - you do begin to miss an audience.'

A third possibility, offered by Hurt, is that he doesn't buy the view of Beckett as an old miserabilist. And since part of being an actor is selling what you're doing, John Hurt is selling good humour. 'He had to put up with so many misperceptions, poor old Sam. He's got this reputation for being gloomy but he's actually not at all,' he says. When pressed, he concedes that Krapp is a moving play - 'not just touching but seriously moving; it's a whole life; it's everything. The point about Beckett is that his writing is so good that there is only one way to do it. He seems to distil it and distil it until he's got only the finest alcohol left.'

In what depths of his own experience does Hurt find a performance that has been described as invaded by pain? 'Heaven knows where it comes from. It wouldn't have occurred to me that I could do it, but then I don't think actors are very good at choosing their own parts,' he says.

I had expected him to be tetchy about personal questions but he only looks awkward when he is asked about acting. 'I dread these questions. You see, you can't talk about it. It's an imaginative leap in the end, not an intellectual leap.' Twenty years ago, when he'd just appeared in Alien, in which his stomach had ripped open to produce a monster, an American reporter asked if he was a method actor. Hurt tore open his shirt to reveal an appendicitis scar, and snarled: 'Listen, if Robert De Niro can put on a few pounds...'

Actually, he says, 'Though I've been quoted as saying I don't like method acting, what I don't like is when acting becomes therapy. I find that troublesome.' As he says it, he gives a glimpse of the quiet fretfulness that infused his portrayal of the lonely writer Giles De'Ath in his recent film, Love and Death on Long Island. Besotted with a Hollywood teen idol, and besieged by technology, his features seemed to play obsession like a piano: now tragic, now absurd, now magnificently selfish. He can pack a whole emotional universe into the twitch of an eyebrow, a sardonic slackening of the mouth.

It is a performance so compelling, so 'real' that I find myself wondering whether Hurt is obsessive; whether, unlike De'Ath, he can handle a video or a fax machine. This is the irony that has dogged Hurt's career: he is not the sort of heroic actor who annexes roles to his own overwhelming personality. Rather, he is a character actor - 'not,' he says, 'in the American sense of someone who is always the same, but in the English sense of someone who plays characters.'

Yet there has been a common thread through three decades of work and 90-odd films - a sense of melancholy, of waste, of self-loathing. It's there in Stephen Ward, the Profumo fall guy of Scandal; it was there in the junkie convict of Midnight Express, in the effete Caligula of I, Claudius and - perhaps most memorably - in The Naked Civil Servant, his TV film based on the autobiography of Quentin Crisp. However accomplished, however technically composed these performances have been, people have always looked for clues to them in his life. He finds this irritating .('I've had people say they had me in mind when they wrote something, and I've always said, 'Which bit of me?'').

Yet he has displayed a clumsy genius for allowing his life to hold a mirror up to his art. He has admitted that, while shooting Midnight Express (1978), he got through up to seven bottles of wine a day. After White Mischief (1987), a film about dissolute Kenyan settlers, he and his second wife, Donna, built themselves a mansion in the Kenyan hills and had public spats about his drinking. More troublingly, in the run-up to Champions (1983) - a biopic about the jockey Bob Champion - his long-term partner Marie-Lise was killed in a riding accident. In talking openly and honestly about her death, he allowed it to become a film-marketing dream. Wisely, perhaps, his two young children from his third marriage, which broke down in the mid-90s, have been declared a no-talk zone. He is clearly terrified of endangering his relationship with them.

Hurt is as candid as ever about himself, though: 'I suppose I had a reputation as a hellraiser,' he says, 'but it's very odd because I never really was. It's just that I lived very publicly and never pretended to be private. I've always lived in the streets. I still walk everywhere and, of course, I've been drunk like most people have, but I just got unlucky, like I did at school. If ever I did anything wrong, I always got caught.'

The trouble began at a prep school in Kent, where Hurt - son of a strict Anglican vicar - was regularly beaten. It followed him into his 20s, when he found himself trapped in a shotgun marriage to an actress who said she was pregnant. The baby didn't materialise and the marriage didn't last. 'Sometimes,' he says, 'life is very difficult to take undiluted.'

Then he grins at the Beckettian seriousness of the statement, and becomes gleeful in his reminiscences. 'Oh I've been set up many times - like that famous punch-up after the Bafta ceremony. Really it was a non-incident. I was in the back of the hotel talking with some friends and the photographers wouldn't go away. One of them was being particularly cheeky and I said, 'Enough is enough,' took a swing at him and missed. The next day there it was across the world: 'Bafta Biffa'. Well, quite honestly, I don't give a toss what people think in that sense.'

His refusal to play safe has had its benefits - not least the role he regards as one of his most extraordinary: The Naked Civil Servant. He was given dire warnings by his professional minders. 'They essentially said if you play an effeminate exhibitionist homosexual, you'll never work again... But I didn't have any qualms because I didn't think that was what it was about.'

The most backhanded tribute came from Quentin Crisp, with whom Hurt remained friends until his death last year. 'I told Mr Hurt it was difficult for actors to play victims, but he has specialised in victims,' wrote Crisp. 'When he stopped playing me, he played Caligula, which was only me in a sheet. Then he played The Elephant Man, which was only me with a paper bag over my head.'

Although The Naked Civil Servant is now regarded as a classic, at the time it was greeted with some ambivalence - as was The Elephant Man, in which, entombed in a mask made of 27 moving parts, he laid bare the torment of the horribly disfigured John Merrick. It's a source of some resentment for him that Love and Death on Long Island did not garner the honours of those earlier films. 'I'm not bitter about it but I just don't understand it. It got the most incredible reviews of any film I've ever made. If a film had had that reaction 15 years ago, everything would have been very different. It does make one wonder where we are when, because of the film distribution system, because of who's in control, because we're dictated to by market research, we can't educate our own country in its own culture.'

If that makes Hurt sound like outdated Giles De'Ath, he rattles happily around the countryside, near Dublin, with 'the girlfriend' - music PR Sara Owens - and a cosmopolitan gang of modern singers, chefs and pop managers. And he hopes to mark his 60th birthday this month by making his film directing debut. 'I've resisted, but friends seem to feel very strongly that I should.' You can see why he would make a good director. He is happier talking angles and takes than the more abstract ideas of an actor's vision, and he can be gloriously rude about directors he has worked with. One reason why he loves Beckett, he says, is because the writing is so precise that there really is only one way to do it. 'That, you see, isn't a restriction, it is freedom.'

The photographer arrives and he produces a broad, smooth smile for the camera. Then a doubt puckers his face: 'How's the neck? Like a turtle, I expect,' he deadpans. It's a perfect moment - Quentin Crisp scripted by Samuel Beckett. Those old friends, the creases, are back.

Krapp's Last Tape is at the New Ambassadors, London (0171-836 6111), from January 25 to March 11.

The most backhanded tribute came from Quentin Crisp, with whom Hurt remained friends until his death last year. 'I told Mr Hurt it was difficult for actors to play victims, but he has specialised in victims,' wrote Crisp. 'When he stopped playing me, he played Caligula, which was only me in a sheet. Then he played The Elephant Man, which was only me with a paper bag over my head.' Although The Naked Civil Servant is now regarded as a classic, at the time it was greeted with some ambivalence - as was The Elephant Man, in which, entombed in a mask made of 27 moving parts, he laid bare the torment of the horribly disfigured John Merrick. It's a source of some resentment for him that Love and Death on Long Island did not garner the honours of those earlier films. 'I'm not bitter about it but I just don't understand it. It got the most incredible reviews of any film I've ever made. If a film had had that reaction 15 years ago, everything would have been very different. It does make one wonder where we are when, because of the film distribution system, because of who's in control, because we're dictated to by market research, we can't educate our own country in its own culture.' If that makes Hurt sound like outdated Giles De'Ath, he rattles happily around the countryside, near Dublin, with 'the girlfriend' - music PR Sara Owens - and a cosmopolitan gang of modern singers, chefs and pop managers. And he hopes to mark his 60th birthday this month by making his film directing debut. 'I've resisted, but friends seem to feel very strongly that I should.' You can see why he would make a good director. He is happier talking angles and takes than the more abstract ideas of an actor's vision, and he can be gloriously rude about directors he has worked with. One reason why he loves Beckett, he says, is because the writing is so precise that there really is only one way to do it. 'That, you see, isn't a restriction, it is freedom.' The photographer arrives and he produces a broad, smooth smile for the camera. Then a doubt puckers his face: 'How's the neck? Like a turtle, I expect,' he deadpans. It's a perfect moment - Quentin Crisp scripted by Samuel Beckett. Those old friends, the creases, are back. Krapp's Last Tape is at the New Ambassadors, London (0171-836 6111), from January 25 to March 11.

fields.headline: The best ways to leave your lover
fields.trailText: Need to get rid of your lover? Best refer to popular music, but exercise caution. Soul is too loving here; and in the whole of country music no woman has ever knowingly left a man. Dance and trance and all that are for wimps. You have to be tough. What you need here is the lady blues artistes:
fields.body:
Need to get rid of your lover? Best refer to popular music, but exercise caution. Soul is too loving here; and in the whole of country music no woman has ever knowingly left a man. Dance and trance and all that are for wimps. You have to be tough. What you need here is the lady blues artistes:

Wash that man right out of your hair: Greet his every phone call for a week with, 'I'd love to but I have to wash my hair', or accuse him of introducing headlice into your home. He will soon begin to feel unloved.

Leave a note on the pillow, and your old wedding ring, with these few words of farewell: 'Goodbye, Old Sleepyhead, I'm packing you in, like I said - Don't look for me, I'll get ahead; remember darling, don't smoke in bed.' It worked on Nina Simone, so it'll surely work on lesser mortals.

Tell them... There ain't nothing going on but the rent. No one likes a gold-digger.

Jump up... on the kitchen worktop and stomp along it demanding that they Think (Think!) Think about what they're trying to do to you. If you remember any more of the words you're a better person than any of us, except Aretha Franklin.

Follow Etta James's advice... and Tell Mama. Mama probably never liked them anyway.

If things have become very complicated, sooner or later you will just have to face the music. Go on - just go and tell his wife: 'Your husband is cheating on us.'' Otherwise, well, I hate to be obvious but you could always:

Hop on the bus, Gus: There are some excellent long-distance coach travel deals around at this time of year.

Drop off the key, Lee: Though this mightn't be clear in itself, as many couples do drop off keys in the normal course of domestic life. But combined with 'It's not you, it's me', 'I just need my own space' and the classic 'I've really enjoyed our time together', it may well work. Plus, by then they'll hate you anyway for coming out with such obnoxious cliches, and leave you. If none of the above works, you'll just have to make a new plan, Stan.

fields.headline: Union seeks Kitemark for partnerships
fields.standfirst: BSI - the Kitemark explained
fields.trailText: Sir Ken Jackson, leader of the Amalgamated Electrical and Engineering Union, is urging the government to adopt an independent Kitemark of approval for partnership agreements between companies and unions.
fields.body:
Sir Ken Jackson, leader of the Amalgamated Electrical and Engineering Union, is urging the government to adopt an independent Kitemark of approval for partnership agreements between companies and unions.

While rejecting rivals' claims that a spate of such agreements between the AEEU and employers are little more than "sweetheart" or no-strike deals, Sir Ken admitted yesterday that some amounted to rudimentary recognition agreements.

He wants Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, to approve a new scheme for rewarding genuine partnerships.

Drawn on the Investors in People Kitemark given to training programmes, it would be called Investors in Partnership. The government is setting up a £5m fund to encourage partnership agreements.

Partnership deals, in which management and unions commit themselves to common objectives, including a non-confrontational approach to disputes, have riven the TUC in recent years. The AEEU has been accused of using them to poach other unions' members.

Sir Ken, who insists his "third way" approach is better suited in an era of globalisation to providing lasting employment, said a union priority in the coming years must be to help build successful companies in Britain.

"Partnership is not a one-off project. It's a change of culture for unions as well as employers," he said. "We don't need counterfeit partnerships that look real but are basic recognition agreements when you scratch the surface.

"If we are to make partnership a truly radical and lasting change for the better, an independent Kitemark system would be a real boost."

fields.headline: Europeans press for £1bn missiles
fields.trailText: European leaders are pressing the government to opt for a high-powered £1bn missile designed in Europe to arm its fleet of Eurofighters rather than a US alternative supposedly incapable of meeting a new Russo-Chinese threat.
fields.body:
European leaders are pressing the government to opt for a high-powered £1bn missile designed in Europe to arm its fleet of Eurofighters rather than a US alternative supposedly incapable of meeting a new Russo-Chinese threat.

President Jacques Chirac of France and other leaders have intervened with Tony Blair and Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, in favour of the Ramjet-powered Meteor missile and urged them to reject a cheaper version offered by Raytheon, the US defence concern.

The choice of missile for Eurofighter, the Tornado-replacement being built in Britain, Germany, Italy and Spain, is seen as a key test for the government's commitment to supporting a pan-European defence industry and breaking America's supremacy in missiles and other defence weapons systems.

A key ministry of defence committee was due to make a recommendation to the cabinet on the choice of missile for Britain's 232 Eurofighters shortly before Christmas. But, in evidence of the far reaching import of the decision, it deferred its choice until February 21.

Alan Garwood, deputy chief executive of Matra Bae Dynamics, the Franco-British missile-maker, said the Russians were in talks with the Chinese to develop a Ramjet version of the AA-12 Adder missile built by Vympel.

He warned that the Russian missile, due to enter service in 2005, would be more deadly than anything available to European and US armed forces and could end up in the arsenal of countries such as Iraq and Pakistan.

The European consortium developing Meteor, including Matra Bae Dynamics, has made an unprecedented offer to deliver the missile to budget and on time - or the government would get its money back. It could enter service in 2008.

fields.headline: Telecoms hostilities heighten
fields.standfirst: Bid target seeks more time
fields.trailText: Mannesmann, the German telecommunications group fending off a hostile bid from Vodafone-AirTouch, has asked regulators for more time to produce its defence document.
fields.body:
Mannesmann, the German telecommunications group fending off a hostile bid from Vodafone-AirTouch, has asked regulators for more time to produce its defence document.

Advisers to the company have applied to the German takeover commission for an extension to this Friday's deadline because of the bid falling over the holiday season. The clock was set ticking after Vodafone launched its £85bn offer document on Christmas Eve.

Vodafone has cut short the usual 60 days for shareholders to declare their hand to 46 days from publication of the offer document, making the cut-off point February 7.

Mannesmann still hopes to publish its defence in the first half of January.

Despite attempts by Vodafone's chief executive, Chris Gent, to play down the hostile nature of the largest bid in corporate history, the battle is becoming increasingly acrimonious. Mannesmann yesterday took full-page advertisements in the British national press which suggested acquisition would have a "profoundly negative" effect on the German company.

The defence document is expected to focus on Mannesmann's growth prospects as an independent company. Mannesmann chief executive Klauss Esser argues that earnings will increase by 50% next year.

Last week, Mr Esser wrote an open letter to shareholders which was published in German newspapers. He accused Vodafone of withholding information related to the risks associated with the bid.

Vodafone has published its offer document in English and German but the 440-page listing prospectus for new shares, which includes a five page section on potential risk, is not yet available in German.

Possible problems highlighted include the adverse effect of minority shareholders in Mannesmann if its bid succeeds. Debt would be "substantially" increased, which might harm its credit rating, while earnings per share would suffer "substantial dilution".

In the letter Mr Esser said: "Vodafone's offer involves a number of significant risks for any Mannesmann shareholder who accepts it. Do not be misled. In the English-language prospectus for its new shares Vodafone admits there are grave risks involved. Remarkably, Vodafone has not published a German version of this very important document. Form your own opinion as to why Vodafone is withholding the presentation of these risks from you."

Vodafone said it was "totally wrong" to suggest it was withholding information. A spokesman said the warnings were simply standard information and the German version would soon be available.

Vodafone approached Mannesmann to cement their relationship through an asset swap in April but went on the offensive after Mannesmann launched a bid for the British firm's domestic rival Orange. If the Vodafone bid is successful it intends to relist Orange on the stock market.

The bid could drag on until the middle of 2000 because German law states that no single shareholder can vote more than 5%.

Vodafone might not be able to remove Mannesmann management until the law is rescinded in June.

fields.headline: Ken Sampsey
fields.standfirst: A big man of the miners' strike
fields.trailText: Ken Sampey, who has died aged 77, was a principal figure in the miners' strike of 1984-85, which is now coming to be viewed as the last epic protest made by the old working class.
fields.body:
Ken Sampey, who has died aged 77, was a principal figure in the miners' strike of 1984-85, which is now coming to be viewed as the last epic protest made by the old working class. As president of Nacods (the national association of colliery overmen, deputies and shotfirers) from 1980 until his retirement in late 1985, Sampey was involved in virtually every step of the year-long miners' dispute, from its beginning with the closure of the Cortonwood pit in 1984. Along with the general secretary of Nacods, Peter McNestry, he led a key section of the mining industry, albeit with a mere 16,000 members at the time; the role of Nacods as 'pit foremen' was crucial to the conduct of that bitter, desperate and historic dispute.

It was Sampey who initiated a compromise that might have settled the strike halfway through and, with hindsight, might perhaps have rescued some rump of an industry that had once been the basis of Britain's vast industrial power.

Nacods did not join the national union of mineworkers' strike at the outset, though Sampey felt strong sympathy with the NUM protest and was fiercely critical of the way Sir Ian MacGregor ran the coal board. Many Nacods men refused to cross NUM picket lines; even in the Notts coalfield, where the NUM breakaway refused to strike, Nacods members were uneasy.

So Sampey put forward his compromise to Sir Pat Lowry, then chairman of Acas. Its main feature was a new and final stage in the review procedure for all pit closures, including those already listed by the coal board. The new independent review body would take evidence from everyone, including local communities. It was an enterprising initiative and came close to succeeding.

Sampey and McNestry felt that the chance of peace lay in their hands and, to force the issue, Nacods leaders decided to join the NUM strike from October 25 1984. They were convinced that neither Mrs Thatcher's government nor MacGregor actually wanted a compromise deal, but were concerned mainly to crush the NUM. The Nacods decision rocked the Conservative cabinet.
This was the moment when a compromise deal could have been made. The TUC leaders thought so. So did Acas. Mrs Thatcher's cabinet was split and Sir Ian MacGregor was fearful. But Arthur Scargill and the NUM turned away from Sampey's peace plan, and Nacods leaders then decided to settle separately and call off their strike threat, much to the anguish of the TUC and the Labour Party leader, Neil Kinnock, who believed a compromise deal was within reach.
Even then Sampey personally tried to persuade MacGregor to meet Scargill in one more 'final' bid to salvage something. But it came to nothing.

Sampey came from a long line of miners, and was born in the old mining village of Edlington, which was the home of the now defunct Yorkshire main colliery on the outskirts of Doncaster. He worked in the pit, at the coal face, as had his father before him. For although he was educated at Maltby Grammar School, his family couldn't afford to support him in further education, so he went down the pit at 16.

When the second world war broke out, he volunteered for the RAF and became a navigator with coastal and bomber command. After the war, he trained as a pit deputy, returned to Yorkshire main colliery and became deeply involved in trade union and local politics.

He was soon a member of the Nacods Yorkshire area executive and, shortly afterwards, of the union's national executive. In the early 50s Sampey was elected to Doncaster town council, before being elected to the newly formed South Yorkshire county council in 1974. He later became deputy leader of the county council, during the period when Sir Ron Ironmonger led it.

One of Sampey's proudest claims was that his local government work enabled him to help a young blind boy from Sheffield, who was interested in local politics. With Sampey's help, the youngster climbed the local educational ladder and went on to some remarkable achievements. The boy's name? David Blunkett.

Sampey was awarded the BEM in 1976. He is survived by his wife Joan, two daughters and three sons.

fields.headline: Change your work
fields.trailText:
Get thee to a nunnery

A letter from a friend set Christine Norden on the path to joining a convent
fields.body:
Get thee to a nunnery

A letter from a friend set Christine Norden on the path to joining a convent

'People often ask me, how did you know? And I always say, when something is right, God makes you know.' A stone's throw from the noise and bustle of London's Marble Arch, 40-year-old Mother Aelred, Adorer of the Sacred Heart, is contemplating the idea of 'becoming' a nun. 'People have these ideas of what a nun is like, and one of the reasons my friends were so shocked at what I was doing was that I didn't seem like their idea of a nun. Some people think a nun is someone who can't cope with life; others that you've been hurt in love or had some terrible trauma. I know some of my friends thought something must have been going on in my life that they didn't know about.'

Her home, Tyburn Convent, stands near the site where the Catholic martyrs of the Reformation died on the gallows. But Mother Aelred, then Christine Norden, had never heard of Tyburn when, 12 years ago, she went to visit the London convent's sister house on the outskirts of Sydney in her native Australia.

Originally Anglican, at 22 she had converted to Catholicism, scandalising her parents. Now she was about to scandalise them further, by entering a silent and enclosed order of Benedictine nuns. 'It didn't seem right for me at all - I love talking, and I really enjoyed the outdoor life,' she says. 'I'd been to university and done a degree, I'd worked as a personnel officer and I could have carved out a good career for myself. But there was something missing.'

Mother Aelred says that as she grew older she realised that, whatever she did with her life, it would have to be done wholeheartedly: 'I knew I'd want to give myself totally to it. And I couldn't find a man, or a career, or anything else that I felt was enough to give myself to totally. Until the convent, and that fateful day.

'The only way I could do anything totally was to do it for God. For a while, I thought I'd probably become a missionary or join an active religious order. But then a friend wrote and asked me if I'd considered joining this convent in Sydney which had some connection to a convent in London. And while I was thinking about it, by chance, I read an article in a magazine about the Adorers of the Sacred Heart - it was very strange!'

The moment she set foot in the chapel of the Sydney convent, Mother Aelred knew it was right for her. 'I could see the sisters across the chapel praying, and I knew this was the life I yearned for, what God was calling me to do,' she says. 'I went to see the prioress and said that if I'd had no commitments I'd join them. And she said, do you mean that? Because if you want to, you can.

'I couldn't believe it could be so simple - that I really could take this step. But knowing it could happen didn't deter me at all - I wasn't scared; I was absolutely certain this was the right thing.' Despite the protestations of her family and friends she decided against sitting the final exams in the nursing course she had been taking.

'They thought that if the convent didn't work out, I'd at least have finished the course - but I didn't need that kind of insurance policy, I knew it would work out,' she says. Four weeks after her first visit, having sold her car and given all her possessions away to friends, Christine was back on the convent doorstep. She left behind a deeply hurt mother and an angry father, but she has since been reconciled with her parents. And her friends were just incredulous.

'The reaction of the friends I told was interesting: they basically divided into two camps. The first were so amazed they never mentioned it again, and the other group were fascinated and they just asked me questions all the time. But most of them thought, give her a fortnight - she'll be back.'

Despite being on the other side of the world from many of her friends, Mother Aelred still corresponds with some of them. 'A lot of people I've known keep in touch - and they're not all churchgoers. I hear from people who have no belief, and often they ask me what I think of something or what I'd do if I were them.'

The life Christine embraced is, by any standards, an austere one - and radically different from her previous existence. 'When I first entered the order I wore ordinary clothes, but eight months on I was clothed in my habit. Instead of the jeans and shorts I'd always worn, I was in this thick, long habit and veil,' she says.

There was no television to watch, no lie-ins to relish - the nuns rise at 5am - and the independent life she had led before was exchanged for the strict rules of a religious order. The level of obedience expected from the nuns is so great that seven years ago, Mother Aelred was summoned to be told she was being transferred from Sydney to her order's mother house at Marble Arch, where she remains today.

Has she, for even a moment, regretted her decision? She is laughing before the question is out: she cannot contemplate regret in the context of this decision. 'I'm not saying it's always easy, living here with 18 other women and my family on the other side of the world, but what we are doing here is giving witness to the Gospel values. We are a little oasis of prayer in the midst of a big city, and we mean a lot to a lot of people.'

Downshift

From restaurant chef to environmental activist

All her life, Joyce Hambling has loved food. Wooed by its luscious variety of textures, flavours and colours, she chose a career in restaurants, first as a waitress and later as a chef. Jobs in high-profile establishments such as London's L'Escargot nurtured this love, and five years ago she decided to become a self- employed caterer.

Prestigious contracts to provide food for events such as London Fashion Week followed. Then Greenpeace asked her to cook for them. 'I can only describe what happened as a road-to-Damascus conversion. My first thought when I got the Greenpeace contract was that they would look good on my client list. I had always thought of food in terms of its gorgeousness - how much olive oil you could throw at a dish, that sort of thing.'

Towards the end of 1996, Greenpeace environmental campaigners were involved in blockading the port of Liverpool to prevent the first genetically modified crops coming into the UK. 'I decided to find out a bit more about why they were doing this, and read an article in Guardian Weekend about the possibilities of growing oranges in Scotland and mange tout in Manchester if these foods were genetically modified to flourish in an alien climate. At first, having been brought up in an age of scientific discoveries, I thought wow, but by the end of the article I was saying, 'Oh, my God, what would that mean for countries in east Africa who have moved away from what they used to grow traditionally so they could have an export crop?' 'It suddenly occurred to me that I couldn't let these Greenpeace campaigners blockade while I just cooked their lunch. I felt that if I didn't make a stand too there would be nothing left to cook with.'

What she describes as 'a steep learning curve' followed. She became involved in the Genetic Engineering Network, a loose coalition of people and groups sharing information about genetic engineering. She has abandoned her catering business to work for them full time, collating news and email lists. The job has not been funded, so at the moment she has no salary. 'I've lost all my muscle tone because I no longer rush around carrying huge sacks of potatoes - instead I'm sitting at a desk reading through all this material. I read much more than I used to and always want to know the other side of the story.'

Aside from her passionate commitment to the campaign, Hambling, 35, believes the new way of working has liberated her. 'I'm free of all that 'I've worked an extra 15 minutes so that's an extra £3.20' stuff.' Even the luxuries she used to enjoy, such as grabbing a taxi, taking a friend out to dinner or buying a new pair of shoes, she has happily forgone.

'My change in direction has made all sorts of differences. I used to be the sort of person who would wear matching lipstick and nail varnish, but now I don't even know where my last dried-out mascara is. Some people think I've taken on sainthood and others think I've joined the ALF. 'The only trouble is that I'm in danger of becoming a bit boring because I love what I do so much and think about it all the time. Let's face it, there aren't many people who want to talk about intellectual property rights when they go to a party.

Upshift

Sara Denver, nurse turned solicitor

At the age of 18, Sara Denver set her heart on becoming a nurse and embarked on almost four years of training - first a degree, then a course to specialise in cardiothoracic intensive care. 'I loved my job, I was doing something practical and I enjoyed working with people.' After spending such a long time training, it never occurred to her that she would want to change, particularly to a career which would involve an even longer period of study. But a chance conversation with a disaffected doctor who had decided to jettison medicine in favour of law had a profound effect on her.

She began to find out as much as she could about training and what a job as a solicitor would entail. 'I wanted to find out as much as I could, as once you've left a career it's quite hard to go back to it.'

Research completed, she decided that law would suit her perfectly. And she hoped that when she qualified she would be able to use some of her skills gained in the NHS to specialise in medical negligence cases. Another protracted training stint followed - this time for five years - with a one-year law conversion course then two years of legal practice and finally a two-year training contract with a firm of solicitors.

'I qualified in September and it feels great. I loved the challenge of studying for something new; law was something I really wanted to do for myself but at the same time I think I've chosen something useful.'

While she doesn't know of many lawyers who have changed career direction, Denver, 32, can think of many colleagues from medicine who are now doing different jobs.

She says an increasing number of medical negligence cases are being taken out, which means an abundant supply of work is likely. 'I don't know whether the incidences of negligence are increasing or whether people are becoming more aware of legal action as an option.'

She is certain there won't be any more lightning career changes. 'This is it now. I'm so much happier in this career; I feel I can really make a difference to people. I would recommend changing direction to anyone. Explore the options thoroughly, but don't be afraid of change.'
fields.bodyText: Get thee to a nunnery A letter from a friend set Christine Norden on the path to joining a convent 'People often ask me, how did you know? And I always say, when something is right, God makes you know.' A stone's throw from the noise and bustle of London's Marble Arch, 40-year-old Mother Aelred, Adorer of the Sacred Heart, is contemplating the idea of 'becoming' a nun. 'People have these ideas of what a nun is like, and one of the reasons my friends were so shocked at what I was doing was that I didn't seem like their idea of a nun. Some people think a nun is someone who can't cope with life; others that you've been hurt in love or had some terrible trauma. I know some of my friends thought something must have been going on in my life that they didn't know about.' Her home, Tyburn Convent, stands near the site where the Catholic martyrs of the Reformation died on the gallows. But Mother Aelred, then Christine Norden, had never heard of Tyburn when, 12 years ago, she went to visit the London convent's sister house on the outskirts of Sydney in her native Australia. Originally Anglican, at 22 she had converted to Catholicism, scandalising her parents. Now she was about to scandalise them further, by entering a silent and enclosed order of Benedictine nuns. 'It didn't seem right for me at all - I love talking, and I really enjoyed the outdoor life,' she says. 'I'd been to university and done a degree, I'd worked as a personnel officer and I could have carved out a good career for myself. But there was something missing.' Mother Aelred says that as she grew older she realised that, whatever she did with her life, it would have to be done wholeheartedly: 'I knew I'd want to give myself totally to it. And I couldn't find a man, or a career, or anything else that I felt was enough to give myself to totally. Until the convent, and that fateful day. 'The only way I could do anything totally was to do it for God. For a while, I thought I'd probably become a missionary or join an active religious order. But then a friend wrote and asked me if I'd considered joining this convent in Sydney which had some connection to a convent in London. And while I was thinking about it, by chance, I read an article in a magazine about the Adorers of the Sacred Heart - it was very strange!' The moment she set foot in the chapel of the Sydney convent, Mother Aelred knew it was right for her. 'I could see the sisters across the chapel praying, and I knew this was the life I yearned for, what God was calling me to do,' she says. 'I went to see the prioress and said that if I'd had no commitments I'd join them. And she said, do you mean that? Because if you want to, you can. 'I couldn't believe it could be so simple - that I really could take this step. But knowing it could happen didn't deter me at all - I wasn't scared; I was absolutely certain this was the right thing.' Despite the protestations of her family and friends she decided against sitting the final exams in the nursing course she had been taking. 'They thought that if the convent didn't work out, I'd at least have finished the course - but I didn't need that kind of insurance policy, I knew it would work out,' she says. Four weeks after her first visit, having sold her car and given all her possessions away to friends, Christine was back on the convent doorstep. She left behind a deeply hurt mother and an angry father, but she has since been reconciled with her parents. And her friends were just incredulous. 'The reaction of the friends I told was interesting: they basically divided into two camps. The first were so amazed they never mentioned it again, and the other group were fascinated and they just asked me questions all the time. But most of them thought, give her a fortnight - she'll be back.' Despite being on the other side of the world from many of her friends, Mother Aelred still corresponds with some of them. 'A lot of people I've known keep in touch - and they're not all churchgoers. I hear from people who have no belief, and often they ask me what I think of something or what I'd do if I were them.' The life Christine embraced is, by any standards, an austere one - and radically different from her previous existence. 'When I first entered the order I wore ordinary clothes, but eight months on I was clothed in my habit. Instead of the jeans and shorts I'd always worn, I was in this thick, long habit and veil,' she says. There was no television to watch, no lie-ins to relish - the nuns rise at 5am - and the independent life she had led before was exchanged for the strict rules of a religious order. The level of obedience expected from the nuns is so great that seven years ago, Mother Aelred was summoned to be told she was being transferred from Sydney to her order's mother house at Marble Arch, where she remains today. Has she, for even a moment, regretted her decision? She is laughing before the question is out: she cannot contemplate regret in the context of this decision. 'I'm not saying it's always easy, living here with 18 other women and my family on the other side of the world, but what we are doing here is giving witness to the Gospel values. We are a little oasis of prayer in the midst of a big city, and we mean a lot to a lot of people.' webTitle: Things to do on your last day at work

fields.headline: Things to do on your last day at work
fields.trailText: Steal away:
fields.body:
Steal away:

Avail yourself of the choicest resources. Obviously, this should not involve stealing stationery, state-of-the-art computer equipment or nifty ergonomic chairs; this kind of office crime costs British businesses £1bn each year, according to the Association of British Insurers. It would be similarly irresponsible to suggest making off with contacts lists or other information resources, since this, too, can constitute a crime. Don't say you haven't been warned.

Express yourself:

Tell your boss what you really think about her or him. If you can't stomach doing it face to face or want to keep your options open for future employment, the internet offers boundless opportunities for spleen-venting. Send an anonymous message via www.e-yourboss.com, a website you can pay to tell your manager where to go; or you can send anonymous email (www.anonymizer.com, among others) or, more specifically, draw attention to your superior's bad breath by sending a tasteful yet anonymous 'floss-o-gram'' through www.floss.com.

Make a meal of it:

Invite all those who have made your working life a misery to a leaving dinner at an expensive restaurant. Order plenty of good wine and express heartfelt gratitude for the way they have made your job a fulfilling experience. Then excuse yourself to go to the loo and leave without paying.

Be a prankster:

Leave your mark with the kind of office prank management consultants and insurance companies call 'sabotage''. According to urban mythology, one UK bank sent thousands of its wealthiest clients a communication addressed to Rich Bastard.

Schmooze the boss:

Introduce yourself to the managing director or chief executive. Visit his or her office bearing a small present, shake hands and - with sarcasm so subtle they won't be able to discern it - offer profuse thanks for the deep personal interest he or she has taken in the development of your career. Do this just before leaving and have all your belongings with you since, as you have never met before, he or she may call security to have you removed. As you're thrown out on to the pavement you can at least congratulate yourself on having a superior wry wit to your former boss, even if he or she has a superior salary.

fields.headline: Tales from the riverbank
fields.standfirst:
Mark Dion
Tate Gallery, London: Rating ****
fields.trailText: It could be an Elizabethan witch's totem or a contemporary manifestation of wicca. Either way the crude wax figure fished out of the Thames by American artist Mark Dion is creepy.
fields.body:
It could be an Elizabethan witch's totem or a contemporary manifestation of wicca. Either way the crude wax figure fished out of the Thames by American artist Mark Dion is creepy. It lies in a drawer in the Tate Gallery along with charred animal jaws and bears' claws, a rusty chain attached to a pole that you imagine might have been used to drown river pirates, and a medieval scabbard - which, on closer inspection, turns out to be a child's plastic toy. As an authority on the Thames and its history, Dion, who spent the summer foraging outside what will soon be Tate Modern and Tate Britain, is even more unreliable than the guides who wing it on tourist riverboats to Greenwich. The objects he discovered are not classified by period or labelled, but arranged according to an aesthetic taxonomy all his own, in the Tate's Art Now room. The Thames is being rebranded for the millennium, but Dion echoes Marlow in Conrad's Heart of Darkness who says that 'this also has been one of the dark places of the earth'. He invokes the river's secret histories, anonymous, forgotten dramas. How is this art? Dion trained as a natural scientist. His installations are 'research'. Here it is the way we imagine ourselves in history that is in question. Dion's installation removes the rational structures - dates, narratives, names - we impose on history to keep it at a distance, to turn time into history. This is the undertow of millennial London.
 Until February 27

fields.headline: Outlook brightens for euro
fields.standfirst:
Duisenberg says rapid EU growth this year will help reverse currency's decline

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Economic growth in the 11-nation euro zone will outstrip that of the US over the next two years, according to Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank.
fields.body:
Economic growth in the 11-nation euro zone will outstrip that of the US over the next two years, according to Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank.

That should benefit the euro, the single currency which made its debut on the foreign exchanges a year ago and has since lost about 13% of its value against the US dollar.

"We expect during the course of this year the euro will go in the opposite direction... The euro has strong upward potential," the ECB president said in an interview on Dutch television last night.

Looking ahead to economic prospects for Euroland in 2000, Mr Duisenberg said: "We now expect growth in Europe during the course of this year to be faster than growth in America and that will remain in 2001. "That is the basic background why we say the euro now has upward potential."

The fall in the euro from its launch rate of around $1.17 to near parity has proved a mixed blessing for the euro zone. So far the region has been able to enjoy the benefits of a competitive exchange rate without inflation taking off but the decline in the euro's international value has done nothing to enhance its prestige as a reserve currency.

Part of the reason for the decline has been the relatively sluggish performance of leading Euroland economies compared to the US but the currency has also been bedevilled by rows between the Frankfurt-based ECB and the German government over the need for Europe's biggest economy to restructure.

Such openly conflicting views, coupled with the ECB's studied avoidance of intervention in the foreign exchanges, helped maintain the downward pressure on the fledgling currency.

Although Mr Duisenberg and his colleagues are keen to see the euro recover at least some of the ground lost over the past year, the ECB president sought to play down the importance that tended to be attached to the exchange rate.

"Europe needs to learn a little bit, I think, that the effect of a change in the level of the currency on the national economy... is much less for the whole single Europe than it was earlier on an individual member state."

During the interview Mr Duisenberg risked reopening the controversy over how long he will stay at the helm of the ECB.

The former Dutch central bank governor was appointed to the ECB for an eight-year term but a behind-the-scenes row was settled by an informal agreement that Mr Duisenberg would serve only part of his term before handing over to the governor of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet.

The squabble caused con cern in the financial markets where there was concern that the compromise over the presidency could be a sign that the ECB would not be as independent of political interference as had been expected.

In last night's interview Mr Duisenberg refused to be drawn on when he would quit but appeared to insist that he would be the one to determine when he would stand down.

"I'll be 65 this year. Certainly I'll still do a number of years, but whether I'll stay the full eight years, I haven't taken that decision yet. That will come later."

webTitle: Lloyd's site falls victim to hacker

fields.headline: Lloyd's site falls victim to hacker
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Lloyd's of London, the world-leading insurance market, was yesterday forced to close down access to its website - not because it had fallen victim to the millennium computer bug - but because an old-style computer hacker managed to break into the system.
fields.body:
Lloyd's of London, the world-leading insurance market, was yesterday forced to close down access to its website - not because it had fallen victim to the millennium computer bug - but because an old-style computer hacker managed to break into the system.

The individual hacker is believed to have struck twice, first at 4am and again at noon, and on both occasions left messages on the site to show they had successfully broken in.

A spokeswoman for Lloyd's said that the website was run by an independent company and was unconnected to any other of Lloyd's computer systems. "We have had one person attack the site on two occasions in the last 12 hours," she said. "As a result we have closed down the site until we can find out how they got in. There are no implications for other Lloyd's systems."

The website provides information for members of brokers and agents working on the Lloyd's market, but is not used to carry out any online business transactions.

Although the security breach was unconnected with the millennium bug, Lloyd's informed both the Bank of England and the Financial Services Authority, which have been monitoring all computer glitches over the millennium weekend.

The spokeswoman said that the timing of the first break-in on the website in the early hours of the morning pointed to a hacker overseas, possibly in the US.

The hacker's comments added to the site made reference to Lloyd's internet security. The spokeswoman described the wording as "neither witty nor clever".

Computer hacking is becoming an increasingly serious problem. While some hackers have sought to break into sites simply to demonstrate their ability to do so, others have sought to spread viruses - some recent examples were apparently designed to mimic the millennium bug - which can cause wide spread damage.

fields.headline: Smuts in their eyes
fields.standfirst:
Follow the Star! Jackie Clune
The Drill Hall, London
***
fields.trailText: 'Think of this show as an ornamental glass of eggnog being poured from a bowl of happiness,' Jackie Clune tells us. She has bounced on stage in a nifty white PVC number, backed up by her two male dancers, and swung into the first Christmas number (Yulesville or Bust) before we even know where we are. Kick, turn, and off to the Christmas log cabin ('I kept the builders up all night to get this ready: ooh my lips were chapped in the morning'). Welcome to the familiar innuendo-filled world of pantomime. Clune crosses Christmas with her own brand of off-off-West End theatre, paying homage to Abba, James Bond, All Saints and, most importantly of all, herself. The songs are sharp and funny, though some of the surrounding material a bit less so. For the first half some of her gags seem a little tired or misplaced: it is not until just before the interval, and then for the much tighter second half that we feel completely Cluned up. That is probably where that slight edge comes from: sometimes, when Clune is talking herself up, or down, we are not sure how to take her. She spends half the time making jokes about exhausting men, and the other half telling Richard Whiteley (who calls her up during the show, although we suspect it may be recorded - no, really) to stop pestering her: 'I'm a lesbian, I've told you before.' After Clune's This is Your Life (featuring Mel and Sue coming out of the shower cabinet) and her very own fly-on-the-wall documentary, we make up our minds that though she may be a bit of a cow, she is our kind of cow, the kind of cow you would like to spend a night in the pub with, picking everyone in the room apart.
fields.body: 'Think of this show as an ornamental glass of eggnog being poured from a bowl of happiness,' Jackie Clune tells us. She has bounced on stage in a nifty white PVC number, backed up by her two male dancers, and swung into the first Christmas number (Yulesville or Bust) before we even know where we are. Kick, turn, and off to the Christmas log cabin ('I kept the builders up all night to get this ready: ooh my lips were chapped in the morning').
